PARA.TAB: Mr SPEAKER (Hon. R. G. Halverson OBE) took the chair at 12.30 p.m., and read prayers.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Nugent, Peter, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That this House:

(1) welcomes the initiative of the Council for Aboriginal Reconciliation to launch a National Reconciliation Week to be held each year from 27 May to 3 June for at least the next five years up to 2001, the centenary of Federation;

(2) notes that the inaugural National Reconciliation Week beginning on 27 May 1996 will launch twelve months of community activities and a public awareness campaign leading up to the Australian Reconciliation Convention, which will be held during National Reconciliation Week in 1997;
(3) reaffirms its commitment to a process of reconciliation; and
(4) calls on all Australians to support the National Reconciliation Week and thereby to advance the reconciliation process.

As I am sure we are all aware as we meet in the chamber now, in the Great Hall of this parliament there are a large number of people assembled at a reconciliation lunch hosted by the Prime Minister (Mr Howard), the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Beazley) and the Leader of the Australian Democrats (Senator Kernot). Amongst those at that lunch today, 27 May, which marks the anniversary of the 1967 referendum—and also, at the end of the week, 3 June marks the anniversary of the Mabo decision which is so important to indigenous people in this country—are a great number of people who have prominence and interest in these affairs of state.

Present, for example, are the first indigenous member of the federal parliament, Senator Neville Bonner, and Mrs Mabo. There are a number of activists from that campaign all those years ago in 1967. All of them have come here today to support the process of reconciliation in our country between the indigenous Aboriginal and the Torres Strait Islander people and the wider community. Those people there and the dates that we are signifying today are part of the living history that is represented in our community, and it is a living history that marks specifically a turning point in the history of our country. The establishment of the Council for Aboriginal Reconciliation was another turning point. It had cross‐party support for the recognition that reconciliation is a process which has to be worked at; it will not just happen.

The council, of which I and the seconder of this motion, the honourable member for Banks (Mr Melham) are both members, is halfway through its term and it continues to need support for its processes and for its actions from parliamentarians. It needs support from its parliamentarians actively—not just tacit support. It needs support from the constituencies in working at bringing people together, in developing a better understanding of our history, in recognising the different cultures, in respecting the differences between indigenous people and the broader community while rejecting intolerance and helping to overcome some of those problems, and in fact working together actively for the future of all Australians.

The Prime Minister and other political leaders are in the Great Hall today and they will all be speaking. I know that they will be demonstrating their commitment to this process and showing us the way at the national level. But we need to spread the message not only in the highest councils but of course right across the land. There are some 25 members on the council for reconciliation, and I will not go through them all, but there are a number of very distinguished Australians who serve on the council—people who feel that it is important that we address this subject in our community to heal some of the wounds and the difficulties that have gone before. I refer to Ian Spicer from the Australian Chamber of Commerce and Industry; Jennie George from the ACTU; Robert Champion de Crespigny from the mining industry; Ian Viner, a former member of this place and a former Minister for Aboriginal Affairs; and Ray Martin, who would be well known to those in the gallery, of course. Ray, apart from being a very popular media personality, has a serious commitment to this cause and lends all the weight and authority he can to getting proper exposure in the media. Of course there is our chairman, Patrick Dodson, who I think has performed outstandingly in the last five years in this process.

But this process is not just about a few big names. It is about what we do at grassroots. As well as having the big launch here at parliament today, the things that will happen during the course of this week are going to happen at grassroots. There will also be today, for example, a flag raising ceremony and a formal launch of the week at the Adelaide town hall to mark the inaugural meeting of the South Australian Eminent Persons Group in Support of Reconciliation. Tomorrow in New South Wales there will be a launch at the Powerhouse Museum hosted by Ray Martin. On Thursday, the Australian of the Year, paediatrician Dr John Yu, and Patrick Dodson will speak on health as a reconciliation issue in a ward at Westmead Children's Hospital. Also on Thursday is the launch of a cross‐cultural awareness package for medical students and doctors announced by not only Patrick Dodson but also the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs (Senator Herron) and the New South Wales Deputy Premier, Andrew Refshauge.

We are going to have ethnic communities involved in the activities during the course of the week. In Tasmania there will be the launch of the Tasmanian reconciliation bus, painted with the Council for Aboriginal Reconciliation logo. That of course will be an activity that is most important, and it will coincide with the Tasmanian Police Academy graduation. Reconciliation and the activities of the police in this country go hand in hand because we have to deal with some of the issues of incarceration rates.

A number of key stakeholders will be here at the end of the week to talk about native title—from the mining sector, from the pastoral sector, from indigenous communities right across the board, and leaders of the community in the business and agricultural fields. In my own state of Victoria other activities will be going on this week. The Victorian eminent persons groups support the work of the council and they will have a major function in Melbourne this week. We will also have the Maribyrnong River cultural heritage trail project opened to specifically mark this week. A number of local activities are taking place and it is important that in talking about reconciliation we recognise that the focus on reconciliation must be at the grassroots level.

This time next year, the focus of reconciliation week will be a major convention to be held in Melbourne. Between now and then, the council will be working hard to progress a complex but critical number of issues, including whether there should be some form of document of reconciliation. It is important to engage public interest and support in thinking through a number of the challenging questions associated with Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander reconciliation with the broader community.

We will have some setbacks on the way but it is important that we adopt a positive attitude. We need constructive discussion where there may be disagreement. I was personally very disappointed to see an article in the Australian this morning which I do not believe helps the process at all. Reconciliation is something we must discuss and debate. We may not always have the same views but it is important that we be constructive and give our full attention to these matters.

There are a number of issues which the council believes are critical to its progress, including these key ones: understanding of country, the importance of land and sea in Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander societies; improving relationships, looking for better relationships between indigenous Australians and the wider community; valuing cultures, recognising indigenous cultures as a valued part of Australian heritage; sharing histories, a sense for all Australians of a shared ownership of history; addressing disadvantage, the greater awareness of the causes of indigenous Australians' disadvantage; a greater community response to addressing the underlying causes of the custody levels in this country; agreeing on a document, whether the process of reconciliation would be advanced by a document or documents of reconciliation; and, finally, making sure of greater opportunities for indigenous Australians to control their destinies.

In the last five years, which are but a blink in the last 200‐odd years of the history of this country, I believe we have made some progress but a lot more needs to be done. I urge all members not only to support this motion but also to actively support the process to achieve the vision of the Council for Aboriginal Reconciliation of a united Australia which respects this land of ours, values the Aboriginal and Torres Strait heritage and provides justice and equity for all.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the motion seconded?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Melham, Daryl, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, I second the motion. As the shadow minister for Aboriginal affairs, I represent the Australian Labor Party on the Council for Aboriginal Reconciliation. The council's vision is as follows: a united Australia which respects this land of ours, values the Aboriginal and Torres Strait heritage, and provides justice and equity for all.

SPEECH.PARA: We are celebrating the first National Reconciliation Week. National Reconciliation Week will be celebrated across Australia annually until the year 2001, the centenary of Federation. The dates are 27 May to 3 June, which are anniversary dates of watershed events when Australians stood up for justice and reconciliation.

On 27 May 1967, 90 per cent of Australians voted in a referendum to remove discriminatory clauses from the constitution and to give the Commonwealth the power to legislate for Aboriginal people. On 3 June 1992, the High Court's Mabo decision overturned the concept of terra nullius—that the continent was empty, that the land was unowned before 1788. National Reconciliation Week is an opportunity for all Australians to observe those national achievements and to take the reconciliation process a little bit further. Patrick Dodson, the council's chairperson, had this to say:
By getting involved in National Reconciliation Week, Australians can stand up and be counted as people of goodwill. By pinning on a badge—
similar to the one I wear today—

slapping on a sticker, flying the Australian, Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander flags together, we can demonstrate we support reconciliation and a fair go for all Australians. Let's all share in the future of this nation. Let's work together towards the Council's vision:

PARA.EMPHASIS: a united Australia; which respects this land of ours; values the Aboriginal and Torres Strait heritage; and provides justice and equity for all.

SPEECH.PARA: Together we can make a difference.

We stand here collectively as people who represent one side of the reconciliation process; namely, non‐indigenous Australians. Substantial achievements have occurred since the 1967 referendum, but we have to admit much more needs to be done. It can only be done in a spirit of goodwill, trust and a preparedness to recognise the other side has a point of view.

Recently, many indigenous people have lost their faith in reconciliation because it seems that at every turn they face betrayal. It seems to many that the hard fought victories of years gone by are being eroded. Governments are reneging on deals made with indigenous peoples. There are many individuals who, through sheer mean‐spiritedness, would betray indigenous people by turning back the clock on the hard won victories. Reconciliation has to be a two‐way street. It cannot be that it is always indigenous people who have to give ground every time there is a conflict of interest.

Today is not a day for political point scoring by me. It is not a day that I come here eager to diminish my political opponents. It is a day I come here to urge greater strength of unity and understanding and offer my party's support for the reconciliation process. Reconciliation cannot be just mere words. It needs to be actioned upon. It needs to be actioned upon by all major political parties; we all are stakeholders in reconciliation.

There has been genuine cross‐party support towards reconciliation. On the Council for Aboriginal Reconciliation all major political parties are represented. The trade union movement is represented. The business community is represented. But it is fair to say that at our meeting yesterday there was a sense of despair and frustration creeping into members on the council. It was felt that in recent months prejudice and fear have been creeping into the national debate, that the blind and prejudiced were leading the blind and prejudiced.

I commend the government on its fortitude in standing up to sections within its own party that are calling for legislation to extinguish native title in relation to pastoral leases. I commend the government and the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) for resisting the temptation to suspend the Racial Discrimination Act and to take sides. Reconciliation should be a win-win situation. It should not have to be a situation where indigenous people are required to give ground. Consultations by the government are taking place. I would urge the government not only to talk to indigenous people but also to listen to what they have to say. I believe that with goodwill we can achieve cross‐party support to resolve some problems without taking away people's rights.

As I said earlier, today is not a day for political point scoring. The Australian Labor Party will support the government in areas of reconciliation. We will look at, in a constructive fashion, legislation that is brought before this parliament. But I can say this: the support that the Australian Labor Party gives can only be given if there is a genuine spirit of goodwill being offered by the government.

It is pleasing to see that the celebration taking place in the Great Hall today is being attended by all political parties. There are over 500 people in the Great Hall representing all interests. I have just left the ceremony and I will be going back there. What was moving was a song that was written and sung by Johnny Huckle. It was called Embrace Love. The Narrabundah Primary School choir provided the backdrop. Some words of the song are: `When the power of love defeats the love of power the world will be a better place.'

It is my belief that a united Australia which respects this land of ours, values the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander heritage, and provides justice and equity for all will provide a better Australia for all of us.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Nelson, Dr Brendan, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —In rising to support this motion on National Reconciliation Week, I wish first of all to recognise the people of the Ngunawal nation who originally occupied and owned this land. In five minutes it is very difficult to cover all the issues that are so important to Australians. Rose Colless AM is an Aboriginal woman who has given her life to helping her people affected by alcohol in the Yarrabah region around Cairns. When I first met her I asked her what she thought about reconciliation. After a long pause she whispered, `I've been trying to reconcile this all my life.'

SPEECH.PARA: About 80 kilometres north of Weipa on the Cape is a place called Mapoon. In November 1963, after months of protracted negotiations, the mining companies decided that they needed to clear the land of Aboriginal people to legally use it for their mining leases. In November 1963—not 1863 but 1963—the police and the people from the mining companies came and cleared the land of Aboriginal people. At gunpoint the people were forced into boats and they were dispersed to Bamaga in the tip of the Cape and as far south as Cairns. Then homes were bulldozed and burned. When I was there in July 1994—the community is rebuilding itself—I met a woman called Constance Cooktown, who had been there that day. She had been out fishing with her husband and returned to find the homes and the houses burning and her children gone.

At Walgett in western New South Wales I spoke to an Aboriginal woman who tearfully recounted seeing, as a little girl, a family of children being taken away on the back of a mission truck. She said to me, `I can still see that little girl on the back of the truck. She must have been about six, with a little rag hat on. She went away and we never seen her any more. She was crying. Everyone was crying. Things like that never leave your memory.'

In 1992 I was a year away from taking over the leadership of the Australian Medical Association. I recall asking one of the senior bureaucrats in the organisation who in our office was working on Aboriginal health. I was told that nobody was. Yet here was an organisation that was probably—and is probably—the peak organisation to represent the interests of the medical profession and the concerns of the community on health care in Australia. Not one page of the Aboriginal deaths in custody royal commission report, which had volumes on health, had been opened in that office.

Thinking in terms of what reconciliation is all about, amongst other things it is calling on Australians, wherever they are from and whatever organisations they may represent, to challenge and change the attitudes of a section of this society who seem not to appreciate what has happened in the past. What this country needs is a deficit reduction strategy on Aboriginal death, intolerance and prejudice. Whatever else we achieve as a nation, if we make no progress at all in this area then, as far as I am concerned, we will have achieved nothing.

During this national week of reconciliation, Australians should ask themselves and ask their children, `How would I feel if this was done to me?' In asking the question, the meaning of reconciliation will be found. It is about all of us—black and white—not for a day or a week but for the remainder of our lives asking ourselves how we would feel and trying to put ourselves in the place of another person. As one of the newly elected members said in issuing a challenge to some members in this place, `You come out to some of these Aboriginal areas and tell me you wish you had been born there.'

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ferguson, Martin, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —As I stand here today to speak as part of National Reconciliation Week, I think back on my experiences of working in the Northern Territory, working cooperatively and in a practical manner with large groups of Aboriginal workers, both traditional and non-traditional, who enrolled as members of my union, the North Australian Workers Union.

SPEECH.PARA: It is through this experience and through my work with such people as Ella Ahmat, Denise Ahsam and Jim and Bingy Clarke that I have come to believe that Australia cannot expect to find real reconciliation until we face up to a number of key areas of deprivation which Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people face. Those areas, I suggest, include housing, jobs, education and health.

The indigenous people I have worked with have always said that they ask for nothing more than to be treated as equals and to be recognised as the first peoples who lived in and worked this great land of ours. In these short moments I want to talk about how we endeavour to overcome the huge barriers that exist before Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people can truly say they have equality with all other Australians. That is what reconciliation is all about: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people having equality with all other Australians.

I say very clearly today that I believe progress is being made and the story is not all negative. In doing so, I refer specifically to some of our successes in the state of Queensland. I refer to the Aboriginal communities at Cherbourg and Shalom College in Townsville as positive stories of where we are making progress as a community. However, it is visits to places like this which give hope that these small sparks of light will quickly spread and glow like a bushfire and therefore make sure that we glow the light of reconciliation across the great length and breadth of Australia.

Interestingly, both these communities have used the problem of providing housing to their communities as the hook to resolve other key issues such as education and training and jobs. As you can appreciate, access to housing and the quality of our housing is something most Australians see as a fundamental right. Unfortunately, that is not the case in Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander communities. In fact, very few Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islanders ever expect to be home owners. More importantly, it is now internationally recognised that their housing is of a quality closer to Third World standards than to what we would normally expect as Australians.

Real reconciliation will only come when we can ensure that the majority of our Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander brothers and sisters know that as a natural right their housing standards, wherever they live, are equal to those of almost any house in any town, city or suburb of this country. I also praise those communities because in facing up to their housing needs they have sought to bring in state and federal government departments of labour and in so doing use the labour market programs to provide practical training and employment opportunities which have then created a sense of pride and achievement in the local communities.

On that note, I believe we as a parliament should do everything possible to ensure that those types of programs continue so that these communities have the opportunity to face up in a very practical sense to their own ability to go forward and to dedicate sufficient local resources, in association with government support, to provide those opportunities that not only mean real training and jobs but also make a fundamental improvement to the standard of living in their local communities.

Reconciliation will only work for all Australians if we look practically at ways to give our Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander brothers and sisters opportunities for real jobs, good education, quality health care and appropriate housing.

Mr LINDSAY (Herbert) (1.01 p.m.) I encourage the people of Herbert and all the schools, community organisations and business groups throughout Townsville and Thuringowa to get involved in National Reconciliation Week. Francis Tapim, the Executive Director of Magani Malu Kes, the Torres Strait Islander Resource Centre in Townsville, has asked me to pass on to the parliament, on behalf of that group, his message. Mr Tapim said:
We want everyone to come together and respect each other's cultural values—united as one, all Australians together.
What is past is in the past. There was great social injustice. But let's move on and get on with the challenges that lie ahead.
We just want everyone to come together and recognise that all of us in Australia have something to offer.

Francis Tapim's attitude gives me heart that reconciliation is achievable and will be rewarding for all Australians. But reconciliation does not just happen; we need to continually work at it over time.

Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander men and women have a significantly lower life expectancy than non‐indigenous Australians. The infant mortality rate for indigenous children is much higher. Indigenous Australians lag behind in employment and in access to all areas of education. They are over‐ represented in our gaols and under‐represented in the day‐to‐day decision making processes at all levels of government.

Palm Island is an Aboriginal settlement located in my electorate, and it is probably the suicide capital of Australia. Over the last two months there has been, on average, one suicide a week. The vast majority of these people are aged between 17 and 25—a shocking statistic when you consider that 50 per cent of Islanders are under the age of 25.

The reconciliation process must include providing indigenous people with better access to appropriate health and mental health services, fair and equitable access to education services, and more culturally relevant education curriculums. Improving the educational facilities and supporting appropriate curriculum changes will go a long way towards improving the standard of living on Palm Island—it may even save lives.

The reconciliation process should also pursue employment programs for indigenous Australians. Speaking on Aboriginal employment in March 1981, former Senator Neville Bonner, who is in the parliament today and who is a person who knows what life can be like on Palm Island, said:

There is no sense in creating employment opportunities which will not be satisfactory for Aboriginal people and which will not give them a sense of responsibility and sense of achievement. They want to contribute something to the Australian way of life. That is the kind of employment that we want.
Palm Islanders do not want handouts. They want the opportunity to work for real jobs, for better health and for a sense of self‐satisfaction.

I certainly support my colleague in the Senate, the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Transport and Regional Development, Grant Tambling, who continues to say that regional development projects can involve a successful working partnership with indigenous Australians. Yet, at the same time, we are seeing projects with tremendous employment and economic potential, such as Century Zinc, jeopardised by questions of native title. It is no wonder people are questioning the workability of the Native Title Act.

BREAK.PARA: I recognise that the economic future of this country depends on resource development, and I intend to support laws which will not allow people who do not have a substantial claim to stall development for years. But I also do not intend to allow these necessary changes to ride roughshod over the rights of indigenous Australians. Reconciliation is a two‐way street and the coalition government is working to realise appropriate outcomes for both parties.

In my electorate Townsville State High School has taken up the challenge, with an indigenous studies course being offered this year. So far it has been very successful. When I visited the school just three weeks ago, I saw the class in action. Do you know what? The majority of the class were not indigenous.

The timing of National Reconciliation Week is opportune. Hopefully, this week will help re‐focus attention on the need to continue to push ahead and to further the cause of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander reconciliation in Australia. I certainly support the motion, and I close with these words: `When the power of love defeats the love for power, Australia will be a better place.'

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown, Bob, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I am delighted to have an opportunity to associate myself with a bipartisan motion of this kind, and I congratulate the honourable member for Aston (Mr Nugent) on ensuring that it came forward. I congratulate the parliament and the Selection Committee as well on making sure that it came on to the program today. While we are here now, the inaugural National Reconciliation Week luncheon is taking place in the Great Hall.

SPEECH.PARA: I appreciate the comments that were made by the member for Herbert (Mr Lindsay), who concluded with a reference to some words that were sung at that luncheon just a short time ago by Johnny Huckle. Singing with him were the children from the Narrabundah Primary School choir here in Canberra.

Johnny Huckle introduced that song by saying that he was talking to a little child from Bosnia and that the child was crying. He asked the child why she was crying, and this child from Bosnia—with all the trauma and the dramas associated with those particular circumstances—said it was because Johnny Huckle was singing songs that caused her to be sad.

I emphasise those words that the member for Herbert referred to as well. The song that Johnny Huckle sang included these words: `When the power of love defeats the lust for power, the world will be a better place.'

I doubt whether there is anything more central to the whole question of reconciliation. Indigenous Australians occupied this continent for 60,000 years. European occupation, European settlement, has existed for only 200 years. When the Reverend Ian Allsop delivered the prayer at the luncheon in the Great Hall, he also said, `Help us to resolve conflict and to right the wrongs.'

Whatever non-indigenous Australians might say about the circumstances of the last 200 years and about how Aboriginal Australians were brought to the verge of extinction, there has been at least some degree of reconciliation in their thinking. I hope that this reconciliation in their thinking makes a major contribution to the practical efforts that are being made by people now and that will hopefully be made by people right across Australia to bring about a reconciliation between non-indigenous and indigenous Australians. That is not going to be an easy task, particularly because of the nature of the problems that indigenous Australians have and the fact that there are still some people in Australia who say that Aboriginal Australians are getting too much money thrown at them.

How can people say that in relation to, for example, health services? Aboriginal Australians have a life expectancy significantly lower than that of European Australians. Aboriginal infant mortality is significantly higher than that of European Australians. Young Aboriginal kids are suffering from diseases that are endemic in Third World countries. Aboriginal families are living under sheets of corrugated iron. Is there too much money being thrown at Aboriginal housing? In some places the rate of Aboriginal unemployment is up to 90 per cent. The average rate of unemployment for Aboriginal people in Australia is 38 per cent. Is too much money being thrown at their employment prospects?

BREAK.PARA: Mr Deputy Speaker, your personal commitment to this question is demonstrated not only by how you pursue these questions in your electorate but also by how you have contributed to addressing them in the committee work of the parliament. The commitment of the member for Lyne (Mr Vaile), who will speak after me, has been demonstrated as well. The extent to which, the way in which, and the success with which we address this problem, and the seriousness with which we pursue it, will to a large extent be a measure of our humanity.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vaile, Mark, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —It is an honour and a pleasure to have the opportunity to support the motion moved by the member for Aston (Mr Nugent) with regard to National Reconciliation Week. I, along with the other members who have spoken here this afternoon, have participated in the luncheon in the Great Hall. It is a great indication of the commitment of members in this place to the process of reconciliation. Members in this chamber will have different views as to the path that should be taken to achieve reconciliation, but it is imperative that we recognise the significance and importance of it. It is not a path that is actually to be found, in so far as we should be going searching for it; it is one that we have to construct from the day there is a commitment to the process of reconciliation.

SPEECH.PARA: My electorate has a very active organisation called the Manning Valley Australians for Reconciliation. They organised a fund raising dinner for 17 April this year. We had the honour of having Mr Patrick Dodson, chairperson of the Council for Aboriginal Reconciliation, as guest speaker at that dinner. I had the opportunity of talking with Pat Dodson on the day he was in Taree at a civic reception that was put on by Mayor Les Brown and again at the dinner at which he spoke. I also had the opportunity to talk to a number of other speakers at that dinner. The Manning River Times had a report on the fundraising dinner and Pat Dodson's visit to Taree. That report was very aptly headlined `Window of opportunity'. It states:
Mayor of Greater Taree City Council, Cr Les Brown welcomed Patrick Dodson to Taree by hailing him as Australia's Martin Luther-King.
"He is a man who I recognise as a very outstanding and distinguished Australian," Cr Brown said.
"Martin Luther-King had a dream and as I understand that is Patrick's ambition and what he is trying to achieve.
"We want Patrick to leave here today knowing this community is committed to reconciliation."
Councillor Les Brown made those comments at the civic reception that was accorded to Patrick Dodson when he visited Taree.

Manning Valley Australians for Reconciliation was recently formed and this year it plans to promote reconciliation in the community. Its definition of reconciliation is `understanding and respect of all cultures'. Its aims are: to further encourage and promote mutual awareness and respect for the heritage and cultures of both the Aboriginal and non-Aboriginal communities through the reconciliation process; to provide a positive information exchange; to develop active programs to promote reconciliation for the Manning community; and to consult and advise council, government departments, community organisations and the public on issues relating to reconciliation. It is interesting to note the diversity of the people involved in Manning Valley Australians for Reconciliation. They are not just indigenous people but also non-indigenous people. I would like to record in Hansard the efforts of the joint chairpersons of that organisation, Krishna Heffernan and Judith Johnston, and the secretary, Judy Browne.

A very strong Aboriginal education group, which comes under the New South Wales Department of School Education, is headed by Charles Davidson in Taree. This morning I received a copy of the department's Aboriginal education policy. The front page of that document states, `To promote the educational achievements of Aboriginal students. To educate all students about Aboriginal Australia.'

To me a very important element of this reconciliation process is education—not just education of indigenous people, but education of non-indigenous people about indigenous people. I went to mass here in Manuka on the weekend. One of the prayers which was given at the beginning of this week reads:

BREAK.PARA: We thank you, Lord, for your gift of conversion and reconciliation which restores our relationship with you and with one another.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Price, Roger, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support this motion. Since we are talking about reconciliation, I thought that I should perhaps offer a dictionary definition of what it means to reconcile. The dictionary says that it is to restore to friendship or harmony. The word `harmony' has a sense of peace about it. Being at peace with oneself and at peace with one another is perhaps one of the highest states that human beings can aspire to. Friendship is to esteem or value people. I think it is most appropriate that we should wish to value and esteem our Aboriginal Australians. After all, they are the original occupants of this land.

SPEECH.PARA: In my own electorate I am often asked what this means. Does it mean that this current generation should accept the guilt for the past 200 years? I think the answer to that is no. But I think it is also about understanding the history of the last 200 years. Therefore, I support this idea that the more we can publicise and make Australians understand the history of the Aboriginal people, that will go a long way to affording us to appropriately recognise and reconcile with them the injustices of the last 200 years.

In the publication put out by the Council for Aboriginal Reconciliation, Working Together, is the story of Lily's daughter. Lois O'Donoghue, the Chairperson of ATSIC, like many other Aboriginals, was ripped away from her mother and family. I do not think Australians really understand the impact of this on families. It just did not happen once; it was a serial activity that occurred in New South Wales right up to the 1960s. Today I am enjoying the company of my eldest daughter and granddaughter. I reflected on what it would be like to have her snatched away from the family, or to even have her mother snatched away. We have a lot to overcome.

PARA.BREAK: I am pleased to say that I have a lot of Aboriginals in my own electorate. I am very proud of them. I am also proud that I fly the Australian flag in my electorate office as well as the Aboriginal flag. In terms of the disad vantage suffered by Aboriginals in my electorate, when I first was a member of parliament I believed I had no Aboriginal students in year 11 and 12. Today I have 25, which is probably a retention rate of between 15 and 20 per cent, with the rest of Australia having about 70 to 80 per cent.

SPEECH.PARA: When we talk about reconciliation—other members have contributed to it—it is really about Aboriginals getting a fair crack at education and employment, the way we would wish for our own children and indeed all children. Again, I do not look at the unemployment rate for Aboriginals in my electorate because it is just so high, but it is not to say that they are not without undoubted ability and talent.

We always talk about the Aboriginal connection with the land, saying that this is a spiritual connection. I do not know that all of us can aspire to have that depth of understanding and feel for it, but I can say that there are many non-Aboriginals who, when we are at sea or when we are working the land, have a spiritual connection with it. I am certainly one of those. Therefore, I can better appreciate how important that is to the Aboriginals and how important the Mabo decision is.

I hope in the future—because we live in a task and target oriented society—that other speakers speaking next year to a similar motion will be able to talk about the great achievements and successes we have enjoyed in the last 12 months and the real confidence we have in facing the turn of the century and ensuring that Aboriginal Australians are valued, esteemed, restored to friendship and restored to harmony.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The time allotted for this debate has expired. The debate is adjourned and the resumption of the debate will be made an order of the day for the next sitting.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Worth, Trish, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That this House:
(1) extends its sympathies to the family and friends of all the victims of the Port Arthur massacre;
(2) recognises the outstanding work done by the police and emergency services during the tragedy and the efforts of those associated with the counselling of victims, their families and friends;
(3) congratulates the Prime Minister and the State and Territory governments in making a significant contribution to public safety by moving to ban automatic and semi‐automatic rifles and shotguns;
(4) acknowledges the contribution made by the Leader of the Opposition in securing a bipartisan approach to the issue of gun control; and
(5) acknowledges that many law abiding citizens who own guns may be inconvenienced by the ban on some types of firearms.

It is on behalf of the people of my electorate that I move this motion today. I convey their sympathy to the family, friends and loved ones of the victims of the Port Arthur massacre. The massacre had a profound impact not only on the small community of Port Arthur but also on the wider Australian community. The Broad Arrow Cafe will be demolished and the perpetrator of the crime will be punished, but this will not be enough. While the motives behind such a massacre are complex and not easily understood, lessons must be learnt and some good must result from this tragedy. Of course, there are issues related to mental illness to be considered but, overwhelmingly, the central issue is: do we accept a culture of violence or do we work against that as a matter of urgency?

In the lead-up to the 1988 presidential elections in the United States, George Bush said that he wanted a kinder, gentler America. Perhaps it was already too late for America, but it is not too late for Australia. But it will take women and men of considerable strength and determination to ensure a kinder, gentler Australia where there is less violence and therefore more personal safety and freedom.

The Prime Minister (Mr Howard) has shown the necessary leadership to achieve not only tighter gun control but also uniform laws. He has been supported by the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Beazley) and the Leader of the Australian Democrats (Senator Kernot). They must all be commended for the political support and sympathy they have shown to the survivors of the massacre and for those who now seek a safer, less violent society, free of the gun culture which is so entrenched in the United States.

Mr Deputy Speaker, this motion also pays tribute to the medical staff and health professionals, the ambulance workers, the emergency service people and the police who responded to all the emergencies that followed the massacre. They will never forget 28 April 1996. Dr Bryan Walpole, Chief Surgeon at Royal Hobart Hospital, led the team of doctors and nurses who treated and cared for the survivors of the massacre. He is quoted in the Sydney Morning Herald on 11 May as saying:
We went to war for a day in Tasmania and we saw on the bodies of all those people the havoc the weapons of war can wreak.
He continued:

If anything can come from what those people endured—the victims, the families, the friends, the ambulance workers, the emergency services people, the police, the doctors, the nurses—then there has to be change on gun control.

A similar message came from Pastor Allan Armstrong, who conducted the funeral service for Nanette, six‐year‐old Alannah and three‐year‐old Madeleine Mikac. All the deaths were horrific, but a young mother dying trying to protect her children was just too much for many of us. Pastor Armstrong said:
As a nation we have the ability to give to our mothers a safer society for their children.
To our national leaders we say do not trade your votes for lives. Hold to your resolve to deal with the menace of unnecessary firearms in our society.
He continued:

Listen not to the loud calls of the few who want to selfishly keep their weapons but instead hear the cries of those who have died, listen to the quiet sobs of those who live, see the majority who stand with them. Deliver to us uniform laws that will give our children the best possible chance to live without the fear of someone having access to violent power that can maim and kill.
These messages have been heeded and, after an all‐day meeting on 10 May, the Prime Minister made the following announcement:
The Commonwealth and the States and Territories today agreed on a uniform and tougher approach to gun laws which will make Australia a safer place to live.
The agreement includes a ban on automatic and semi automatic rifles and shotguns and a nationwide approach to registration and licensing.

The Australian community demanded urgent and effective action on tougher gun laws and today all governments have answered that call with a comprehensive action plan which will deliver effective nationwide controls.
We have agreed to prohibit the importation, ownership, sale, resale, transfer, possession, manufacture or use of:
all military-style centre-fire rifles including those which substantially duplicate military styles;
all other self-loading centre-fire rifles;
all self-loading and pump-action shotguns and
all self-loading rim fire rifles.
The importation ban will be effective immediately.
The exceptions will be a limited range of official or occupational purposes certified by a permit.
Action will be taken to strictly regulate mail orders.

I commend everyone who worked towards the historic agreement brokered to give Australia the opportunity to avoid the gun culture which has so impacted on the ordinary citizens of some other countries.

I trust there will be the same resolve as complementary laws are passed around the country. The loss of life at Port Arthur has become a catalyst for action following on other recent multiple killings in Australia where guns were used.

In August 1987, seven people were shot in Melbourne in the Hoddle Street killings; in December 1987, eight people were killed in Melbourne in the Queen Street massacre; in August 1990, five people were shot in Surry Hills, Sydney; in August 1991, six people were shot and one stabbed in the Strathfield Shopping Plaza, Sydney; in October 1992, six people were shot by a lone gunman on the central coast of New South Wales; in August 1993, three people were shot dead by a gunman in the inner west of Sydney; and in January 1996, seven people were shot dead in a murder‐suicide in a Brisbane suburb.

It has been estimated that 84 per cent of victims in mass killings between 1987 and 1993 were killed by a licensed gun holder, while 86 per cent of the victims were reportedly killed by a person with no record of violent crime or mental illness. The statistics on mass killings are chilling but other statistics are more chilling and should stand alone as a single reason—if one single reason was needed—to severely restrict the availability of guns. In 1994, 420 Australians used a firearm to commit suicide and 76 Australians were the victims of intentional killing, often by people known to them or family members. So guns play a big role in domestic homicides.
Firearms contribute to death and injury in two ways: first in terms of their availability and second because they are lethal. The National Committee on Violence found that:

The vast majority of firearms homicides are unplanned and impulsive, and in all likelihood would not occur if such a lethal weapon were not to hand. The availability of a firearm in these circumstances makes death a far greater likelihood, for research has demonstrated that the death rate for victims assaulted by guns is several times that of those assaulted with lethal intent by knives or other weapons.

I have spoken with Dr Steve Zubrick, who has conducted significant research into these issues and who has told me that, with a gun in the home, the risk of suicide is increased by 25 per cent. He says a gun is a `totally unforgiving device—it is designed to do a job and it does it well'.

Mr Deputy Speaker, there will be law‐abiding, good people inconvenienced by tighter gun control, but they are not well served by those who speak of bloodshed, of civil disobedience or of blaming the homosexual community for community attitudes which now demand action for a less violent society. I have had letters and contact from pro‐gun lobbyists in my electorate office, some of those with legitimate inquiries but, in the main, I have had contact from those who reflect the Age poll of 2-5 May 1996 which showed that 90 per cent of those surveyed supported a national ban on all automatic and semi‐automatic fire arms. Eighty‐eight per cent supported firearms registration.
There are those who argue they have a right to own firearms. I remind them of the major contribution to the agreed reforms of our Attorney‐General (Mr Williams). He said:

BREAK.PARA: Gun ownership is not a right. Rather it should be seen as a conditional privilege reserved for those with a genuine reason and subject to appropriate controls.
I would like to conclude by quoting from some letters I have received on this subject. A resident of Prospect, in my electorate, said:
You received our support in March now it is time to give the majority of Australians your support.
From a city dweller:

On the brighter side, think of the very positive signal tighter gun control laws will send to foreign tourists—would you rather take your chances on the streets of New York or LA or visit a country which is actively reducing the number of guns and gun owners?
From another:
I have never felt so proud of an Australian Prime Minister.
Finally, a specialist physician describes gun control as `superb preventative medicine'. I commend the motion to the House.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the motion seconded?
—I second the motion and reserve my right to speak.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Adams, Dick, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —It goes without saying that I support the sentiments of the member for Adelaide (Ms Worth) in the first part of her motion. I thank her for her support of the people of my electorate and of my state. There was a lot of suffering and a lot of grief, but now life must go on. These people are picking themselves up and are coming face to face with a rather bleak tourism outlook unless we can help them further. I hope she will continue to support the state and the state's need for some special assistance because of the trauma that we have experienced.

SPEECH.PARA: I, along with my colleague in the other place, Senator Shayne Murphy, have written to the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) seeking to follow up the promise he made to the state during the election in relation to the $49.5 million worth of Bass Strait subsidy travel. It was to be allocated over three years with the third‐year amount being the greatest—that is, $22.5 million. We are seeking, and meekly asking, that the third‐year amount become the first‐year amount, and that the $19.1 million come forward to try and help kick‐start the tourist numbers for this year and for next year.

The plan includes a passenger and car subsidy and an accommodation rebate for this year. It also takes into account the rebuilding of the cafe-information centre which is so vital to the economy of this site. I hope members of this House will be in a position to try and help Tasmania out of its current difficulty by supporting the idea. It is a chance for all of us to readily express our sympathy practically and to give thanks to those who worked so tirelessly during that time.

I would also add that there is an appeal running around Parliament House with the maple leaf stickers. Twelve federal Tasmanian parliamentarians from across the political spectrum have all put in $100 to pay for another 20,000 stickers to be distributed around Tasmania, Parliament House and the rest of Australia. If all are sold it means that our politicians have helped raise another $40,000 towards this appeal. So I thank all those people who responded so promptly and without any persuasion to assist in this appeal.

The other part of motion moved by the member for Adelaide goes to guns and gun laws and the efforts of all parties to have a consistent view on how to deal with the question of guns and gun ownership. The last government banned military style automatic and semiautomatic weapons from importation through the Customs Act and by using the Customs Service. It also banned ammunition—the bullets that arm those weapons.

But a meeting of the state police ministers in Launceston—at which a proposal to ban their use for private and mail order sales and for tougher licensing and training schemes and storage of weapons—fell apart because of the resistance of some states, and chiefly my own state. The honourable member for Denison (Mr Kerr), my colleague from Tasmania, is here. Of course, in the last government he was the Minister for Justice. He had put that on the agenda and was carrying the motion forward at the ministers conference, which unfortunately did not see fit to pick up on those matters.

BREAK.PARA: It has taken the shock and the terrible tragedy at Port Arthur to put the debate back on the rails. The motion of the member for Adelaide points out that all sides have to be positively involved. I hope that, this time, sense will prevail to make sure that we have the best legislation we can get. I am sure the member for Adelaide supports that. I know she would.

In my electorate there are many law‐abiding citizens who own guns. They will be inconvenienced by the legislation because it has gone far further than it was ever envisaged to go last year or in the years past. But I do not think it is impossible to make it work; I believe that we can make it work.

I was heartened to hear from the New South Wales Shooting Association Ltd that they support the directions of agreed resolutions on gun control announced by the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) on 10 May 1996, and that they have been advocating similar proposals since 1991. Their organisation is the official New South Wales member for the sport in the Olympic Games, the Commonwealth Games and other meets around our country. National meets hold up the structures that bring our shooters together throughout the year to compete and reach the ones who go on to represent us at the Olympic Games and at the Commonwealth Games.

I have been trying today to contact bodies in my own area to see what their views are. I believe that they would not be very different from those of the New South Wales Shooting Association. Where sports requirements or other legitimate reasons for having a particular style gun require changes to the gun laws in some way, I believe we can negotiate our way through it.

I do not think we want to follow the lead of the United States, which has guns as part of its culture of personal defence and aggression. That has never been a part of our culture. We have never had guns tied to ourselves for those reasons.

Guns have a place in such sports as target shooting and hunting and on farms where there are legitimate uses and people are trained from an early age to handle guns with safety and responsibility. When I was a young man growing up on the farm, I was taught the responsibility of using a gun.

It is of great significance, when I look back on it, that my father let us learn to shoot only with a single shot shotgun or a single shot .22. If I went off with five bullets and came back without any bullets and without any rabbits, I was in some difficulty because I had failed the test of being able to shoot straight. His idea was that you should learn to shoot correctly if you have only a single shot shotgun. I think that is probably very true.

I do not think anyone would disagree that legislators have to do something. I am sure that if we all work together we can achieve a much safer and a more informed Australia. I thank the honourable member for permitting me to speak again on the issue. I hope she will visit Tasmania and see for herself what a truly beautiful and peaceful place it is despite the recent events that we have had to endure.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cameron, Eoin, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I commend the member for Adelaide (Ms Worth) for moving this motion. I would like to begin by placing on the record my contempt for those in the gun lobby who are making threats to members of parliament, not just electorally but physically, for the bipartisan stance that has been taken with respect to the gun laws. I am grateful that there has been bipartisanship on this issue. I commend all members of parliament involved, both state and federal, for their contribution to, and hard work in, having reached an agreement to ban automatic and semi‐automatic weapons.

SPEECH.PARA: To those people who have telephoned my office or who have written to me saying that they will vote against me because of my position on the matter, let me tell you this: like most others who have received such threats, I do not give a damn. We do not give a damn. I am prepared to lose votes. I would be prepared to lose the seat of Stirling for supporting measures that make Australia a safer place.

I have a wife, two daughters, a son and a beautiful granddaughter. I am fortunate that my parents are still alive, as are my nine brothers and sisters. Any one of them or any member of their families could have been at Port Arthur on that tragic day. Very sadly, a young woman from my electorate of Stirling was there and lost her life.

We owe it to our constituents, our nation, our family and our friends and, most importantly, to those who died and to those who survived at Port Arthur to take action to ban these weapons, which were invented for one reason only: to kill, and to kill on a large scale. It is fitting that the first part of this motion passes the sympathy of the House on to the family and friends of all the victims of the Port Arthur massacre.

My words are meaningless to them. This motion will mean probably very little to them. But our whole nation does share in the grief that they suffer, and we do offer our profound sympathy and compassion. Our thoughts are with the families and friends of the victims of the Port Arthur massacre.

It is unfortunate that it has taken a tragedy like this to unite our nation in its outlawing of these destructive weapons. Nevertheless, it has taken courage and backbone in getting the measures through and in maintaining our stance in the face of a vocal but minority opposition.

I congratulate the Prime Minister (Mr Howard), the Attorney-General (Mr Williams), all police ministers and all opposition spokespeople who have given their support. I congratulate the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Beazley) on supporting the Prime Minister on every occasion during the debate on this topic.

This motion also recognises, rightly, the outstanding work done by the police and emergency services during the tragedy. I extend that to include all volunteers involved. We all would have read different stories about individuals going to the scene of the tragedy to assist those who had been shot. They were courageous beyond description. I commend them for their services. I particularly congratulate those workers at the Royal Hobart Hospital, who were mentioned by the member for Adelaide. They had a horrendous time during and following the massacre. Their work deserves greater recognition.

BREAK.PARA: All those who were involved are true Australians. I think it would be fitting if those people, as a group, were nominated for the Australian of the Year award. A group has won that award before. I think those who went beyond the normal course of individual commitment, who displayed the true Australian spirit and courage and who united our nation in the face of adversity, would be extremely worthy nominees.

Their courage and actions define the Australian spirit. No one person represents them, but as a group those emergency services people, the volunteers, the hospital staff—all those involved—are great Australians and would be worthy recipients of the Australian of the Year award. I do acknowledge that the decision to ban certain guns will inconvenience many law-abiding citizens, and I offer my apologies. However, the right to live in safety far outweighs the right to bear arms. If this law saves one Australian, it is a law worth having; it will be working. I am confident that it will save many more than just one Australian.

Finally, I have suggested to the Prime Minister that, as an addition to the Medicare levy to fund the gun buyback, the metal parts of the guns handed back be melted down and made into medallions commemorating a safe Australia. This could be coordinated by the Mint and sold to those many Australians who want to invest in making our great nation safer. I call it taking out insurance for making Australia safer. The War Memorial, as all would probably know, sells pens from melted down nuclear warheads. Perhaps we could do the same with the metal parts of those guns. I commend the initiative and the motion to the House.

I conclude by noting that a 29‐year‐old Western Australian man was killed on Friday night at a town called Borden, near Gnowangerup, in the Western Australian wheat belt. He was accidentally shot in the back of the head. The gun involved was one that would be banned under the proposed laws.

For those who do not know, CDEPs are the major employment programs for indigenous Australians. I am surprised that the member for the Northern Territory (Mr Dondas) did not raise this afternoon the fact that they, for example, employ 6,500 people in the Northern Territory in 45 different communities. Any delay in their ongoing operation will have a devastating effect on employment and welfare in these communities.

SPEECH.PARA: The program has been used to assist in overcoming the risks of alcohol abuse and to ensure that structured and beneficial jobs are created. The projects enable essential services, including garbage collection and transport and roadworks, to be carried out and food to be distributed to out‐stations. Yet, under the guise of a so-called appointment of a special auditor to ATSIC, they now suggest that these programs are frozen.

I can only say that, on the very day that Aboriginal Reconciliation Week commences, our indigenous communities are to be singled out for particularly harsh treatment by the current government. The government should give an assurance to the House and take immediate steps to ensure that 1996-97 funding for CDEP programs, which are essential for community development activities, are not held up.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to put very clearly to the honourable member for Lindsay (Miss Jackie Kelly) her absolute ignorance about what an EIS is all about as far as Badgerys Creek is concerned and also to tell this House that I was one of those speakers who was debating at 2BL on Friday night. The honourable member for Hughes (Mrs Vale) did not turn up. I also have an electorate office where calls for the honourable member for Hughes are coming to. She is not available for comment. I feel for her because the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) of this country did not even have the decency to consult her before the announcement was made that they were taking on board another EIS at Holsworthy. What we are really saying on this side of the House is that, if you are going to have EISs, at least consult the constituents at large as well as your members of parliament.
—Order! It being 2 p.m., in accordance with standing order 106A, the time for members' statements has concluded.

—My question is to the Minister for Transport and Regional Development. How many meetings did you attend prior to the election regarding the coalition's secret deal to sell Holsworthy and Badgerys Creek to real estate interests? When were the meetings held? Who else attended those meetings? What was discussed at those meetings and what deals were struck? Was it agreed at those meetings to keep the details of this shabby deal secret until after the election? Did you inform the Liberal Party candidate for Hughes of the deal; if not, why not? Finally, since the election have you or any other ministers held any meetings with the same business interests whom you met prior to the election concerning Holsworthy?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Sharp, John, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The Leader of the Opposition asks a question that can be equally as well answered by members on his own side. We did in opposition precisely what they did in government; in other words, members on this side of the House heard a proposal put by a certain gentleman who had a scheme called the Lawrence Hargrave project. We listened to that gentleman's proposals, as did members on the other side of the House listen to that proposal. For example, the honourable member for Kingsford‐Smith, who was then the Minister for Transport, admits that he also received the same gentleman and heard the same project put to him. It is interesting to note that the former Senator Richardson also heard the same project put by the same gentleman. It is worth noting also that other members of the new South Wales Labor Party heard the same project put by the same gentlemen.

ANSWER.PARA: So when it comes to the question put by the Leader of the Opposition, I say to him that, like people on his side, we heard from this gentleman in a couple of meetings, individually or as a group, just as the opposition did either individually or as a group. I can assure the Leader of the Opposition that just as the opposition did not strike any secret deals neither did we on this side of the House.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Prime Minister. Will the Prime Minister advise the House of his plans for his first overseas trip as Prime Minister?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howard, John, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for Deakin for his question. I am happy to inform the House that arrangements have been made for me to visit Tokyo from 7 to 10 August and Jakarta from 11 to 13 August. This visit represents a further affirmation of the importance that the new government places on relations between this country and the countries of the Asia‐Pacific region. In saying that, I quite freely acknowledge the contribution that was made to the building of good relations between Australia and the nations of the Asia‐Pacific region by a series of Prime Ministers: Prime Ministers Whitlam, Hawke and Keating of the Labor bent and Prime Ministers Menzies, Holt, Gorton, McMahon and Fraser on the coalition side.

ANSWER.PARA: One of the more ridiculous, stupid, infantile comments that was made during the election campaign was the suggestion that the leaders of the Asia‐Pacific region would not deal with a coalition Prime Minister. I think we have demonstrated the contrary very quickly. I want to compliment the work of the Deputy Prime Minister and Minister for Trade, and the Minister for Foreign Affairs, both of whom have made very important visits to the region. By their actions, they have demonstrated the importance that we attach to our relations with the nations of that region. It is a common commitment, I would have thought, on both sides of the House.

It would serve the interests of Australia well if that commitment were more readily acknowledged on the other side of the House. I noticed on the Sunday program yesterday that diplomat extraordinaire, the member for Kingsford‐Smith. Somebody had not given him the more up to date hymn sheet because he was still singing the old hymn, that is, that nobody in Asia likes us. It all seems rather pathetic.

There is a difference. The difference is not the level of commitment between us and the opposition in relation to our links with the countries of the Asia‐Pacific region. Unlike the former government, the new government does not see the associations that this country has with the nations of Europe and North America as being a liability in our dealings with the nations of our region; rather, we see them complementing our dealings with the nations of that region.

Indonesia and Japan are, of course, amongst the most important countries with which Australia has links. It is no accident that Japan's economic relations with Australia are so deep and abiding. It was, after all, a coalition Prime Minister, Menzies, and a coalition Deputy Prime Minister, McEwen, who were responsible in 1957 for the signing of the Australia‐Japan trade agreement. Be it remembered that the signing of that trade agreement was strenuously opposed in 1957 by the Australian Labor Party. They do not like being reminded of it, but it remains the fact. It is just a demonstration of the humbug in their pretending that, in some way, they are the authors, the parents, of the great relationship between Australia and the nations of the region.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, my question is addressed to the Prime Minister. I refer him to reports of confidential meetings before the election—involving, amongst others, himself, the present Minister for Transport and Regional Development, Senator Newman and Senator Parer—regarding the coalition's secret plan to have Holsworthy as the site of the second Sydney airport. Prime Minister, did you discuss delays in the government's legislation on the sale of Sydney airport at these meetings? Did you discuss a process of conjoint environmental studies between the Holsworthy and Badgerys Creek sites? Did you indicate your preparedness to consider their proposals after the election?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howard, John, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, my recollection of these events is as follows—and I thank the honourable gentleman for asking the question. I was rather hoping I would get asked this question. Can I say to the—

ANSWER.PARA: Opposition members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order!

—I know what the subject is. The answer, Mr Speaker, is that in October of 1994, when I was the shadow minister for industrial relations, I remember very clearly seeing a group of people, and I am sure it is the group of people to which the opposition questions are directed. I saw them in an office in Sydney. They put forward this proposal regarding Holsworthy. I listened to it.

ANSWER.PARA: I was then the shadow minister for industrial relations; I was not the Leader of the Opposition. At that particular time my recollection is that Senator Parer, not the new Minister for Transport and Regional Development, was the shadow minister for matters dealing with aviation,

I listened to the group's proposition and, at their request, I passed on the information with a request to the relevant shadow ministers including, because of his transport interest, the new minister. To my recollection, I had no further contact at all with those people.

TALK.START.PARA: —Who are they?

—You know who they are because some of your colleagues were met by them. Mr Speaker, I had one meeting with this group in October of 1994. Let me make it perfectly plain to the House that no promises were made, no deals were made, no Kirribilli pacts were entered into. There were no arrangements, no understandings, no winks, no nods. I gave no promises about environmental impact statements.

ANSWER.PARA: As to a later meeting, I have no recollection of being involved in any other meeting. There may well have been other meetings—and so what? You have this incredible proposition that, if you have a meeting with a group of people, out of that there is an automatic secret deal. If every meeting Laurie Brereton had with a businessman in Sydney could be construed as a secret deal, he would be buried in secret deals.

The truth of the matter is that I have entered into no arrangement, I have nothing at all on this issue to hide—nothing at all. You can spend the rest of question time—come on, Lindsay, I invite you to do it—cross‐examining me about this. I would be delighted. I have nothing to hide. There were no deals made. Everything has been quite transparent. If this is the best you can get it up to at question time, you have a long way to go to become a competent opposition.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, my question is addressed to the Treasurer. Can the Treasurer inform the House of recent developments in advanced economic nations with regard to budget deficits and labour market flexibility? How will the pursuit of such objectives assist the hundreds of thousands of young families and small businesses which were ignored by and which suffered under the dismal failure of the previous Labor government, whose finance minister, now Leader of the Opposition, left in his wake an $8 billion budget black hole?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Costello, Peter, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, I thank the honourable member for McPherson for his question. On 21 and 22 May, on behalf of the Australian delegation, I attended the OECD ministerial council meeting. I record that the subject of discussions on economic policy at that meeting centred on two necessary adjust ments in advanced industrial nations. The first was fiscal consolidation, and the second, structural reform. For example, the Danish statement:

ANSWER.PARA: There is now widespread agreement on the twin main economic policy goals, namely, to reinforce both fiscal consolidation and structural reforms.
The German statement:

There is no alternative to a strict policy of fiscal discipline and consolidation. The possible contractive effect of budget consolidation on the demand side can be overcompensated by the expansive effects of the measures that create confidence and relief on the supply side.
The AC economic secretary to the treasurer said:
On the macro‐economic front, the most pressing need is to get public finances under strict control.

TALK.START.PARA: —What did Dr Stiglitz tell you?
—Well, you can imagine my surprise to wake up on Saturday morning to see in the business section of the Age newspaper a report from Tim Colebatch, noted economic journalist, saying:

ANSWER.PARA: President Clinton's chief economic adviser has given the Federal Treasurer, Mr Costello, a firm warning against cutting Government spending the way he and his colleagues are planning to do it.
The article went on to quote Dr Stiglitz as saying:
"We must also recognise that deficit reduction is not an end in itself, but a means for increasing living standards and growth by raising available savings and fostering investment.
The government agrees completely with that statement.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about the rest of the quote?

—I had a conversation with Dr Stiglitz, in the course of which he gave no such warning at all. In fact, the only complaint that was registered in the course of that conversation was my complaint about the US Helms‐Burton legislation in relation to the extra‐territorial reach of it and its effect on Australian investors in Cuba.

ANSWER.PARA: Mr Colebatch, sitting 17,000 miles away, apparently feels able to report conversations which never occurred and to put his own construction on them. Let me say that report was totally in error. It is as a result of erroneous reporting like that from people like Mr Colebatch that the Age is suffering from its present PR difficulties. If I were you, I would not rely on Mr Tim Colebatch. I do notice the Age is trying to recruit from the Herald‐Sun to improve its standard of journalism, but it will need to do a lot more recruiting, and I would suggest recruiting in the economics area should be its first priority.

Mr Colebatch was entirely wrong. He is one of those journalists who has perfected reporting question time whilst never attending, one of those journalists who has perfected reporting on the OECD from 17,000 miles away from conversations that never occurred. In relation to the OECD, there was complete agreement on fiscal consolidation and structural adjustment. There was only one party in the Western world out of step—the Australian Labor Party. It is out of step even with its comrades in the Socialist International.

In relation to the matters that were discussed, the importance of fiscal consolidation is to make sure that we as a country can ease the burden of debt which was bequeathed by Labor to future Australians. It is important that we give future Australians an opportunity which the Labor Party would have denied them. This party tripled debt over four years and, as a result, put pressure on interest rates. The hope for future Australians is the reduction of debt; the hope for small business and families is the easing of pressure on interest rates in relation to fiscal consolidation and structural adjustment—all of things Labor was incapable of doing, all of the reasons why Labor was thrown out of office.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Transport and Regional Development. Did you or Senator Parer or any other member of the front bench indicate to the people who approached you in regard to the development of the Holsworthy site a preparedness to consider it after the subsequent election?
—Can I assure the Leader of the Opposition—I cannot speak for Senator Parer, but I can speak for myself—that there was no deal—
—That's not what I asked.

—No agreement, no assurance of any type given to any persons in regard to the settlement of a second airport for Sydney. I give that assurance so the Leader of the Opposition clearly understands that there was no deal, no assurance, no agreement other than what was in our election platform, which was that we would build a second airport for Sydney as quickly as possible in order to overturn the 10 years of failure of the previous Labor government. Members of the House should be interested in this view—

—Mr Speaker, I rise on a point of order on relevance. The question was very specific. The question I asked did not mention deals, undertakings or anything else. What I asked specifically was: did he indicate to them a `preparedness to consider' the Holsworthy site after the election?
—The minister is addressing the question.
—I have already answered the question.
—No, you haven't.

—I have already answered your question. Let me assure the House that the only reason why I am here today talking about this problem, why we are listening to this problem being discussed in the parliament in 1996, is the failure of these people opposite to resolve the problem of Sydney's second airport.
—Mr Speaker, I rise on a point of order. The minister said that he had answered the question so it is time that he sat down.
—He has!
—Order! The minister has concluded his answer and resumed his seat.

—My question is addressed to the Treasurer. Has the Treasurer seen reports that the budgets of the Australian states are in aggregate surpluses this year? Is it a fact that state Liberal and National Party governments are making efforts at fiscal consolidation to repair the financial and economic vandalism of previous state Labor governments? Why is this necessary and who is responsible?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Costello, Peter, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for his penetrating question. He has, as a result of studying the position of the various states, found out that the aggregate underlying state and territory budget position in 1995‐96 is in surplus equivalent to 0.4 per cent of GDP. That is across all of the states. All of the state budgets are in surplus. If last year's budget would have been believed, the Commonwealth should have been heading for a headline surplus of $3.4 billion, rather than a deficit of $4.9 billion. We all know who is responsible for the $8 billion deficit. We know that it was the person who, during the election campaign, said he stood by the forecasts of a $3.4 billion surplus when in fact we were $4.9 billion in deficit.
—Your unfunded promises. That's what we've got now.

—You love this, don't you? The mistake was this: what you should have done was come clean. What you tried to do was cover-up. You will live with that forever, covering it up forever. What you should have done was called a press conference. You should have said, `The estimates have changed. The spendings have changed. I couldn't get it through the cabinet.' You could have come clean on it, but you took the coward's way out. You tried to deceive.
—Mr Speaker, I rise on a point of order. The Treasurer is big on the issue of concealment. When is he going to table the Finance costings of his unfunded promises?
—Order! This is not a legitimate point of order.

—We always get the second question before we finish the last. The states have made the strides which the government was unable to do under Labor. The aggregate underlying state and territory budget position in 1995‐96 is a surplus equivalent to 0.4 per cent of GDP. Even in relation to New South Wales, the Carr Labor government claims it will be bringing down a surplus in 1996‐97. If one looks at it, in underlying terms, the general government deficit will be around $357 million.
