ANSWER.PARA: There is one difference between New South Wales Labor and federal Labor. New South Wales Labor at least has the decency to commit itself to surpluses. Not only is federal Labor out of step internationally; it is out of step with its own state branches. Bob Carr can commit himself to a surplus. The Leader of the Opposition, `Deficit Beazley', and the Deputy Leader, `Deficit Evans', cannot even bring themselves to do that.

This Australian Labor Party, having failed Australia so badly, would do well to take note of the position in New South Wales, to commit itself to the necessity for reducing debt and delivering surpluses and to support this government in cleaning up the messes it inherited from Labor.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Transport and Regional Development. In view of the fact that Holsworthy was rejected as the second worst alternative location for Sydney's second airport, have you at any time instructed the department of transport to examine other sites which in the department's judgment had much greater merit than Holsworthy as an alternative to Badgerys Creek? If not, why not?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Sharp, John, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —After we entered government, the question of Badgerys Creek and the coalition's commitment to an environmental impact study for it was raised with me and was the subject of some considerable discussion. The possibility of a negative outcome from an environmental impact study of Badgerys Creek was raised with me. I asked people in my department, and indeed anyone else who had any ideas about a second airport solution for Sydney, what other sites are available if Badgerys Creek gets a negative outcome for its environmental impact study.

ANSWER.PARA: The only sites that were available that had any prospect at all were sites like Richmond. Richmond was regarded as being unsuitable because the runway at Richmond is 2,000 metres in length and you need a runway that is at least 4,000 metres in length. It would also require virtually the removal of one very historic township, a move I think most people would have been unhappy with.

I also point out to the honourable gentleman asking the question that one of the concerns raised was that, if you went outside of Richmond or the site that we finally chose as an alternative or backup site, that is Holsworthy, and wanted to minimise the delays that would be incurred if Badgerys Creek got a negative EIS, the only way you could go about it was to look at alternative sites that were currently 100 per cent owned by the Commonwealth, which limited it to either Holsworthy or Richmond. If you found, as you were gambling on, that Badgerys Creek got a negative EIS, we would have had to go right back to the drawing board and we would have had several years further delay in building a second airport for Sydney.

Sydneysiders are sick and tired of the 10 years of delay, the 10 years of fast talking and slow tracking, on Badgerys Creek. So I said, `If we are going to resolve this problem as quickly as possible, the only way to do it is go to an area that the Commonwealth currently owns 100 per cent of.' To go anywhere else—to go to Goulburn, Wilton or other airport sites that have been mooted around Sydney—would only lead to further delays and further inconvenience for the people who are suffering as a result of aircraft noise in Sydney and would lead to further cynicism about any government's resolve to fix the problem of a second airport in Sydney, which has been on the agenda for 30 years.

TALK.START.PARA: —I address my question to the Minister for Health and Family Services. As this is national Aboriginal reconciliation week, can the minister inform the House about what the government can do to improve the appallingly low state of health amongst Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Wooldridge, Dr Michael, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for his question. Today is the first day of National Reconciliation Week and many honourable members today attended a lunch hosted jointly by the Prime Minister, the Leader of the Opposition and the Leader of the Australian Democrats.

ANSWER.PARA: Part of the reconciliation process is attempting to address the terrible state of the health of Aboriginal Australians. To this end, my department has responsibility for Aboriginal health. I say two things at the outset. The first is that if we are going to be honest it is going to take the best part of a generation to make a very substantial improvement in the health of Aboriginal and Islander Australians. If we look to the example of countries similar to us, such as Canada or New Zealand, which have substantial indigenous populations, we see that this has been their experience. It also gives us some cause for hope because it shows us that improvements can be made.

The second thing I say at the outset is that government must realise that its capacity to do anything is limited because it cannot act unilaterally. In the end, we have to do this with the cooperation of states and territories and of Aboriginal and Islander organisations and people.

My department has four initiatives under way that I hope will collectively take some steps towards this end. The first initiative is that of looking to better coordinate Aboriginal specific programs with mainstream health systems. If there is one thing we could do that would substantially help Aboriginal and Islander people it would be for states and territories to provide, as far as possible, the same level of service to them as they provide to any of their citizens. In the past, the two levels of government have not talked together. This has led to situations where you have one level of government funding capital and another level of government not prepared to fund recurrent services.

I have had a draft agreement go around to all states and I hope to be signing the first one within a month. This will mean that under this agreement two things will happen. The first is that the Commonwealth, states and territories will sit down to jointly plan needs, have a look at where the gaps are and see what we can do to fill in those gaps. Secondly, we will be having the National Aboriginal Community Controlled Health Organisation, NACCHO, and the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission at the table. The four players in the health area will be jointly planning priorities and how to meet them.

We are also looking at new approaches to service delivery. As part of the COAG process there are opportunities for coordinated care trials. A number of trials are well progressed in WA, the Northern Territory and New South Wales. These are very exciting because they have the capacity to turn Aboriginal health completely on its head. For example, we are looking at a trial in the Tiwi Islands in the Northern Territory whereby the Commonwealth, states and the Tiwi Health Council would jointly fund a renal dialysis service for Tiwi people suffering from the highest known level of kidney disease known in the world.

The other one we are looking at is Katherine, where the Commonwealth and the Northern Territory government would look to be cashing out their health dollar and providing it to the local community so that they can meet their own needs. What is quite radical about this is that they would actually be rewarded for keeping people well rather than being rewarded when people are sick. The third thing we are doing is looking to develop particular strategies to combat specific health problems, particularly sexual health. To this end, last week I met with ANCA, the Australian National Council on AIDS. They have a working group on indigenous sexual health under Dr Ian Anderson from Victoria and we are hoping that they can lead the fight against HIV‐AIDS in Aboriginal communities.

Finally, I now have agreement about the make‐up of the national Aboriginal and Islander health council. I have sent out letters of invitation and I hope to be able to make an announcement on this in the near future. It will be chaired by my department and will be reporting directly to me. I hope this direct input will provide the resources and the knowledge that we need to do our part at a Commonwealth level. Collectively, I hope these four initiatives will make a small start on what will be a generational task to improve Aboriginal and Islander health.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Treasurer. At the OECD last week were you out to lunch, jet‐lagged or just not paying attention when Joseph Stiglitz, President Clinton's Chairman of the Council of Economic Advisers, in his speech warned all ministers attending the OECD meeting not only that cutting budget deficits was not an end in itself but a means for increasing living standards and growth—the question you have already addressed—but also that it simply does not make economic sense to cut budget deficits by cutting spending on the very programs that lead to future growth, in particular research and development, labour market training and infrastructure investment? Does the Treasurer propose to take any notice of this warning by one of the world's best known, most influential and highly regarded economists, or does he think he knows better?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Costello, Peter, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —Let me say, as I said before, the statement reported by Mr Colebatch is apparently where the deputy leader gets his economic ideas from. But I would not get them from him for too long, if I were you, because he thinks the Labor Party is a little right wing; he is more into green and socialist left economics. We must recognise that deficit reduction is not an end in itself but a means for increasing living standards and growth. Why do you think we want to reduce the deficit? To increase living standards and promote growth. That is exactly why we are doing it.

ANSWER.PARA: I am in complete and absolute agreement with Dr Stiglitz's comment. It is all about raising available savings, getting the savings to GDP ratio back up and fostering investment. I am absolutely in agreement with Dr Stiglitz. But where Mr Colebatch goes wrong is to suggest that this was a warning given to me.

TALK.START.PARA: —No, no; he doesn't say that.
—He does say that, I'm afraid. Can you not read? He says this:

ANSWER.PARA: President Clinton's chief economic adviser has given the federal Treasurer Mr Costello a firm warning.

TALK.START.PARA: —Now read the next bit.
—That is exactly what he did say. Every now and then you should read before you talk.
—Were you there?
—And, oh, of course I was there.
—Oh!

—Was that your big knockout point—oh! We like to keep you happy in question time, we really do. Of course I was there and I put Australia's position—a position which was endorsed by just about everybody else: the need for fiscal consolidation and structural adjustment. You ask, `Are you going to follow all of Dr Stiglitz's prescriptions for the Australian economy?' Let me tell you: no, because we follow what the Australian people elect us to do in elections. There is no forelock tugging here.

ANSWER.PARA: We do not have to go up to Washington to get our orders. We are perfectly happy as Australian elected representatives to stand here and, in accordance with election mandates, to determine what is necessary in Australia. What is more, because we are not seeking UN offices we do not have to go around the place and kowtow. We do not have to do that. We are not looking for votes to get jobs for us post politics in the UN. We are perfectly capable of looking at the position in the Australian economy and making our own decisions—and we will.

I have got to tell you that this is an Australian government which accounts to the Australian people. That is whom we account to. We make sure that it is the Australian people who make the decisions. This is not an Australian government that has to get its orders through international instruments. We are quite prepared to make the decisions. It just so happens that international opinion accords with us as well, which makes us doubly sure of fiscal consolidation and structural adjustment.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister for Industrial Relations. The minister would be aware that I have an all‐female clothes shop factory, the Can't Tear `Em factory, which makes work wear in my electorate. Is he aware of the broad support for the government's industrial relations package? Also, is he aware of suggestions that the government's industrial relations package should be split into several components? What is his reaction to these matters?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Reith, Peter, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I certainly am aware of the very broad support which has been expressed for the government's industrial relations package and I am not surprised that the honourable member would refer to the circumstances of a business in her electorate. The fact is that in businesses all around Australia we have had the message back in the last few days of very strong support for what we are trying to do. For example, there may well be people in that particular business who would like to be able to exercise the right to either be in a union or, alternatively, not be in a union.
—Order! The minister will resume his seat. The member for Newcastle on a point of order.
—Mr Speaker, I can't disappoint you. You're expecting it.
—You have not disappointed me yet.
—I refer to standing order 82. Following your correspondence, I say that this answer is clearly in breach of that standing order, and I think you would have to agree with that.
—I am listening very carefully to the answer as I was to the question. The minister's view is being canvassed about the impact of particular legislation.
—The bill is currently being debated.
—He is not debating the issues that will be raised in the legislation. There is no point of order.
—Thank you, Mr Speaker, I will be mindful of what you said. The Australian Financial Review states:

ANSWER.PARA: At the very least, by putting the emphasis on workplace agreements, it is a valuable step forward and has the potential to go a long way towards overhauling this country's sadly outdated industrial‐relations system.
Perhaps I will leave aside the quote from the Age , given the earlier remarks about the Age .

TALK.START.PARA: —No, no, no; go on. Read it.
—Okay. Even the Age states:

ANSWER.PARA: The Howard Government's proposals are, by and large, the right ones. Industry needs flexibility in its workplaces—true flexibility that puts more value in our products, makes the nation more productive and provides greater rewards for workers and businesses. The broad thrusts of Mr Reith's changes have the capacity to achieve that goal to a greater extent than anything that has been tried before.
Mr McCrann in the Herald‐Sun states:
. . . after sifting through the rhetoric, the changes—when and if implemented—should produce a win‐win outcome.
The last sentence in an editorial in the Australian states:
In terms of the nation's economic needs, the Coalition's industrial relations legislation represents a significant and sensible move in the right direction.
The one which I particularly liked, and which I know the Prime Minister will like, was this remark in the Courier‐Mail :
The package outlined by Industrial Relations Minister Peter Reith yesterday afternoon contained no surprises.
I like that because the article goes on to explain:
It was entirely consistent with the policies outlined in Opposition . . .

That is another significant element of what we are doing—keeping faith with what we said we would do. Those remarks have been echoed by a series of other interested commentators and those involved including, obviously, employer organisations. Even one branch of one of Australia's super unions, the Australian Liquor, Hospitality and Miscellaneous Workers Union—

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, I raise a point of order. The questioner referred to a particular business and particular employees. You in your comments referred to the `impact'. The minister is speaking constantly about proposals, about legislation, about the act itself. You speak of the impact of the proposal as opposed to the legislation. He is clearly talking about the proposals which he spoke on last week and which are currently in debate. Mr Speaker, the point you made in your letter to me was very clear. I suggest that you give it to the minister to read. When he drafts dorothy dixers in future he can modify them, because this answer is now out of order.
—The minister has ranged broadly over the topic and I am sure he is now about to address the finer points of the question.

—I am, Mr Speaker. The last point I make, without dealing with the substantive matters, is that there have been suggestions that we ought to deal with some of these policy issues on a one‐by‐one basis. I simply say in response that that carries the assumption that there are some policy issues which are more important than others. For example, some would say that the unfair dismissal law, important as it is, ought to be the most important aspect of policy issues being addressed by the government. Well, that is not the government's view. For example, we consider the freedom of association changes—the right to be in a union or not—to be of equal importance. In some cases, for a lot of individual employees or employers, those changes are even more important. On that basis, we believe that Australia's industrial relations system ought to be addressed as a whole. We need a package of reforms to deal with the issues which are confronting so many individual businesses.

—My question is addressed to the Prime Minister. Do you recall stating the day parliament opened that you wanted to reaffirm `the importance of reasserting the supremacy of the parliament over the executive'. Did you also say that `it is part of our system of government that the executive is controlled by parliament'? How are these statements consistent with your endeavours now to bypass the parliament by exploring a backroom exercise to effectively sell off Telstra without legislative approval?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howard, John, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —Where has Holsworthy gone, eh? Where is Holsworthy? Where is it? Where has it gone?

ANSWER.PARA: Honourable members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Members on my right.
—I warmly thank the Leader of the Opposition—

ANSWER.PARA: Opposition member interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Your bloke asked the question. Do you want me to answer your bloke's question, or do you want to ask another one? I thank the Leader of the Opposition for asking me a question about Telstra. Let me say a few things to the parliament about Telstra, about the relationship between the executive and the parliament.

ANSWER.PARA: At the last election, the coalition was elected overwhelmingly with a mandate to do a number of things, one of which was to sell one-third of Telstra. After the election, somebody made a suggestion to me and to one of my colleagues that maybe it would be possible to achieve the policy by means of forming a new company and transferring the assets. I quite happily tell the House that, when that suggestion was put to me, I had the suggestion sent to the Attorney‐General's Department for advice. I am quite happy to tell the House the thrust of that advice.

The thrust of that advice was that—as best I can, I am summarising—it could possibly be done, but it would be very technical, very complicated, and could involve some difficulties. I, at no stage, have had any preference for going down a path other than the path that we are now going down. It is a very curious notion of politics and it is a very curious notion that an executive, having the authority of the house of parliament which creates the government in the first place, is in some way under a constraint in implementing a policy it was elected on by any lawful means available to it. I say to all of you that I will, with great enthusiasm and great gusto, do everything I can to lawfully implement the policies on which I was elected. I make no apology for that.

The preferable course of action is the course of action that the parliament has been invited to go down, and which this House has already gone down. I hope that the Senate will pass the legislation dealing with a one-third sale of Telstra. That would be the neatest, tidiest and best way of doing it. I think the other way is very complicated. It was examined. I make no secret of it. Why shouldn't it be examined? Is there some law against examining ways of keeping your election promises? What are you mob getting up to? You are carrying on as though it is some crime to keep an election promise. We were elected on a commitment to sell one-third of Telstra. We are trying to do that.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Mr Brereton having entered the chamber—

TALK.START.PARA: —The diplomat extraordinaire is back! The sequence of events is simple. We went to the last election and the coalition said, `We'll sell one-third of Telstra.' The Labor Party said, `Don't sell one-third of Telstra.' I had almost forgotten this, but over the weekend some very energetic person in my office turned up a speech that was made to the National Press Club. It was called `Paying for our future: the changing role of public investment'. It was made on 24 August 1994 by the then Minister for Finance, the now Leader of the Opposition.
—It was a great speech.
—Yes, Kim, it was actually. You have slipped a lot since. I will quote generously but carefully. He said:

PARA.EMPHASIS: Privatisation fits in with the Government's—
broader economic imperative to create jobs.
Privatisation is not pursued because of a New Right ideology . . .
This is really very relevant to Telstra. He continues:
Privatisation, for instance, can strengthen the performance of enterprises by allowing private capital injections, as happened with the sale of the Commonwealth Bank . . .

That was before you flogged off the lot, with our assistance. You talk about a secret deal to flog something off. What about the deceit of the Australian public when you make the member for Gellibrand go to the Australian public with a written guarantee that you would not sell down the other 51 per cent of the Commonwealth Bank? You have the gall to talk to me about the deceit of the Australian public. If the corporate laws of Australia applied to you, you would have been in the slammer as a result of saying that. That was a disgraceful piece of deception. This is even better. He finished by saying:
The Government's commitment to the deficit reduction strategy—

TALK.START.PARA: —Keep reading.
—You liked them then, did you? You used to be in favour of deficit reductions.
—I rise on a point of order, Mr Speaker.
—I hope this is a real point of order.
—I have a point of order on relevance. If it is relevant for the Prime Minister to mention that in answer to the question, perhaps he could explain the $25 billion deficit he left us.
—There is no point of order. I am allowing the Leader of the Opposition a fair amount of latitude. Don't test it.
—We don't like this, do we?
—I rise on a point of order, Mr Speaker.
—The member for Newcastle is not disappointing me, but testing me.

—It has become a habit in these three sitting weeks of ministers, when points of order are taken, not sitting down. It has happened almost every question time on more than one occasion. I would urge you to uphold the standing orders.
—I thank the member for Newcastle for his point of order. I remind all members of the conventions of the House.
—The speech went on to say:

PARA.EMPHASIS: The Government's commitment to the deficit reduction strategy means that a halt to privatisation would result in a direct cut to government programs.

If you stop the privatisation of Telstra, you will be directly cutting $1 billion of money going into your own argument. Your own argument will have been played out. There is a very simple proposition involved here. We were elected with the authority of the Australian people to sell one-third of Telstra. That mob opposite is doing everything possible to stop us keeping that promise. I give the Australian people an assurance that we will do everything possible in a totally lawful, legitimate and orthodox fashion to keep our promises and to meet our commitments.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy. In light of the fact that the electorate of Kennedy is $30 million a year poorer as a result of the papaya fruit fly, is the minister aware of concerns that the use of consultants to the primary industries and energy ministry in recent years may not have given taxpayers value for money?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Anderson, John, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for his question. I recognise that his farmers are experiencing a very rough time and they would be absolutely committed to seeing that we did not waste money in this place. There is a question as to whether taxpayers got value for money from the consultancies engaged under the previous government. I want to draw the House's attention to one of these in particular and let people contemplate what might have gone on.

ANSWER.PARA: As it happens, during the course of the last government the former Minister for Resources, Mr Beddall, under the watchful eye of Senator Collins, was casting his eye around for a good consultant on resources—someone who knew something about fishing, energy, minerals or forestry, where he plainly needed some very good political, as well as policy, advice. He found one. His name was Mr Brian Courtice. At that time he had been a recent consultant to another minister, Alan Griffiths. Griffo had been the Minister for Resources, but that did not matter; he was wanted in a new role as a consultant in the area of resources. As a consultant to Alan Griffiths he was on an annual salary of $73,300. Over an eight‐month period he managed to rack up travel of $16,000 and airfares of $23,000—a total of $91,000 for eight months work. I have not seen any of the work; I assume it is there.

Before that, Mr Speaker, it was the case that Mr Courtice had been the member for Hinkler in Queensland. Following that, he became a key consultant to Minister Beddall. Curiously, the consultant's office was based in Bundaberg—that is, 300 kilometres from the minister's office and also, curiously, in the seat of Hinkler. It is rather interesting, too, that many of the key resource issues needing this level of expertise were to be found in community functions in and around the electorate of Hinkler. And so it goes on.

This wisdom does not come cheaply, either. His salary by that time was well over $74,000 per annum. He managed to rack up another $20,000 in travel and another $32,000 in airfares. He had a personal car in Bundaberg for his own use which was worth $9,200. There was a total for his second period as a consultant to the then Minister for Resources of $161,000—a total bill of $231,500.

A couple of questions have to be asked. Where are the reports? Where is the $230,000 worth of value in advice? Where are the great gains to our resources sector? Perhaps they are in the forestry area. If they are not there, perhaps the explanation lies in the fact that Mr Courtice ran as a candidate for the seat of Hinkler at the last election. And for all of that taxpayers' money, here is the interesting point: he not only failed to regain his seat but—do you know what actually happened?—the sitting member increased his lead from 300 to 16,000 votes. I would like to finish by making this observation: we will not be re‐employing Mr Courtice as a consultant.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Ferguson, Laurie, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, my question is directed to the Minister for Administrative Services. Speaking of consultancies, on the 15 May Today Tonight program, former Greiner government adviser Gary Sturgess made the following comments about Jeff Kennett's family share purchases from Guangdong Corporation Ltd:

QUESTION.PARA: They are inevitably matters of public concern. The appearance is that they are using their public office, using their public rank, in order to gain some kind of public advantage.

What is the different between Jeff Kennett's actions and your own commissioning of Gary Sturgess, as principal of Sturgess Australia, to conduct work on privatisation and the contracting out of DAS services, given his dual role since 1993 as a director of SERCo, a major contractor of DAS services? How does the minister defend this appointment?

TALK.START.PARA: —When we employed Mr Sturgess to undertake those studies of DAS, he gave us a guarantee that if there was any conflict of interest in anything he looked at he would stand aside from it—
—He is not a member of parliament.
—The Prime Minister reminds me that he is not a member of parliament—and to my knowledge he always has.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Veterans' Affairs. Does the government condone the use of memorials and shrines of remembrance as protest venues? Is the government concerned about comments attributed in the media to a representative of those opposed to the proposed national gun laws that people who make use of RSL clubs and their facilities are `bludgers'?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Scott, Bruce, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the member for Longman for his question. Of course, probably part of his interest in this question would be because, like many members of this House, he has had a long and distinguished career in the services.

ANSWER.PARA: Mr Speaker, the government does not condone the use of memorials or shrines of remembrance as venues for protests without the permission of the proper authority. Like many Australians, I was concerned that the shrine in Brisbane was used for a protest during the weekend. Quite clearly, those people protesting there sought to link their message with the very powerful message that is conveyed by our shrines and memorials across this country. The RSL has initiated an investigation into that protest on the weekend, and we certainly support those inquiries.

BREAK.PARA: Mr McNiven, who appears to be the self‐styled leader of the gun lobby, also attacked the RSL, and I quote to the House his allegation in the media:
Some branches of the RSL are a hide‐out for bludgers and left‐wing extremists who aid and abet the disarmament of their nation.
Honourable members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, I would not have thought that would have brought mirth from the other side of the House.
—They are laughing behind you. Look.
—Look at the Leader of the Opposition here.
—Order! This is a very serious topic. I think we should all learn something and listen to the answer.

—The RSL has a long history and a very special status in this country. It plays a very important role in ensuring that we continue to remember those who made great sacrifices to ensure that this nation is indeed a free nation. We condemn those comments of Mr McNiven. He should apologise to the RSL, because they are not comments that I believe are supported by legitimate owners and those who seek to legitimately own rifles in this country.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training. I call the minister's attention to the review of the new schools policy by Professor Ken McKinnon which was commissioned by the former government. I remind him of the coalition's pre‐election demands for its early release. I ask the minister why, despite advice from his department that the final report be printed and circulated to key interest groups, he has still not released it after having it for almost three months? Is it because Professor McKinnon's report, while supporting a number of changes to the policy, specifically rejects as false the sorts of arguments advanced by the minister in the House last week for its complete abolition?

—The previous government appointed the McKinnon inquiry to investigate the new schools policy. We received that report on coming into office. The report is not in line with the policies that the government took to the election campaign; it was a report based on completely different assumptions. That report has now been made available to those who request it. It is not relevant to the existing policy of the government, but if the shadow minister for education would like to have a copy of the report I would be very pleased to forward one to him—and to anyone else who asks.
—I seek leave to have the report tabled in the parliament.
—My question is addressed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs. What is the government's response to reports of a crackdown on Aung San Suu Kyi's opposition in Burma?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Downer, Alexander, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for Menzies for his question. I recognise the concern of the member for Menzies—and, indeed, other members of the House—about the current situation in Burma. I am sure that I reflect the views of the whole House in saying the government is deeply concerned about events that have taken place recently in Burma and, in particular, the detention of what we believe now to be in the vicinity of 260 members of the National League for Democracy, the political movement which is led by Aung San Suu Kyi.

ANSWER.PARA: These arrests represent a significant backward step in Burma, and the Australian embassy in Rangoon has conveyed the Australian government's deep concerns to the Burmese government. Our embassy in Rangoon will be monitoring the situation closely, but I note that the National League for Democracy's party conference is continuing, despite the detention of some 260 of its members, most of whom, by the way, were elected democratically by the people of Burma some years ago.

BREAK.PARA: This sort of violence and the arbitrary arrest of individuals is no solution to the problems of Burma, and it will only lead to continuing instability in that country. The only way forward for Burma is through negotiation, consultation and discussion, and until that takes place the country will simply suffer from uncertainty.

Let me say also on the topic of Burma that I know all Australians were delighted that Aung San Suu Kyi received an Order of Australia, which was announced recently by the Governor‐General. That was in recognition of the work an enormously courageous woman has put into the processes of democracy in Burma. Despite all that has been thrown at her and despite having been detained for a very long period, she has continued to stick by her principles. I probably speak on behalf of 18 million Australians in saying that we are right behind her and the courage she has shown in her pursuit of democracy.
In conclusion, I noted at the end of last week an editorial in the Sydney Morning Herald—normally a highly reputable and accurate newspaper, or sometimes it is anyway—

TALK.START.PARA: —What? Peter Reith thinks so.

—Yes, today. That editorial was mistaken in characterising the Australian government's policy on Burma as `a policy of constructive engagement', which is, of course, the policy of the ASEAN countries. I know the member for Holt will have a real sense of this, because he was the author of the current Australian government policy on Burma. This government is continuing with this policy because we see it at this stage being the most appropriate way forward.

BREAK.PARA: It has to be said that the so‐called benchmark policy is a policy which ensures that there is no bilateral development assistance given directly to the Burmese government. The only development assistance we give is through non‐government organisations. As far as trade is concerned, the Australian government does not go out and promote trade with Burma; we have an official policy of neither encouraging nor discouraging trade.

The fact is that, as far as Burma is concerned, we look for outcomes and policy approaches which will encourage the process of democracy and which will encourage Aung San Suu Kyi. This will, we hope, lead to a greater process of liberalisation by the SLORC. The policy of constructive engagement by the ASEAN countries has not led to that, nor I suppose you could argue has our benchmark policy. Nevertheless, we will continue to stand up for appropriate human rights in Burma. We will continue to support the processes of democracy. We will support Aung San Suu Kyi because she has the backing of the overwhelming majority of the people of Burma.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to the Minister for Finance. I refer the minister to reports of meetings with business leaders concerning savings measures in the forthcoming budget. At those meetings, did any of the business leaders raise the issue of a GST? Did you or any of your ministerial colleagues plead with business leaders not to raise debate about a GST because this might force the government to rule it out? Is a GST on the table or not? If not, did the Minister for Industrial Relations tell you about his plans for a GST?

—I thank the honourable member for his question. I can indicate that the only business group I have had a meeting with and which raised the subject of a GST was the ACCI. The meeting involved discussion on a number of matters. When the question came up, it was made abundantly clear to that particular group that they were perfectly free to do what they wished, but as far as taxes are concerned this government has made it abundantly clear that there will be no new taxes. I stand by that, as do all members of this government.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs. Will the government restrict the entry of boat people into Australia? I understand that in recent weeks a number of boat people have arrived on Christmas Island and have subsequently been moved to Port Hedland. What is the status of these boat people, and where are they now?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ruddock, Philip, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for his question. Between 5 May and 10 May there were four unauthorised boat arrivals on Christmas Island. They carried a total of 244 people. I am pleased to advise the House that yesterday morning, 26 May, the last of those arrivals were returned to China. I can also advise the House that over the past two weeks a further 113 people have been repatriated to China under the memorandum of understanding signed with China last year. In total, 357 boat people have been returned to China in the last couple of weeks.

ANSWER.PARA: I want to assure the House that the government does take seriously its international humanitarian obligations. Our policy is that people who engage our protection obligations will be entitled to have their claims heard. But the fact is that none of the recent returnees engaged those obligations and, as required under the Migration Act, were removed as soon as possible.

The returns are a clear illustration of the government's determination to ensure that the integrity of our borders is not compromised by those attempting illegal immigration to Australia. I would like to recognise the cooperation of the government of the People's Republic of China in the return of these people to their homes. Regional cooperation on these matters is essential if we are going to be able to maintain in place an orderly migration arrangement.

The unauthorised arrival of boat people in Australia is not a new phenomenon. It is possible that there will be further arrivals. Indeed, yesterday another 40 people arrived by boat on Christmas Island. Like the other recent arrivals, they will be taken to Port Hedland and processed in the normal way and in accordance with our act and international obligations.

PARA.BREAK: I want to make it clear to the House that, if people have no authority to come to Australia and do not engage our protection obligations, they are not welcome and will not be allowed to remain. That is a clear and decisive mes sage for those who attempt to enter Australia illegally.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Treasurer. How can the government justify holding its proposed inquiry into the banking and financial system behind closed doors, without submissions being public and without there being a public hearing process? Why are you going around saying that a public inquiry would necessarily involve hordes of lawyers and an undue delay, when you know perfectly well that public inquiries held, for example, by the Industry Commission, by the old Prices Surveillance Authority, by parliamentary committees, to name just a few, do not usually involve such trappings and are also perfectly easily able to cope with questions of confidentiality that might arise from time to time? Why, with huge issues at stake for consumers, for bank customers, for bank workers, for building societies, for credit unions and for regional banks, given all that, should the banks and other big corporate players be able to make their submissions in private, free from public scrutiny?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Costello, Peter, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —It was a long speech based on a false premise. I have made it entirely clear that I think the submissions that are put should be made public. I feel that the committee will agree with that. It is certainly the instruction that I will be giving to them. In relation to people who are asked to come in and give further material, I think it would be quite advantageous if that were done publicly as well.

ANSWER.PARA: What I have said I do not feel is necessary is for all interested groups to have the right to come in and cross-examine any person who does come in to supplement a submission. That is the only position I have made. There is a very basic reason for that—apart from bogging down into legal complexities as to what questions are permitted and which are not permitted and which people do have standing and which do not—that is, we want it to finish by March of next year.

TALK.START.PARA: —March of next year?

—Yes, March of next year. Have you got that? It is about nine months away. The reason we want it to finish by March of next year is so that any recommendations that it makes can be considered by the government with the chance of getting them into legislative form in this term.

ANSWER.PARA: You would be aware that the previous inquiry ran over several parliaments. I think it is important that these inquiries and the recommendations that come out of them can be dealt with within the one parliament. That is the way in which we want to do it. They are the reasons we are setting it up in the way that I have indicated.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Health and Family Services. Is the minister aware that private health insurance fund membership for the March 1996 quarter has dropped to just 33.9 per cent of all Australians? What can the government do to respond to the continuing decline in fund membership?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Wooldridge, Dr Michael, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I am grateful to the honourable member for his question. I am aware of the figure he talks about; it was released on Friday. Coverage of private health insurance is now at 33.9 per cent of the Australian population. I agree with the former health minister Graham Richardson that when health insurance drops below 40 per cent we have a problem, because it puts extra pressure on the public hospital system.

ANSWER.PARA: My department estimated last year that a two per cent drop in private health insurance puts the pressure of another 322,000 public hospital bed days onto the public system, or leaves roughly two big city hospitals brimful for 365 days a year. If you want to do something about private health insurance, you have to look at the reasons why people are dropping out.

PARA.BREAK: The first of these reasons is price. Roughly two-thirds drop out because of price. That is why we are bringing in incentives for people to take out private health insurance, and that is why they are pitched at the group which are dropping out most heavily, that is, fami lies with kids—presumably parents who are in their late 30s, early 40s.

ANSWER.PARA: The second reason for dissatisfaction relates to the gap. Thirteen per cent of people drop out because of that. In spite of legislation passed over a year ago now, there is no health fund in Australia offering a comprehensive policy, because, basically, the doctors would not trust the former government.

We hope to make amendments to that legislation so that it will be workable. We are not in any way opposed to the notion of doctors signing contracts with health funds or with hospitals but, if we can get people to sign up, if there can be a bit of goodwill, the public will benefit.

We are also putting to the medical profession that it is up to them to try to address the issues that drive people mad, such as numerous bills. A year ago my son was admitted to hospital for two days in intensive care. I received 35 bills for that two‐day admission, and many people are annoyed with similar things. It is up to the medical profession to address that. I certainly challenge them to do it. Our main reason for supporting people having a choice to take out private health insurance is quite simple. Our commitment to private health insurance underpins our commitment to Medicare: one will not work adequately without the other.

I would like to supplement an answer to a previous question while I am on my feet. I talked previously about Aboriginal health and I thought on the day it was not worth being partisan about it but I cannot let pass a comment from the previous minister for health that the four initiatives that I announced were in some way a ringing endorsement of Labor's policy.

Let me tell you what Labor's policy on Aboriginal health did. Many would say that the only two countries in the world with indigenous people where health has gone backwards in recent years are the former Soviet Union and Australia. The member for Fremantle is babbling away now that they are your policies. I will go through them one by one. The first is better coordination with states. You could never talk to them. We started from nothing. This has not been conceived before. You could never do it even if you wanted to. The reason it has taken us so long to get it off the ground is you had nothing. We started with a clean slate.
The second initiative is the coordinated care trials. Those trials totally stalled because the medical profession withdrew its support.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, I rise on a point of order. This is a disgraceful abuse of question time.
—Order! The minister is amplifying a former answer to a question and is totally in order.
—I can recall them saying the same thing.
—Resume your seat.
—I have not got to my point of order.
—There was so much waving of arms and hands up there I thought you had well delivered.

—You should have been watching them, Mr Speaker. My point of order is: the minister has been asked a question and he has finished his answer to the question. In the terms of allegedly adding to a previous answer, he has started to launch an attack on the previous minister. If that is not out of order, I do not know what is.
—The point of order is out of order. The minister is amplifying a former answer to a question.
—Which he is perfectly entitled to do.

—Mr Speaker, a point of order: there is unquestionably a right to add to an answer but that right is exercised exclusively in the circumstances when you may have inadvertently misled the parliament by what you have proposed in your previous answer or that there was a piece of information which could have added to the answer usefully. It has never been used to go into a debating attack on another member of the House—that is, utilising question time for debating purposes as opposed to simply amplifying what information was at hand beforehand. This is a completely unprecedented use of adding to an answer.
—I thank the Leader of the Opposition for his further point of order. The minister needs to address specifically where he is amplifying his answer. I urge him to do so with some precision.
—Thank you, Mr Speaker, I am trying to be very precise in amplifying my previous answer.
—Mr Speaker, I raise a point of order. I would like to clarify the ruling you have just made.
—No, no; that is not a point of order.
—I am encouraging the minister to respond very cautiously in his amplification.
—My point of order is: I understand the convention of the House is that ministers add to answers at the end of question time rather than in the middle of answers.
—I think you will find that it is.
—Could you rule as to whether this is an appropriate time for the minister to add to or amplify his answer?
—It is a well‐established precedent but I think you will find that we are very close to the end of ministerial question time. The minister is in order.

—The third initiative I raised previously looked at particular strategies to combat particular problems. The fact is in 13 years you were never able to get any national strategy to combat HIV in Aboriginal populations. Professor Richard Feachem, who did the second review of the national AIDS strategy, said as much.

ANSWER.PARA: Finally, the Aboriginal and Islander Health Council is new. You had the council for Aboriginal health. It did not meet for three years. The only things you did for Aboriginal health were press releases, overblown rhetoric and hopes that were never met.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper .

—I raise a question concerning plagiarism in the House. Last Thursday, which was our last sitting day, the member for Cowan gave a 20-minute speech on the supply bills. This speech, word for word, sentence for sentence, paragraph for paragraph, was lifted from this article entitled `The age of social transformation' by Peter F. Drucker.
—It is pronounced `Droocker'.

—I have to say the member for Lalor assures me it is Drucker. Given a challenge between the plagiarisers and the member for Lalor, I know whom I am going to take here. It is Peter F. Drucker. It was published in the Atlantic Monthly in November 1994. I have highlighted in green in the Hansard the plagiarised pieces of the speech to help you.
—That gives a new meaning to a Hansard `green'.
—Order! That was one of the member for Hotham's best interjections thus far. Do not overstep the mark.

—You can gather from this there is not a lot of original Liberal Party thought in the speech. I would ask you to advise the House, firstly, whether plagiarism is an acceptable practice in this House, especially following the Prime Minister's call supported by yourself, Mr Speaker, for improvements in parliamentary standards. Secondly, will you recommend a standing order dealing with this practice? Thirdly, how will you deal with the breach of copyright and intellectual property rights by the member for Cowan? Does parliamentary privilege extend to civil legal action dealing with breach of copyright? Finally, given the Hansard 's wide distribution throughout the nation and the broadcasting of the House's proceedings last Thursday, does the House now owe Peter Drucker royalty payments? If so, how will these be paid?
—How do we know Drucker is not plagiarising the member for Cowan?
—I knew you would run out of ideas, but this is ridiculous.
—We are not debating the issue.
—The Treasurer asked, `How do we know that Drucker is not plagiarising the member for Cowan?' Drucker made his speech in November 1994. The member for Cowan made his last Thursday.
—I warn the member for Werriwa. We are not going to debate the issue.
—Mr Speaker, some of those opposite are asking the source of this speech, so to assist you in your deliberations I would ask for leave of the House to table the article by Peter Drucker.

—The member for Werriwa has raised a series of very complex questions. I am not aware of any standing order relating to plagiarism but, as one who studied Peter Drucker very substantially in my earlier periods, many of his words are indelibly etched on my mind. Whilst I recognise the level of green in the Hansard , I will take your range of questions on notice and will reply either to the House in total or to you privately when I assess the situation.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —For the information of honourable members, I present a statement of the use of the Advance to the Speaker of the House of Representatives, May 1996. I wish to advise the House that on this occasion the Advance to the Speaker was used to reimburse me for actual out-of-pocket medical expenses associated with treatment of an illness that developed in 1993 whilst I was overseas on official duties. At the time, I was the member of an Australian parliamentary delegation that travelled to Somalia at the invitation of the then Minister for Defence.

INTERJECT.PARA: After my claim for medical expenses was rejected by Medicare on the basis that my employer was responsible for meeting the cost of work related illness, I contacted Comcare, seeking reimbursement. However, Comcare advised that it had no authority to pay the claim and passed it on to the House of Representatives. After considerable toing‐and‐froing, the matter was finally referred to the Attorney-General's Department, which advised that under the circumstances an act of grace payment could be made under section 34A of the Audit Act. In January of this year, the former Minister for Finance approved an act of grace payment. In February, the former Speaker authorised the use of the advance to reimburse me for the costs I had incurred. The whole process took some three years to finalise.

I want to make it quite clear that my decision to provide the House with this explanation does in no way compromise the privacy of other members who from time to time may find themselves in a similar situation. However, I do want to emphasise the fact that, unlike other public servants, members of parliament are not always covered for cost of treatment of medical conditions that may arise as a result of their official duties. I believe this is both unreasonable and unacceptable and is a matter that should be immediately addressed by the appropriate authorities.

TALK.START.PARA: —Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows and copies will be referred to the appropriate ministers:

PETITION.PRESENTERS: Cobb, Michael, MP; Latham, Mark, MP; McLeay, Leo, MP; Melham, Daryl, MP; Thomson, Andrew, MP
PETITION.TITLE: Betaferon
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament:
The petition of certain citizens of Australia draws the attention of the House to the fact that:
for the first time there is a drug brand name, Betaferon, which has proven to assist many people with Multiple Sclerosis.
Your petitioners therefore ask the House to have Betaferon subsidised under the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme (PBS).
Without this listing the drug would cost $1500 per month which is clearly unaffordable.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Cobb (from 130 citizens), Mr Latham (from 60 citizens), Mr Leo McLeay (from 110 citizens), Mr Melham (from 15 citizens)and Mr Andrew Thomson (from 16 citizens)

PETITION.PRESENTERS: Gambaro, Teresa, MP; Sullivan, Kathryn, MP
PETITION.TITLE: Marriage
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled:
The petition of the undersigned shows that:

We believe that the traditional Christian view of the family unit excludes anything other than a male and female, living in a lawful marriage relationship, along with their children, and that it is necessary for this to be restated by our political leaders.
We reaffirm our belief in the traditional Christian view of marriage as God's holy institution in which male and female become one flesh. (Genesis 2.24; Matthew 19.5,6)

We reaffirm that God is the author of marriage, and has restricted it to the union of male with female and that such marriage between male and female is commended in Scripture as honourable among all. (Ephesians 5.15‐23)
We reaffirm that such marriage between male and female is ordained for life‐long companionship, help and comfort which husband and wife ought to have of each other. (Romans 7.2,3)

We reaffirm that children are a heritage of the Lord and should be nurtured in a godly home, and that human society can be strong and happy only where the marriage bond is held in honour. (Psalm 127.3)

We reaffirm that incestuous marriages can never be made lawful by the law of any man or government, or the consent of parties, so as to allow those people to live together as married couples. (Mark 6.18; Leviticus 18.6‐28)

We reaffirm that, according to Biblical law, it is forbidden for a male to practise sexual intercourse with another male, or for a female with a female, and that since this is an abomination before the Lord, such as a prohibited relationship for marriage. (Leviticus 18.22; 20.13)
We believe the entire stability and well being of our society depends on maintaining this traditional Christian view of marriage and family (Leviticus 20.15‐16; 18.23‐24)
Your Petitioners ask that the House of Representatives should call on the Government to:
(a) Preserve completely intact the exclusiveness of marriage as being one male and one female.
(b) That the definition of a prohibited relationship in the Marriage Act 1961, Part III 23(2) be amended with the addition of a new clause (c) so that it reads as follows:
(2) Marriages of parties within a prohibited relationship are marriages—
(a) between a person and an ancestor or descendant of the person; or
(b) between a brother and a sister (whether of the whole blood or the half blood); or
(c) between a male and a male or between a female and a female.
Your Petitioners humbly pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Ms Gambaro (from 120 citizens)and Mrs Sullivan (from 17 citizens)

PETITION.TITLE: Overhead Cabling
PETITION.PARA: To the honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives assembled in parliament:

The petition of certain citizens of Australia draws to the attention of the House the proliferation of mobile base stations and the introduction of overhead cabling which are causing environmental, aesthetic and possible health damage to the people in the area.

Your petitioners therefore pray that the House amend the Telecommunications Act to provide a consent role for local government so that the telecommunications carriers will not be free to behave irresponsibly and will be required to conform to local development regulations.

PETITION.TITLE: Croatia
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
The Petition of certain Australian citizens draws to the attention of the House the need to establish an Australian Embassy in the Republic of Croatia:

PARA.TAB: because of the many difficulties experienced by Australian citizens accessing limited consular services when travelling through Croatia;
because of the limited consular services in Croatia, requiring Australian citizens to visit the Australian Embassy in Austria, incurring travelling and other costs; and
to establish and maintain economic and political ties, for the mutual benefit of Australia and the Republic of Croatia.

PETITION.PARA: Your Petitioners respectfully request that the House should:

PARA.TAB: take appropriate and immediate action to establish an Australian Embassy in the Republic of Croatia.

PETITION.TITLE: `How to Vote' Cards
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
The Petition of the undersigned shows:

That the printing and distribution of `How to Vote' Cards on Polling Day in State and Common wealth Elections is extremely wasteful as the distribution of approximately 40 million pieces of paper during the last Federal Election indicates.
Your Petitioners request that the House of Representatives should:
Enact legislation to stop the use of `How to Vote' Cards at Commonwealth elections and that it should prevail on all State Governments in Australia to pass similar legislation for State elections.

PETITION.TITLE: Communications Superhighway
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in parliament assembled.

The petition from the undersigned citizens of Australia draws the attention of the House to the grave concerns we hold regarding the dangers inherent in the communications Superhighway, with its potential to corrupt and deprave our present and future society if material containing depictions of indecent or obscene material is not proscribed.
Your petitioners therefore request that in regard to Computer Bulletin Boards the House will frame legislation to ensure that the system cannot be used to:
(1) (a) transmit or
(b) advertise as available for transmission or
(c) possess objectionable material regardless of intended use.
(2) the definition of `to transmit' includes `to obtain' or `to acquire'.
We further request that the legislation ensure that `objectionable material' means material which in any way:
(3) (a) depicts indecent or obscene material

(b) describes, depicts, expresses or otherwise deals with matters of sex, drug misuse or addiction, crime, cruelty, violence or revolting or abhorrent phenomena in a manner likely to cause offence to a reasonable adult person
(c) depict in a way that is likely to cause offence to a reasonable adult, a child who is, or who appears to be, under 16 (whether or not engaged in sexual activity)
(d) depicts child abuse
(e) promotes, incites or instructs in matters of crime or violence, or which depicts denigration of religious beliefs
(f) depicts material which is unsuitable for a minor to see or play (definition of `minor' is the same as in the Classification (Publications, Films and Computer Games) Act 1994)
and that the legislation ensure
(4) that requests for classification by investigating or prosecuting Authorities shall be completed by the Censorship Board within 60 days, and
(5) provide that proceedings for an offence under section 1.(a), (b) and (c) may be commenced at any time after the material has been refused classification.

Your petitioners also request that all of the above be included in section 85ZE of the Crimes Act 1914. Your petitioners therefore request the House to enshrine legislation containing the above to ensure that the information superhighway be used to contribute beneficial knowledge which will enrich the lives of all Australians.

PETITION.TITLE: Sudan
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled:
The petition of certain citizens of Australia draws to the attention of the House that:
(a) the Sudanese Government's policies of genocide against Sudanese groups are repugnant, and
(b) the sustained and systematic attempt to enforce Sharia law on non‐Islamic citizens is condemned.
Your petitioners therefore pray that the House of Representatives will persuade the Government and the international community, including the UN Security Council to:
(i) impose an arms embargo on the Government of Sudan
(ii) establish air exclusion zones in Sudan
(iii) support the peace initiatives of the Inter‐Governmental Authority for Drought and Desertification
(iv) engage in discussion with all officially banned democratic opposition groups
(v) ensure the immediate access by the United Nations Operation, Life‐Line Sudan and other aid agencies into all areas; and
(vi) Provide teams to monitor human rights in the north, south and the Nuba Mountains of Sudan.

PETITION.TITLE: Television Reception
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and the Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament:
The Petition of certain residents of the State of Queensland draws to the attention of the House:
That many areas of Sarina and surrounding district have very poor television reception.
Your Petitioners, therefore request the House to:
Ensure that the quality of television reception to Sarina and district residents is improved to a suitable standard.
And your Petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Commonwealth Bank
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament:

The petition of certain electors of the Division of Shortland draws to the attention of the House that residents of Budgewoi and adjacent areas will be seriously disadvantaged and inconvenienced if the Commonwealth Bank proceeds with its proposals to close its Budgewoi branch on 31st May, 1996.
Your petitioners request the House to call on the Commonwealth Bank of Australia to maintain its existing banking services at Budgewoi.

PETITION.TITLE: Betaferon
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament:

The petition of certain citizens of Australia draws to the attention of the House the plight of young Australian adults suffering from multiple sclerosis. At present Betaferon, the only drug available to the improve the quality of life for these citizens and potentially decrease the percentage of these people that will inevitably become a disabled burden on society and the government, is not available as a subsidised drug. Your petitioners therefore request the House to legislate to make Betaferon available as a subsidised drug for all Australians that may benefit from it.

PETITION.TITLE: Social Security Offices
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled:

The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of the State of Victoria showeth they are against proposals by the Secretary to the Minister for Social Security, to close the Wendouree office of Social Security. The location of the office in Wendouree office provides a vital service to clients in the North‐Eastern region and should not be closed.
Further, we believe that a transfer of work to the Ballarat DSS office will only exacerbate problems of client access and proper service delivery to the region.
Your petitioners therefore pray that the proposed Wendouree closure not be supported by the Members of the House of Representatives.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Petrol
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament:

The petition of certain citizens of Australia draws to the attention of the House that petrol prices in country Victoria are too high and that country Victorians are severely disadvantaged and suffering with prices as high as 12c per litre more than in metropolitan Melbourne.
Your petitioners therefore request the House to adopt the alternative presented by the RACV, Victorian Farmers Federation and the Victoria Automobile Chamber of Commerce which recommends:
the abolition of the PSA's set maximum wholesale price of fuel;
the provision for all wholesale purchasers of access to fuel at the wholesale terminal gate price for that class of customer;
that the current metropolitan free delivery zone be abolished;
that oil terminals be open to any potential customer or transport operator with a vehicle meeting appropriate standards driven by a suitably qualified driver;
that the ACCC monitor all links in the petrol delivery chain;
that the principles of aforementioned should be put into effect through a separate petroleum industry code of practice on petrol pricing.

PETITION.TITLE: Fuel
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament.
The following citizens of Australia request that the House of Representatives notes with concern:
(1) the high cost of fuel, especially in country, regional and remote areas of Australia;
(2) that country residents are frequently required to pay from 7 cents to 14 cents per litre higher than prices in the city, despite regulation of maximum wholesale prices and transport costs;
(3) that fuel consumers in both city and country areas do not always have access to an effective open, transparent and competitive market that is fair to all consumers, free from discrimination; and
(4) that fair and reasonable fuel prices for all consumers are not available under existing practices.
Your Petitioners request the House to call on the government to act to address these problems by implementing the proposals of the RACV, VFF and VACC to:

(a) assist in the establishment of a voluntary oil industry code of conduct involving a system of access to fuel designed to prevent unfair discrimination between retailers of fuel in the country and the city;
(b) ensure wholesale fuel prices are published daily;
(c) ensure oil companies are able to set the price for fuel at different rates recognising the commercial realities of price differences based on volume and terms of payment;
(d) ensure all wholesale purchasers have access to fuel at the published rate applicable to the volume of fuel and the terms of payment involved in the transaction;
(e) ensure that wholesale fuel should not be offered at different prices at delivery to different customers based on the geographic area in which the customer operates; and
(f) open oil terminals to any potential customer with an appropriate vehicle and qualified driver; and

Your Petitioners request that the House further calls on the government to ensure that the new system is closely monitored by the Australian Competition and Consumer Commission and if evidence of discrimination, uncompetitive practices or profiteering is discovered, to take firm and prompt action against those involved in such unfair and unacceptable practices.

PETITION.TITLE: Gun Laws
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament:
The petition of certain citizens draws to the attention of the House the need for tighter gun laws.
Your petitioners therefore ask the House to support moves by the Prime Minister to tighten gun laws through the following measures:
the banning of fully automatic and semi‐automatic weapons;
the introduction of a nation‐wide shooters licence system; and
the introduction of a nation‐wide gun registration system.

PETITION.TITLE: National Competition Policy Bill
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament:

The petition of certain residents of the State of South Australia draws to the attention of the House to certain shortcomings in the draft National Competition Policy Legislation which would result, on the one hand, in cuts in wages and conditions for affected public sector employees and user‐pays price increases which will cut low income people from services they now enjoy, and on the other hand, price cuts for big business.
Your petitioners therefore ask the House to amend the Bill for a National Competition Policy to ensure that:
(1) all existing environmental, consumer, health and safety, wages and working conditions and social justice regulations are maintained for all public sector operations affected by the new law;

(2) no privatisation or franchising out or "third party access" to public facilities take place without a transparent public process which establishes the advantages to the public interest from such a change;

(3) where a privatisation, franchising out or "third party access" takes place, that the wages and working conditions established in current Enterprise Bargaining Agreements and Awards transfer to the new employer, thus preventing bidders from bargaining with the employees' wages and working conditions. Laws to this effect apply in Europe, and should also apply in Australia.

PETITION.TITLE: Pharmacies
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.

The petition of certain residents of the State of Queensland draws to the attention of the House the proposal to establish a pharmacy at Montville to service the needs of local residents and visitors. We believe there is a genuine need for a local pharmacy because
(a) the town and district are poorly serviced by public transport
(b) the town is relatively isolated by geographic factors
(c) there is a significant population of retirees and young families
(d) there is a general practice open 34.5 hours per week
(e) further, there are three specialist doctors consulting in Montville, including a full‐time dermatologist.
Your petitioners therefore request that the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled require the Government to allow this proposal to proceed.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.
