SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brereton, Laurie, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Australian parliament:
(1) declares its support for world efforts to secure peace in the Middle East through a settlement of the present conflict between the Hezbollah and Israel in Southern Lebanon;
(2) deplores the tragic loss of life and the endangerment of the innocent civilian population as a result of this conflict;
(3) is of the view that a settlement must involve the governments of Lebanon, Syria and Israel and be based on the following guarantees:
(a) the territorial integrity of Lebanon and all countries in the region; and
(b) the absolute right of security for the citizens of Israel; and
(4) supports the implementation of UN Security Council Resolution 425 as part of the settlement.

Last month all Australians were shocked and appalled by the tragic events in Lebanon. As honourable members will recall, for 16 days each night's television news brought us scenes of conflict and horror as Israel's armed forces launched massive air and artillery attacks in southern Lebanon, an operation codenamed `Grapes of wrath', in response to Katyusha rocket attacks on northern Israel by Hezbollah guerillas.

It is not my intention today to canvass all the rights and wrongs of this episode. Israel has said its actions were defensive and aimed at protecting its northern population centres against repeated rocket attacks. At the same time, however, no-one should be allowed to ignore the horrendous human costs that resulted from Israel's action. More than 170 innocent Lebanese civilians—men, women and children—were killed in the bombardment and more than 400 others were injured. More than 100 Lebanese civilians—refugees seeking safety—were killed when Israeli artillery shelled the UN peacekeeping camp at Qana.

Some 200 Lebanese villages were evacuated because of the bombardment and more than 400,000 Lebanese were made refugees—forced from their homes until the shelling ceased in the early hours of 27 April. There was also extensive damage to Lebanon's electricity supply, blockage of its ports and repeated fire on civilians travelling Lebanon's main coastal road.

The tragic events of last month were, of course, only the latest episode in Lebanon's long history of conflict and long history of suffering—a history in which Lebanon has all too often been the subject of foreign occupation with flagrant disregard for Lebanese sovereignty and independence. Last month's events also clearly underscored the continuing fragility of the Middle East peace process. The successful efforts of the United States to broker a new cease‐fire between Israel and the Hezbollah are to be commended and demonstrate the vital role that they have played as a key player in the Middle East peace process.

Unfortunately, however, the underlying circumstances in Lebanon remained unchanged, sadly and tragically. Israeli forces and their ally, the South Lebanese Army, continue to occupy southern Lebanon whilst, at the same time, the Iranian backed Hezbollah guerillas remain committed to continuing their fight against Israel and continuing that fight from within the territory of Lebanon. At the same time, Syria continues to maintain an estimated 35,000 troops in Lebanon.

Against this background, there can be no doubt as to the absolute necessity for all participants in the Middle East peace process to work unremittingly to achieve a just and lasting peace for the region—a peace which, I put to the House today, must include a fundamental guarantee of the territorial integrity of Lebanon as well as the absolute right of security for the citizens of Israel.

There is no doubt that an essential element of any durable peace in the Middle East will be the implementation of resolution 425 of the Security Council. That resolution, adopted by the council more than 18 years ago, calls for:
. . . the strict respect for the territorial integrity, sovereignty and political independence of Lebanon within its internationally recognised boundaries . . .
It goes on to call on Israel to cease military action in Lebanon and to withdraw its forces from all Lebanese territory.

I am pleased to say that the profile that Lebanon enjoys in the minds of Australians today is greater than any other Arab country. Australians admire Lebanon's rich and ancient history—a history that has been touched by nearly all of the great civilisations of the past. We have welcomed into our presence in Australia over 400,000 Lebanese people and their descendants. This community has already played an extraordinarily positive role in building and maintaining linkages between Australia and Lebanon. Lebanese Australians have brought with them notable contributions at every level of Australian society—whether it be business, commerce, politics, education, sport or the arts. They have maintained a tremendous commitment to their adopted homeland whilst also cherishing their cultural and ethnic heritage.

We in Australia—I know I speak for all Australians—are delighted that this is so, giving such tangible expression to what multiculturalism is all about. In the process, all aspects of Australian life have been enriched, and we as a nation have a special responsibility in return to do all that we can to support respect for Lebanon's sovereignty and for Lebanon's territorial integrity as a fundamental and integral part of the Middle East peace process.

PARA.BREAK: Let me say to the House that our nation is neither a party to the Arab-Israel conflict, nor are we ever likely to play a major diplomatic role in mediation in the Middle East. But we do have important economic, strategic and humanitarian interests in the region. We share the strong global interest, strategically and economically, in the maintenance of stability in the Middle East and, of course, we share with the international community humanitarian concerns about the suffering that war and conflict are bringing upon innocent civil ians—concerns only too recently reinforced by the appalling events at Qana and elsewhere in southern Lebanon.

SPEECH.PARA: Australia's interests prompted the federal Labor government to make a significant contribution to the multilateral arm of the Middle East peace process. Australia has a longstanding commitment of Defence Force personnel to the UN Truce Supervision Organisation and, as well, we provide personnel for the Multinational Force and Observers in the Sinai.

Australia has been an active participant in the Arms Control and Regional Security Working Group. That was the group developed from the 1991 Madrid Middle East Peace Conference as the appropriate forum for negotiating regional arms control measures. We have been able to make this contribution because we have a great deal of positive experience—positive experience that comes from our own track record of involvement in non‐proliferation and weapons of mass destruction issues, especially the chemical weapons convention, the nuclear non-proliferation treaty and the comprehensive test ban treaty issues. Australia has been involved centrally in all of these areas. In addition, we have been able to draw upon our experience, given our leading role in the formation and development of the ASEAN regional security dialogue forum. That is the forum for our own region.

Can I say that of the many non-defence issues which are crucial to the stability in the Middle East we have taken a particular interest in that of water security. With its intrinsic importance to the region, and again because of our experience in that field, Australia has been an active contributor to the work of the Middle East Water Resources Working Group, and some very fine work indeed has been done by that group.

All of these activities have made a real contribution to the Middle East peace process, and we can be rightly proud of them. Our involvement in both the arms control and water resources working groups has been universally welcomed and valued by all of the countries of the region. Today, I urge the government to ensure that adequate resources are committed, within the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade and to Australian diplomatic posts in the Middle East, to continue and to build upon these most important activities.

At the same time it is incumbent upon all of us, as Australian members of parliament, government and opposition, to make sure that we take every opportunity to urge all of the parties to the peace process to respect the sovereignty of Lebanon as an integral and essential element of a just and enduring settlement in the region. In these and many other areas, none is less important than all of us looking for the opportunities that might present themselves in our electoral work to look at the great distress that exists and take whatever measures we can, be it through non‐government organisations or similar means, to provide assistance of a humanitarian kind.

Today is an important opportunity for us in the Australian parliament to demonstrate our support for efforts to secure peace in the Middle East. On Wednesday, Israel will hold its parliamentary elections and, one way or another, the Middle East peace process will enter a new phase. It is in that context that it is most timely for this parliament today to register our very strong support for all efforts to secure a just and lasting peace in the Middle East. I commend the motion to the House.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the motion seconded?
—I second the motion and reserve my right to speak.

—I was very pleased and interested to hear the speech of the shadow minister for foreign affairs, the member for Kingsford‐Smith (Mr Brereton). I was keen to hear him outline the opposition's policy in regard to the existing situation in Lebanon and the Middle East peace process. It seems that by and large we have a bipartisan view of the situation in Lebanon. It is important to speak on these issues so that we can do everything possible to ensure that participants come to the table in the spirit of peace and reconciliation.

BREAK.PARA: When I was first elected as a state member of parliament in 1984 I came across the very substantial number of people of Lebanese—Maronite, Melkite, Orthodox and Muslim—background in my electorate. I found them all to be very genuine people, for whom I have a lot of time and respect. One of the first things I noticed about the Lebanese is that, rather than asking, `How are you?' they invariably ask, `How is the family?' They feel that if the family is okay you are okay. They are people whom I have come to love. I have spent a lot of time with them over the past 13 years and will continue to do so because these are people who work hard, love their former country and love Australia just as passionately.

When I was aged about 10 or so my uncle took me on a short holiday from Alexandria in Egypt, where I was born, to Lebanon. I remember seeing the city of Beirut and being very impressed with what I saw even at that early age. Lebanon is a very small nation, bordered on the north and east by Syria, on the south by Israel, and by the Mediterranean to the east. It is a very courageous nation which for centuries has been invaded and subjugated by the Phoenicians, the Egyptians, the Hittites, the Assyrians, the Neo‐Babylonians, the Crusaders, the Arabs and, for a 600‐year period, the Turks. Prior to that was invasion by the Romans and Greeks. The Lebanese have had a very tough life, but the little nation of Lebanon has always survived. As the shadow minister said, something in the vicinity of 400,000 Lebanese have migrated to Australia and they have done extremely well.

The current situation in Lebanon could become very explosive unless people of goodwill sit at the table to resolve this very difficult situation. There have been some 17 years of civil war. I recall that on each and every occasion that we gathered at the invitation of the Australian‐Lebanese community—be they Christian or Muslim—the same two things were said: Lebanon wants to be free of foreign interference in its internal affairs; and all foreign troops should leave Lebanon.

Unfortunately, that has not happened. As a result, tensions have continued and have heightened at different times, especially during the past 20 or so years. Four basic principles must be adopted. I was pleased that the shadow minister specifically mentioned UN Security Council resolution No. 45 regarding the security of Lebanon. We must remember that not only is Lebanon under threat but Israel as well.

I recall visiting Israel with my family some years ago. As we were going around visiting different places we invariably had escorts that used to be around us all the time—military escorts, armed escorts. Emblazoned in my memory is the sight of a young Israeli soldier who was only about 17, maybe 18, not much older than my eldest son who was with us at the time. I recall looking around and seeing this young man with a machine gun in his hand—a very big, menacing machine gun. I recall him looking up at the heights, the parapets, and I could see fear in his eyes. Then I saw my son beside him, not much younger, and I thought what a great country we have in Australia. We do not have that threat, as I saw in the eyes of that young Israeli soldier, over us constantly.

There are four basic resolutions that Australia has supported, and will continue to support, regarding the sovereignty of Lebanon. First of all, Israel's security must be ensured. Secondly, the sovereignty of both Israel and Lebanon must be respected. Thirdly, the negotiated settlement must be based on UN Security Council resolution 425 and credible assurances regarding Israel's security. Lastly, not the least of which, a settlement must engage Syria, which bears some responsibility to help end Hezbollah attacks against Israel. Syria has a very strong responsibility to ensure that Hezbollah comes to the negotiating table in a spirit of goodwill and compromise. Unless Hezbollah does that, then the situation will continue to be inflamed in that part of the world.

We also have to look at the situation regarding the terrific cost that has to be borne by Lebanon for the recent shelling that has occurred and the damage that has done to the economy of Lebanon. Some estimates put it as high as $500 million. That is something the Lebanese people themselves cannot carry. We need to look at doing all we can to provide not only moral support but also financial support. I am pleased to see that Australia has made a modest contribution towards the cost of that rebuilding. The Australian embassy in Beirut will be exploring with the Lebanese government and the business community how Australia can assist in the reconstruction process which is going on.

The Middle East faces a very explosive situation there unless the people come to the table in goodwill, sit down and negotiate a settlement that is not just a verbal settlement, as has occurred in the past, which has not worked, but a written agreement that would be binding on all parties and that will hopefully build for the future a safe Lebanon, a safe Israel and peace in the Middle East.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Melham, Daryl, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support this motion as a member of the House whose parents were born in the north of Lebanon. I think I am the only member of the House of Representatives of Lebanese descent. It is with a heavy heart that I have to rise to speak to this motion.

SPEECH.PARA: I have had three visits to Lebanon. My first visit was in August-September 1987 as a private citizen. That was towards the end of that horrific civil war. My second visit to Lebanon was as part of a parliamentary delegation to the Middle East. We visited Syria, Lebanon, Tunisia and Morocco. That was in December 1993, and we provided a report to the parliament. My third visit to Lebanon was in July last year when I was privileged to return to witness the reopening of the Australian embassy in Beirut.

On each of those three occasions I was able to witness a fragile peace, a developing nation coming out of what was a horrific civil war, and a people that were looking to the future. Australia showed its confidence by re-establishing the embassy in Beirut. Last July there was great hope. There were some 400 to 500 people celebrating the reopening of the embassy in Beirut.

There is no doubt that Australia is warmly regarded in the Middle East. That dates back to the First and Second World Wars when Australians fought and helped the liberation of Damascus. It also arises out of the strong migration that has taken place for over 130 years from the Middle East to Australia. During the period of the civil war, many people in Australia were sending money to their relatives in Lebanon. There are over 200,000 people of Lebanese descent or Lebanese born people living in Australia. So the bonds were and are still very strong.

It was quite devastating to see the ferocity of what was occurring in the south of Lebanon. The ferocity extended to Beirut itself. One cannot help but feel for the Lebanese people who, I think it is fair to say, appear to be pawns in a much wider game. There was an interesting article from the Washington Post which appeared in the Guardian Weekly on 28 April 1996. It says in part:

There are many explanations of why the violence burst out of its confinement in the security zone: Hezbollah's growing boldness, Iran's strategic aims, Syria's ire at a diplomatic freeze, Israel's election‐year ambitions and fears. Underlying all of them was the instability of the security zone itself, where Israel was in danger of losing its grip.
None of those have anything to do with the people of Lebanon. Another section of the article states:
Many Lebanese, even those unsympathetic to Hezbollah's call for strict Islamic rule, regard armed resistance as justified until Israel departs.

The truth is—and the information we were given on our parliamentary delegation—that Hezbollah enjoys very little support in Lebanon. The only support it derives is as a result of the Israeli occupation of the southern zone. The information we were given was that, if Israel were to leave, the support for Hezbollah would dissipate very quickly. Another section of the article states:
Most analysts agree that while Peres had something to gain from Operation Grapes of Wrath, he had more to lose if he failed to respond to Hezbollah's escalation.

I do not stand here blaming Israel, Hezbollah or Syria alone. This is a complicated problem. But what people of Lebanese descent want—I think what everyone wants—is for this thing to stop and for the Middle East peace process to get back on the rails. It is imperative for a secure world for there to be just and lasting peace in Lebanon, in Syria, in Israel—in the whole of the Middle East region. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Barresi, Phil, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I commend the member for Kingsford-Smith (Mr Brereton) on the moving of this motion. I particularly feel that this House is richer for having members such as the member for Banks (Mr Melham) who are direct descendants from places such as these. It is through such members that the rest of us are helped to understand and empathise with some of the issues which affect other areas in the world, particularly war‐torn areas.

SPEECH.PARA: Australia is home to over 100,000 persons of Lebanese descent. The Lebanese have made a significant contribution to Australia, whether it be in small business or in establishing trade links with the Middle Eastern region. Yet Australia's Lebanese community has had to endure the harsh reality of their homeland ravished by war—of seeing Beirut, once the cultural and economic powerhouse of the Mediterranean, become the scene of the most divisive and bloody of civil wars.

Lebanese in Australia have relatives who have been affected by this war. For this reason, the Australian government has a responsibility to do everything in its power to encourage and facilitate the peace process in the Middle East. It is important that Lebanon be given a chance to prosper.

The tragic incident at Qana has no doubt been a setback for the Middle Eastern peace process but is one which must not mark the end of hope for achieving peace in southern Lebanon. The peace process must continue and Lebanon must be assisted by the international community in rebuilding those areas affected by recent hostilities. It is a matter of not just the financial cost, as the member for Lowe (Mr Zammit) has indicated—the $500 million—but also the more tragic loss of innocent human lives.

The Australian government has demonstrated a real commitment to the Lebanese people. The reopened Australian embassy plans to examine just how Australia can contribute to the reconstruction process. With Australia now having a lot of expertise in drylands agriculture and water projects, we have the chance over the next few years of making a lasting contribution to the physical wellbeing of Lebanon and other nearby countries.

The Qana incident is indicative of the degree to which the people of Lebanon have suffered over the years. The tragic bombing of the UN compound also cost the lives of Fijian United Nations peacekeepers—men committed to assisting the Lebanese people in the process of rebuilding their nation.

Such tragic events ought not lead us to neglect Israel's right to protect its borders and, above all, protect its people from the danger of attacks, both within and without Israel. No less tragic to the Qana incident have been the terrorist attacks on innocent Israeli citizens. By the end of 1995, over 100 Israelis had been killed by Hamas attacks. To date in 1996, a further 63 have been killed.

Attacks from Lebanese based Hezbollah terrorist groups are a real and constant threat to Israel. Hezbollah is a radical Shiah group, backed by Iran, which is anti-Israeli and anti-Western. Its reason for existence is the removal of all non-Islamic influences from the area—a notion which is threatening not only to Jewish Israelis but also to Christian Lebanese.

The more cynical political commentators have suggested that Israel's recent hardline stance against terrorists, a stance which tragically led to the Qana incident, has more to do with Israel's election campaign than real political concerns. I believe that all Israelis, whether they be supporters of the conservative Likud party or Mr Shimon Peres's Labor Party, would demand that Israel must be protected from terrorist organisations which are out to destroy not just the peace process but also Israel itself.

I personally hope that it will be in the interests of all Lebanese if, whoever wins the Israeli elections, the peace process set in motion by Yitzhak Rabin continues. If terrorist organisations in Lebanon or Israel are allowed to derail the process, Mr Rabin's death will become meaningless.

The motion's part (3)(b) is of great importance. Any settlement of the problems in the Middle East must protect the security of the Israeli people in a peace agreement between Lebanon and Israel. I believe it is fair to say that Syria must take some of the responsibility, particularly in exerting its influence over the Hezbollah and terrorist organisations, in bringing about a peaceful conclusion to the conflict.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLeay, Leo, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I am very pleased to support the motion moved in this House this afternoon by the honourable member for Kingsford-Smith (Mr Brereton). I think it is important to restate the motion. It reads:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Australian Parliament:
(1) declares its support for world efforts to secure peace in the Middle East through a settlement of the present conflict between the Hezbollah and Israel in Southern Lebanon;
(2) deplores the tragic loss of life and the endangerment of the innocent civilian population as a result of this conflict;
(3) is of the view that a settlement must involve the Governments of Lebanon, Syria and Israel and be based on the following guarantees:
(a) the territorial integrity of Lebanon and all countries in the region; and
(b) the absolute right of security for the citizens of Israel; and
(4) supports the implementation of UN Security Council Resolution 425 as part of the settlement.

I have been a member of this parliament for some 17 years now. There has not been a month or two that has gone by when I have not risen in this parliament to speak on the issue of Lebanon. The war in the southern part of Lebanon in particular has been going on for nearly 20 years, and many of the people who have come as migrants to Australia have come because they wanted to leave that war‐torn area and settle in a country where there is peace.

It is a very unfortunate thing when people have to leave their homes, their neighbours and, in many instances, their families because of what has occurred in the south of Lebanon, that is, an invasion by a foreign country, to wit Israel, and in the western part of the country by Syria in the Bekaa Valley region. Over recent years the government of Lebanon has, in effect, ruled nothing. Until recently, the country has been ripped apart by militias and foreign troops. I think we should be very careful in Australia's response to the crisis settlement in the Middle East that we do not see Lebanon become a casualty of a resolution of Israel's problems with its neighbours.

It would be too easy for the Americans, the French or whoever else wishes to broker a peace agreement between Israel and Syria to say that part of that brokering would be that the Syrians still have effective economic and political control over a great part of Lebanon and that the Israelis would still maintain some sort of security zone in the south. People would say that the question of the Hezbollah and Israel is a chicken and egg issue and whose point of view it is depends upon where the chicken and the egg started.

The reality is that over the years thousands of people have been killed. The Shi'ite population of south Lebanon have been tarred with a brush as alleged terrorists by international commentators. That allegation is not so. Most of those people have been fighting for their own lives and for their villages and have supported the Hezbollah because they were the only ones who, in some instances, took up the fight for them.

The group that we should be giving more consideration to is the Amal movement in south Lebanon. Nabih Berri and his people in that organisation are moderates and all they say is that Lebanon should be there for the Lebanese. A settlement of the Middle East question must involve Lebanon being satisfactorily dealt with and the only satisfactory way that Lebanon can be dealt with is that all the foreign troops should be out—the 35,000 Syrians and the thousands of people that the Israelis support.

Lebanon should be able to have free and fair elections so that Lebanon can then return to what it was 25 years ago, namely, the jewel of the Middle East, a country that people flock to and a country that should be reconstructed in that way. I think that this parliament and members on both sides should stress that Lebanon should not become the last casualty of the Middle East peace settlement. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cameron, Ross, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support the motion, having spent three hours last night with the parish of Our Lady of Lebanon in my electorate at what was a most inspiring gathering where the young people of that parish had presided over a budget of $250,000 to build a new youth centre for the parish. One of the young builders in the congregation had actually built the centre and the young people had raised $30,000 to complete that facility. It was a statement of what a group of motivated young Australians can do and a lesson from the Lebanese community to the rest of us in Australia about investing back in our communities.

SPEECH.PARA: The aspirations of that Lebanese community in Parramatta are similar to those of the rest of us in Australia and throughout the world in relation to peace. It is one of the most fundamental aspirations of the human spirit but it can be very costly to achieve. One cannot help but wonder what we, at this distance, can hope to achieve through a motion such as this, in agreement as I am with all four of its principal propositions. At times I wonder whether we are merely adding to the verbiage, adding to the sheet upon sheet of Hansard, and wondering in our hearts, on both sides, about the depth of our commitment to peace.

It has been noted to me that one of the greatest problems we have in this city of Canberra is a kind of tribal mentality, an unforgiving factionalism, a political culture with long memories in which many of our acts are motivated by revenge rather than by a desire to achieve peace. I suspect that we in this place ought to examine our own culture before setting ourselves up too highly on matters concerning peace in the Middle East.

It is something to which the honourable member for Kingsford‐Smith (Mr Brereton) rightly referred in saying that we have a contribution to make. I note the motion refers to UN Security Council resolution 425, which was passed some 18 years ago, and here we are today supporting this motion when so little progress seems to have been made. We must ask: what can we say, what do we have to offer, what words are worth anything more than the paper they are written on in that regard?

The Middle East is really the cradle of civilisation. It has thrown up the greatest leaders known to civilisation. A figure like Moses, who the Muslims would recognise as a divine messenger, a prophet with a new revelation, is likewise looked to with reverence by Christians and Jews as a patriarch of their faith. Seemingly, there are still elements which are held in common by all the parties which are having such enormous difficulty achieving cohesion and peace at present. They all share a belief in a monotheistic god.

I feel that we owe a great debt to the region. When we see what has happened in South Africa and in the former Soviet Union, when we see such inspiring examples of those who have transcended their histories, their factionalism, their tribal differences, I am optimistic about the prospects in the Middle East. I join with honourable members who have spoken previously about the need for respect for territorial integrity and for diverse religious cultures. Whatever peace is achieved ought not be a peace of the strong over the weak. Lebanon must be a part of any enduring peace settlement. If peace is to be enduring, it has to be a genuine expression of the will and hearts of the people. It will not be achieved by posturing or pre-election manoeuvring. We have to hope and pray that it is a growing, generalised aspiration of the people of the Middle East. We join with them as a statement of solidarity that—in spite of our distance—that situation is of considerable importance to us. We join with all those who seek peace. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tanner, Lindsay, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I am grateful for the opportunity to speak in support of the motion moved in the House today by the honourable member for Kingsford-Smith (Mr Brereton). I commend him for that motion and I commend the honourable members for Watson (Mr McLeay) and Banks (Mr Melham) on their contributions. I suggest the value of the Parliamentary Library Research Service to the honourable member for Parramatta (Mr Ross Cameron).

SPEECH.PARA: It is widely recognised that Israel's conduct within southern Lebanon constitutes a gross overreaction to assaults from Hezbollah. But we should not lose sight of the fact that Hezbollah is financed by Iranian sources and effectively operates as a bargaining chip under the de facto control of Syria. Nonetheless, the real momentum for Hezbollah's assault comes from the continued Israeli occupation of southern Lebanon and issues such as the diversion of water resources from the El Litani river in southern Lebanon and similar matters.

We need look no further than the bombing of the United Nations shelter at Qana and the death of over 100 civilians and United Nations peacekeepers, the destruction of power stations, and such atrocities as the destruction of the ambulance carrying injured civilians because it was a so-called Hezbollah ambulance. All of these incidents deserve the strongest condemnation of the House. But we need not ignore the attacks that have produced these outrages, because Hezbollah and those who support them are equally culpable for what they are doing.

It is tragic that, just at a time when finally some form of fragile peace is starting to emerge in the Middle East and finally Israel is starting to give some form of remedy for the injustices that it has meted out to the Palestinian people over many years, these sorts of outrages should be occurring on both sides. The peace process in the Middle East should be allowed to work, and I am sure that we in this House all support that process and hope that it will work.

I commend to honourable members a very good article written on this issue by Martin Woolacott in the Guardian Weekly of 13 April 1996. In that article Mr Woolacott runs through the basic problem in the Middle East: how violence has become the only universal language and how people on all sides—Israelis, Syrians, some of the groups such as Hezbollah and Hamas—are effectively using violence as a political weapon to bolster their own authority with respect to their constituencies.

An important issue lurking behind the current situation, which was adverted to by the member for Watson, and which I would like to refer to in the brief moments available to me, is the future of Lebanon. The period after the conclusion of the civil war in Lebanon under the Taif accords has been followed by effective Syrian hegemony in Lebanon, a regime that is dominated by Syria, with roughly 35,000 troops from Syria stationed in Lebanon. There are substantial question marks over the legitimacy of the Lebanese government. Elections were subject to widespread mass boycotts. Recent presidential elections that were due have been scrapped and the term of President Hrawi has been extended.

It is widely rumoured that the parliamentary elections that are due in September this year will also be similarly postponed. Many Lebanese from across the denominational and sectarian spectrum do not regard the government as legitimate. There is a serious risk that Lebanon will effectively become a pawn in the negotiations with respect to future Middle East peace arrangements and that, because of the Syrian dominance of Lebanon at the moment, it will potentially be condemned to indefinite foreign control or some of its existing resources will be traded away: for example, water rights.

The sad thing is that this sort of arrangement could very well suit Israel. Lebanon is probably the major potential competitor with Israel with respect to its economic future in the Middle East. It is westernised, highly skilled, multicultural and has some sort of democratic traditions. If it is under some sort of authoritarian rule, if it is fragmented, if it continues in the situation that it is in, its potential economic threat to Israel is much less. I am disturbed to see recent threats in that regard made by the Israeli Deputy Minister of Defence, Mr Ori Orr.

Therefore, Australia should be pressing for the implementation of not only UN Security Council resolution 425 but also resolution 520, which calls for `the strict respect of the sovereignty, territorial integrity, unity and political independence of Lebanon under the sole and exclusive authority of the government of Lebanon'. Removal of Syrian troops from Lebanon is not the first nor the most important step for Middle East peace, but it must be not be forgotten that it is an important part of achieving a just and comprehensive and overall solution to the Middle East situation. We must not allow broader geopolitical considerations to push the integrity and independence of Lebanon and the future for the Lebanese people off the agenda. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Broadbent, Russell, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker Jenkins, the first thing I should do, as I rise on this very important matter, is to congratulate you on your elevation to the position that you currently hold. I hope that your wait for return to government is a long and patient one.

SPEECH.PARA: In my first address to this House since becoming the member for McMillan, rather than the member for the former seat of Corinella, I did not think I would find myself standing here supporting a motion moved by the member for Kingsford-Smith (Mr Brereton), with whom I have little in common, supported by the member for Banks (Mr Melham), with whom I have less in common, and further supported by the member for Watson (Mr Leo McLeay), with whom I have little in common, and by the member for Melbourne (Mr Tanner), with whom I have nothing in common.

It is a reflection of this House and this parliament that we are representatives of the community we serve. Part of the community we serve, as pointed out by the member for Kingsford-Smith, is made up of 400,000 Lebanese, all with a heart for this country and concerns and a heart for their own. It is appropriate for us to address in this parliament, on the other side of the world from where these conflicts take place, but where our television screens flash to us, the ghastly pictures that we see of what can happen with one smart bomb in one small area.

In this country we fall over if we have a major bus smash. We have had the tragedy in Port Arthur that stopped a nation. We can remember back to Cyclone Tracy, which stopped the country for six months. Yet these people have had to put up with this sort of tragedy for a long time. There have been a number of programs on Australian television over the weekend, probably in the build up to the elections, as pointed out by the member for Kingsford-Smith, that will be held in Israel this week. One of the lines that was used was, `The dust of the Middle East is old and has seen a lot of blood.' I dwelt on that and thought that we in Australia will be here in Canberra on the other side of the world with one member of this House, the member for Banks, with Lebanese blood running through his veins.

My only investment in the people of Lebanon is that as a former retailer—probably the only one in this House at the moment; I am not sure—I have dealt with these people and found out that they are not only good business people, they are excellent business people and they have contributed enormously to this nation. Why? Because our concern is a direct one. Our concern is that the overarching peace process must continue whether it is between Israel and Syria or the others mentioned by the member for Melbourne and that we are to bring peace through with the other smaller players that are intent on disrupting the process itself at any cost. What we can do from a distance is say, `Yes, we are here in Australia and we actually do care.'

Therefore, by the good grace of this parliament, I was lucky to be taken on a delegation to the Middle East at the end of 1992. We visited Iran, Jordan, Egypt and Israel. I was exposed for the first time to the realities of what the Middle East is—not reading it in a library document, not hearing about it from a speech in this House, not reading it in a paper or seeing it on television, but experiencing what those people feel in those nations in that area.

I have not been to Lebanon, described as the jewel of the Middle East. What I heard from the member for Banks this morning in a previous conversation is that these people have the ability to rebuild and rebuild themselves. What we can do in this nation on behalf of this whole Middle East process is continue with our efforts as best we can and encourage these people to stay there and be part of the process, as we are part of the process, as best we can.

We will not give up in this House on behalf of the people who live in this country. We stand with them on this day and say, `If there is a process where this parliament can help this Middle East peace process to its conclusion, we will be there.' We will stand with those people and every effort, as has been outlined by the speeches today, will be made and hopefully accepted in a bipartisan way, as it has been today. It is my pleasure to stand here and support the previous speakers.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sercombe, Bob,MP

TALK.START.PARA: —Over recent years we have all witnessed the very considerable courage that has been shown by a number of leaders of both Israel and various Arab communities in starting the peace process. Some considerable time ago we saw peace between Israel and Egypt, followed up somewhat later by peace between Jordan and Israel. In more recent times we were all moved by the handshake between Yitzhak Rabin and Yasser Arafat. In more recent times we have seen very considerable progress made in the settlement of the political status of the Palestinian people in relation to the West Bank and Gaza. We have also seen the considerable strides made by the Palestinian authorities in relation to the amendments of their charter.

SPEECH.PARA: All those points of courage need to be congratulated, but they need to be built on. They need to be built on by a vision of the future of the Middle East. In that respect, I commend to the House a book written a few years ago by the current Israeli Prime Minister, Shimon Peres, entitled The New Middle East. Shimon Peres outlines his vision of a Middle East as a peaceful, developing, economically cooperating area for the benefit of all the people of that region. He says, amongst other things:
With the Middle East at a turning point in history, it is time to seek a different "solution . . .

He is talking about a different solution in the sense of a non-military answer of a non‐military solution because a military solution is, frankly, not possible. We now need to see a rekindling of the peace process in a way which produces a settlement with Syria on the difficult issue of the Golan Heights. This motion before the House today of the shadow spokesman on foreign affairs, the honourable member for Kingsford‐Smith (Mr Brereton), very much deals with a settlement in relation to Lebanon, which is based on the sovereignty and the territorial integrity of Lebanon. If it is to be durable, that peace process needs to reflect that Israel's security has to be ensured. The sovereignty of nations in the area needs to be respected and any settlement has to engage Syria, which does bear some responsibility to help prevent Hezbollah attacks against Israel.

Having said all that, I want to refer to a lead article that appeared in the respected Economist magazine on 20 April. It directly relates to the more recent events which have occurred in Lebanon. The article states:

Israel has the right, and indeed the duty, to protect its people . . . But neither the protection of its citizens in northern Galilee, nor the hope of a comprehensive Middle Eastern peace, justifies the forcible displacement of up to half a million inoffensive Lebanese, and the savaging of their homes and livelihoods.
What is required is a sense of proportion. Shimon Peres, in the book that I referred to earlier, certainly clearly understands that because he said the following:

Prolongation of the Arab‐Israeli conflict has inevitably led to the continued misery of millions. In frustration, many of these people have turned to mysticism and otherworldliness, have rejected the modernist state, and have immersed themselves in religious fundamentalism.

Press reports make it clear that Hezbollah support in the community there essentially arises from its role as a resistance movement and, once the issues in dispute principally between Israel and Syria are resolved, the expectation is that the future Hezbollah—along with the other militias that have already been dissolved and absorbed into the Lebanese national army—ought to also be quite capable of being resolved in a way which ensures the security of Israel but respects the legitimate rights of the people of Lebanon to their territorial integrity.

As other speakers have said, Lebanon is a jewel. It has been in the past a powerhouse for the economic development of the Middle East; it ought to have that opportunity again. Before the recent outbreak of troubles there, the economic projections for Lebanon were growth rates of eight per cent per annum up until the next century. Those sorts of growth rates would transform it in the sorts of ways Shimon Peres envisaged in his book. There would be great opportunities for cooperation and economic development, including, I might say, the economic development of Syria. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brereton, Laurie, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave of the House to speak again without closing the debate.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the House for its indulgence, Mr Deputy Speaker, and I very sincerely thank each of the members who have contributed to this debate this afternoon. The measure of agreement and the measure of universal concern that has been expressed for the future of Lebanon and for the people of Lebanon is entirely appropriate coming from the Australian Parliament which, as we have said here this afternoon, represents several hundred thousand people either born in Lebanon or of Lebanese descent.

SPEECH.PARA: Might I say that I am thankful to the members for Lowe (Mr Zammit), Banks (Mr Melham), Deakin (Mr Barresi), Watson (Mr Leo McLeay), Parramatta (Mr Ross Cameron), Melbourne (Mr Tanner), McMillan (Mr Broadbent) and Maribyrnong (Mr Sercombe) for their participation in the debate this afternoon. When the member for Banks spoke from his personal knowledge of Lebanon, of his three visits there, and with the experience of someone who is of Lebanese descent, you could not help but be moved. He has very well illustrated to the House the ferocity of the conflict and the enormous damage that has been done and that he has witnessed with his own eyes. But he also spoke of the great spirit that will be able to rebuild the nation, provided we can guarantee its sovereignty and territorial independence.

The fact is, as the member for Watson said, the Lebanon has always stood a real risk of being a casualty in the Middle East peace process—being, as it were, the expendable chip. But the purpose of this motion this afternoon, and the unanimous support that has been given to it, is indicative of the fact that the Australian Parliament believes that fundamental to Middle East peace is the guarantee of the sovereignty of the state of Lebanon and respect by all of the parties for the territorial boundaries and the territorial independence of the nation of the Lebanon. There is no doubt that everyone today supports the concept of a Lebanon for the Lebanese—indeed, a multi‐religious sovereign nation, one that is respected by all—and, of course, we have a very special responsibility on all of us to be advocating that at every opportunity.

I will say something about the comments of the member for Parramatta here this afternoon because he raised a number of questions. He asked what could really be achieved; were we just adding verbiage, were these just words. I think it is fair to ask the questions but, of course, there is a great deal we can do. First of all, we can speak out fulsomely in support of the right course of action for Lebanon. Secondly, we can make sure that our voices are heard here in the parliament. It is not just a matter of telling our constituents that we think the Lebanese have had a bad go; it is a matter of us taking that view out to the wider world.

As I acknowledged in speaking to the motion, we are not central players in the settlement of the Middle East peace process, but we can and must ensure that our voices are heard and that we influence our friends, those who are parties to the settlement of the Middle East peace process, to the maximum extent possible. I think this is terribly important.

It is equally important, I think, that the government ensure that in those areas that I indicated where we are doing valuable work through the United Nations—and it is very valuable work: the work of the arms control group and the water resources working group has been widely welcomed by all countries in the region—that the effort is maintained. With government cutbacks in the forthcoming budget it would be very easy for the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade to say that these are expendable areas of discretionary commitment. It will be a real test to continue to ensure we put the resources into those terribly important efforts. (Time expired)

PROCTEXT.PARA: Question proposed:
That grievances be noted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Morris, Peter, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —My grievance today is the decision by the Commonwealth Bank of Australia and Westpac Banking Corporation to close their branches at Budgewoi in my electorate. The Commonwealth Bank is scheduled to close on 31 May 1996 and Westpac on 21 June 1996. Earlier today the Clerk of the House presented petitions I had lodged from some 737 petitioners from my electorate requesting that the House call on the Commonwealth Bank of Australia to maintain its existing services at Budgewoi.

SPEECH.PARA: I present also, in a form that you will not accept—and nor will the House—a further 655 signatures to petitions. I am going to walk from this desk a little later to the Acting Clerk of the House and hand it to him. Undoubtedly, he will say to me, `These are not in a form acceptable to the House.' I will still present them to him. I want the parliament to note that there are almost twice as many people—there are 1,392 people—who are gravely dissatisfied with the actions of the Commonwealth Bank and Westpac Banking Corporation. One way or another, we will get this information through the House, possibly with the help of the Minister for Industrial Relations and Leader of the House (Mr Reith), to the minister responsible and to the banks to try to reverse those decisions.

At a time when banks are making record profits and senior executives of banks are being paid obscene levels of salary, they have now descended to the stage where they are going around branch by branch picking them off in areas that have long supported both those banks, particularly in the case of the Commonwealth Bank. Both Westpac, under its former names, and the Commonwealth Bank lived for decades off the miserable amounts they paid to savings bank depositors—1¼ per cent—moneys that were lent out subsequently at eight, 10, 12, 15, or 20 per cent rates of interest to borrowers.

They have lived and waxed fat for years off these people who now in their later years of life find it extremely difficult to change banking practices and banking means. Now, when these people need the assistance of the banks to help them with their monetary matters, the banks say, `Sorry, we are not making a profit at your branch. Not enough money is being lent at the branch at which you do business and we are closing up shop. You will be able to transfer to other branches or use some of the other electronic means that are available.' Try teaching an 82‐year‐old person with limited sight how to use an automatic teller machine. Try showing them how to fill in a new form in a new banking system or getting them to change the practice that they have where they are used to people looking after their affairs and knowing their problems and needs.

When the news came through that the Commonwealth Bank wanted to close its branch at Budgewoi, my constituents Ms Gail Staines and Ms Julie Buffon, and 82‐year‐old Mrs Jean Black, met with me to discuss the closure of the Commonwealth Bank at Budgewoi and the implications of that. They determined to gather signatures to the petitions that were tabled earlier, in addition to those signatures that they had already started gathering before I was able to get them a proper format that I requested be passed on to the appropriate minister.

To compound the damage being brought to Budgewoi and its residents, it was only two weeks later that Westpac announced that they would close their Budgewoi branch. They rang me and spoke to me about it. They said, `Look, we have been considering this for some time. We have had to bring our decision forward to close our branch too because the Commonwealth is going to close their branch and it would be most unsatisfactory if the Commonwealth Bank closed their branch and their customers transferred to us only to find that we were also closing our branch.' So, rather than doubly discomforting customers and my constituents, they decided to bring forward their date of closure.

We have a situation where low income earners will be hit hardest by the closure of the Commonwealth and Westpac banks. Claims by the banks that most transactions can be made from post offices or automatic teller machines fail to acknowledge that many isolated people in Budgewoi will find it difficult because of the public transport available to access the full range of banking services elsewhere. While the banks argue, as I have said, that you can use electronic means, that is just not possible or practical for people in the higher age group who are used to doing things a certain way and only consider doing them that way. It is not fair to those people who need personalised banking services for the banks to walk away from them.

Banks claim that business has declined and that there are not enough loans being written. My constituents are those people, as I said, who have propped up the profits of these banks in their earlier years with that cheap money that the banks used and which the banks paid them 1¼ per cent for. Westpac's decision to close its Budgewoi branch will create fresh hardships in addition to the Commonwealth Bank's decision to close its branch. Both banks are determined, it seems, to ignore the difficulties that their closures will create for those people who need their services most.

The system used to be that banks averaged their costs, returns and earnings across branches so a network of services was provided. Now we have the situation where banks are making record profits and paying obscene salaries to their senior executives and where each branch is considered on a branch by branch basis. It is no longer a complex of community service obligations. The reaction in Budgewoi was all the worse because, on the day that Westpac made it known that they were pulling out of Budgewoi, the chief executive of Westpac was telling Australia that they were on course for a billion dollar profit. So bye‐bye to Budgewoi banking services for the aged and loyal customers of Westpac: we are well on our way to a billion dollar profit this year for Westpac across Australia. I find it distasteful that that kind of event could take place.

The reaction that has taken place since then, along with our petitions and meeting with constituents, has been people getting together themselves and arranging a public meeting at Budgewoi at the Halekulani Bowling Club this Wednesday evening at 7.30 p.m. Unfortunately, as the House is sitting I cannot get to that meeting. They are having a public meeting for all the residents in the area to protest at what these banks are doing. It is not just a matter of me saying that here. Mr Ron Connell, the Senior Vice‐President of the Halekulani Bowling Club, said:

Here we have a government promising to look after small business yet they allow the banks to drive those small businesses to the wall . . . and if these two banks go, there will be a lot of pensioners who will go elsewhere to get their money and shop elsewhere. They're going to shoot down 30 or 40 businesses and their employees.'

That is now the great worry of the business people in Budgewoi: if you pull out those banks, you pull out the underpinning of services to that small business community. Not only do the residents lose the service but also the business people stand the risk of seeing their businesses damaged.
That letter was from the Central Coast Express Advocate of 17 May 1996. In the same newspaper of the same date, another constituent of mine, Mr L Wilson of Noraville, says:
The decision by the Commonwealth Bank to close its Budgewoi branch shows a total lack of regard for customers.
Many of Budgewoi's residents are pensioners, dependent upon the local branch and Toukley and Lake Haven branches are over capacity now.
The Commonwealth Bank once prided itself on the slogan: the bank with branches everywhere.

I strongly endorse the comments of Mr Wilson. We have to get the message across to banks that they are more than just cherry picking in the finance or banking worlds, that they do have a wider obligation to provide a service to the community. I wrote to the Chairman of the Westpac Banking Corporation, John Uhrig, on 21 May asking that the bank continue its services. I have not had a response from him yet. On 1 May I wrote to the chief general manager of the North Metropolitan branch of the Commonwealth Bank also requesting the Commonwealth Bank to continue its services. I have received no response. Twenty‐six days have elapsed, which is a reasonable time in which to have a response.

I have spoken with business people in Budgewoi and with Mr Ron Nash of Paul Finnimores Pharmacy. I feel for these people. These business people, our constituents and our community need a continuation of these services. People in higher age groups cannot readily change to complicated banking procedures. I seek in this grievance debate the support of this parliament for the petitions that were tabled earlier and for the request that I have made, and continue to make through the parliament now, that Westpac Banking Corporation and the Commonwealth Bank of Australia each continue to provide a range of banking services to the residents of Budgewoi and recognise that people in higher age groups cannot readily adapt to changes in the banking procedures or adapt to the use of electronic banking machines that younger people can readily embrace.

I seek the support of members on both sides of the House to try to ensure that an adequate network of banking and financial services is maintained to all of our communities, as has been the case for many, many decades.

TALK.START.PARA: —It might suit the purposes of the honourable member for Shortland if he sought leave of the House to have the non-conforming petitions tabled.
—Mr Deputy Speaker, I seek leave of the House to have the non-conforming petitions I hold in my right hand tabled and seek from the minister a process by which they could be recorded.

—This is a very important issue for the member for Shortland and, indeed, for all of us who hold rural and regional seats. The government very happily accedes to the request by the member for Shortland to table the out of order petitions.
—I thank the minister on behalf of my constituents and express our appreciation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bradford, John, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I grieve today for Anna Wood. The tragic death of 15-year-old Anna in October last year is a subject of an article in the Australian Magazine of this last weekend. The very beautiful face of this young girl adorns the cover of that magazine. The article is actually an edited extract from a story about Anna by Bronwyn Donaghy. It paints a picture of a society which obviously has some serious problems. If the story is in any respect typical of what is going on amongst younger teenagers, it would appear that we as a society have in many ways very badly let them down.

SPEECH.PARA: I do not intend in this short speech to add to the speculation about Anna's life or the exact circumstances surrounding her death. The circumstances are fairly well known. She died from taking an ecstasy tablet she purchased at a party at a friend's home. In this short speech, I would like to make a short contribution to the celebration of the apparent happiness of Anna's short life. She died when she was only 15 years old.

My wife and I were reading this article over the weekend. It occurred to both of us that every parent should either read this article in the magazine or read the book that has been written by Bronwyn Donaghy. One of Anna's young friends, who I suppose would be 14 or 15 years old, is quoted in this article as saying:
In the past year I've tried cigarettes, drinks, dope, speed, ecstasy and tripping, which is when you use LSD.
Does that sound like a typical 14‐ or 15‐year‐old? I hope not, but I wonder. Another one of Anna's friends, Alexia—these are not necessarily their real names, as the article points out—says:
In Year Seven we smoked to be cool. Then we tried marijuana, but we didn't like it much. By the time we were in Year Nine we couldn't stop smoking cigarettes. We were hooked.

Is this real? Are these kids who are talking in this article typical of kids in a middle class area in the northern beaches of Sydney, going to what is, as far as I can understand it, a pretty good school? There are a number of warnings for parents in this article, and that is why I think the article should be read by all parents. Anna's dad is quoted as saying:
You can't choose their friends for them and you can't tell your kids they can't go out, not when they get older.

He is talking about Anna, who was only 15 when she died. I wonder how long they had had that problem for. I do not want to comment on that proposition, but I think the statement that Anna's dad makes here raises lots of questions for parents about the extent to which we do intervene and, when we do intervene, at what stage of our children's lives we intervene to guide them in respect of their friends and in controlling their activities.

The mother of Kathy—Kathy is another one of Anna's friends—is called Anne in the article and she subscribes to the belief that today's parents indulge their children to compensate for the attention they are not providing. Why are parents not paying attention to their children? That is a crucial question which needs to be examined carefully. Maybe it is because of the pressures to achieve material success which means both parents have to go out and work when their children are young. Maybe it is the pressure placed on women in particular to place their children in institutional child care and go out to work outside the home.

The bottom line is that children need love, attention and supervision. They cannot get too much of it. All of our efforts in government should be directed to reversing the social engineering which has been occurring for too many years now.

Ironically, the story about Anna has been told at a time when the Victorian government is considering the decriminalisation of marijuana, as advocated by the Penington report. Some of the recommendations in this report include:

BREAK.PARA: 7.1 Use and possession of a small quantity of marijuana should no longer be an offence. `Small quantity' should be defined as no more than 25 grams . . .
7.2 Cultivation of up to five cannabis plants per household for personal use should no longer be an offence. `Household' should be defined to exclude everything other than private residences.

7.3 Sale of marijuana should remain an offence. Sale of small quantities by an adult to an adult should incur a caution delivered by Victoria Police for a first offence and an adjourned bond for a second offence.
Another one of the recommendations states:

Provisions of the Summary Offences Act 1966 should be reviewed to ensure offensive behaviour under the influence of marijuana can be dealt with by police. Similarly, local government should establish bylaws that restrict consumption in public places.

I can only imagine that local councils would be horrified to be lumbered with that particular responsibility. They have signs up all over the place now saying `No skateboarding', `No cycling'. I guess the next thing to be added will be `No marijuana smoking'. Goodness knows how they are meant to police these laws.

I cannot understand why Premier Kennett has not ruled out unequivocally this particular proposal. On his own admission, 97 per cent of submissions to his office have been opposed to the decriminalisation of marijuana. The argument apparently is that prohibition has not worked. Apparently the Minister for Health and Family Services (Dr Wooldridge) and some of his medical colleagues actually support Mr Kennett's view on this matter.

I think this is crazy stuff. In the context of reading what happened to Anna Wood and how her young friends, 14‐year‐olds and 15‐year‐olds, were introduced to the drug scene first by smoking cigarettes—as if that is not a big enough problem for our society—then marijuana and so on down the line, we are heading down a very dangerous track. By allowing marijuana to be trivialised, we would be giving permission for young people to act as they wish about this drug.

PARA.BREAK: The claim that cannabis is safer than alcohol, a claim that is sometimes made in de fence of decriminalisation, is dangerously misleading. Cannabis remains in the body much longer than alcohol does. In fact it remains there for some months and it can certainly affect behaviour, as tests have shown many hours later. The tar content in a cannabis cigarette is 12 times higher than in a tobacco cigarette. The toxicity of cannabis is well established. Cannabis leads to impaired judgment. It causes bronchitis and the risk of lung cancer is much greater than with tobacco smoking. It is undoubtedly a gateway to other dangerous drugs.

BREAK.PARA: Surely at a time when we are grappling with the huge family and health destroying problems caused by alcohol abuse and with the huge health bill for tobacco abuse, you would think the decriminalisation of marijuana was not even being considered remotely seriously. It concerns me that apparently it is being considered seriously. I want to read into the record again what Anna's friend Chloe, who is 14 or 15 years old, said to make sure I make the point. Chloe said:
In the past year I've tried cigarettes, drinks, dope, speed, ecstasy and tripping, which is when you use LSD.

Surely our kids deserve better than a society which condones the use and, ultimately—perhaps even implicitly—the abuse of drugs. We as leaders in this country should be drawing the line on these issues now. We should be drawing the line firmly and clearly and recognising the problems we already have with drugs, particularly tobacco and alcohol, which are legal. Tobacco is a dangerous drug and one which is quite difficult to stop using. Surely we must draw the line. I encourage Premier Kennett to do so before it is too late.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Sheep: Ovine Johne's DiseaseBank Branch Closures

TALK.START.PARA: —All Australians should be aware of the troubles facing our wool industry at present, with world prices recently sinking below the cost of production and many producers still suffering the effects of, or recovering from, drought. Nowhere is this being felt harder than in my electorate of Calare, and to make matters worse many wool growers have been

BREAK.PARA: dealt yet another blow which deserves urgent federal government attention. Until recently, few people outside Calare had even heard of Ovine Johne's disease, and because it is largely confined to the central tablelands of New South Wales it appears to have been given only scant attention.

Johne's disease is caused by a bacteria that invades the small intestine of sheep causing the animal to waste away and eventually die. In the worst cases it has wiped out 15 per cent of flocks. The disease is believed to have originated in Europe and appears to thrive in cold climates, which is why it has so far remained largely confined to the tablelands of New South Wales, although any thought of its exclusivity to this region were erased by its discovery in several Victorian flocks in December last year.

There is no known cure. The bacteria lives in the soil and the disease was first detected in the Orange district in the drought of the early 1980s when animals were grazing closer to the soil. Because no action was taken back then, it has resurfaced in the latest drought over a more widespread area.

So far 130 properties are affected. One hundred of those are in the Calare electorate. These fine wool producers have moved quickly to try to contain the problem, placing bans on the sale of any breeding stock from flocks in which Johne's disease has been detected. This action has left many facing financial ruin.

One letter I received from an Orange district stud last week gives an indication of the sorts of hardships Johne's disease is causing to farming families. Since the disease was detected in the stud flock last month, the family has been unable to sell any of its stock. Mr Deputy Speaker, I will read you part of this letter. It states:

I hope this letter will show you how devastated we are at the news last week of Ovine Johnes in our stud. The stud was formed in 1988 with Stud Sheep bought as well as ewes with one hundred years of breeding that our family had achieved and have embarked on an extensive breeding program artificially inseminating all the stud ewes with top sires. This has been costly but as we thought well worth the money.

In April of this year we had 830 commercial ewes sold to Victoria for $37.00 (a total of $30,710) only to be told when the truck was at Bombala that we were under suspicion of Johnes Disease. These people in Victoria were also after as many sheep as we could supply so another 300 would also have been sold. My husband turned the truck around at Bombala and we no longer had our interest payment and carry-on money for the planting of our wheat. We had also sold $50,000 worth of rams to Melbourne to be delivered later this year. In just 4 weeks we have already lost over $90,000. We have documented proof of all these sales.

Because of the drought we were struggling to pay our interest in 95. We felt it was a temporary state of affairs and we were confident we could trade out of this short term difficulty. I tried unsuccessfully to date, to have Northern Division B in the Bathurst Pastures Protection Board District drought declared exceptional circumstances even though we met all criteria and we are surrounded on three sides by exceptional circumstances. With an interest subsidy last year we would have been financial. Now Ovine Johnes Disease.

This lost income has meant the family has been unable to make an interest payment to the bank. It has also had no money to sow a wheat crop, therefore missing out on the chance to take advantage of the current high prices in that industry.

I would argue that if ever a case existed for receiving exceptional circumstances assistance from the Commonwealth government, this is it. I know an informal approach was made to the former primary industries minister to see whether property owners affected by Johne's disease could qualify for funding under the rural adjustment scheme provisions. Understandably, with so much money already going out to drought affected families, the minister was loath to consider extending funding to farmers whose income has been hit by Johne's disease or any other disease. I would, however, implore the new government to show some compassion to these families who really are suffering and to reconsider the former minister's stand.

Many communities in my electorate rely almost entirely on the sheep and wool industries for their existence. One of the major problems is that there is no test to find out if sheep actually have Johne's disease. The only way to do that is to kill them and carry out an autopsy.

A New South Wales agriculture department researcher at Orange is working on developing a reliable live test method. However, I am told that budget cuts by the Carr Labor government have seriously jeopardised this research. Clearly this problem, which threatens an industry that for decades was the lifeblood of the country, deserves more than to be left in the hands of farmers alone and the Carr state government—a government which seems to have done everything it can to destroy its credibility in the eyes of the agriculture industry and the rural community in general.

I would urge the federal minister, the member for Gwydir (Mr Anderson), the neighbouring electorate, to tackle this problem with the sort of leadership it deserves and intervene to ensure it does not become a national disaster. It may only be present in a small part of New South Wales, but it clearly is a national industry problem—with ramifications for our live mutton export as well if our overseas buyers decide that Johne's poses any sort of risk. We only have to look at the impact mad cow disease has had on the British industry. Market responses to similar mycobacterial diseases in animals, such as tuberculosis, are also well known.

The way regulations stand now, it is estimated the disease will be prevalent in a majority of sheep flocks in New South Wales within 15 years. The time to act is now, before it becomes so widespread that it will be far too expensive to take any control.

A steering committee has been set up and has put forward a strategic eradication plan, which is now open for public comment. Letters and deputations I have received from concerned producers already indicate there is widespread dissension within the industry over whether this plan will work. The criticisms already out there suggest it is not off to a good start. The steering committee admits its plan cannot work without the full support of affected producers. Indeed, from its draft plan the committee says:

. . . the sheep industry now has a very short window of opportunity to bring this disease under control before eradication becomes uneconomic as more and more properties and pastoral districts become infected by the introduction of infected sheep.

Whatever plan is finally adopted, the chairman of the steering committee has indicated that the Commonwealth would need to contribute as much as $3 million to make it work. I believe there should also be a compensation scheme to enable graziers to de‐stock and safely replace their breeding flocks with minimum penalty, because at the moment the likely cost of eradication will be far greater than the cost of the disease itself.
I have informed the minister that I was to make this speech. I would urge him to seriously consider this call for assistance, because I believe our marino industry is at grave risk.

In closing—and in stressing the need for more, not less, government support for the bush—I endorse the views expressed a moment earlier by the member for Shortland (Mr Peter Morris) on reduced bank services. My electorate is also to lose two Commonwealth Bank branches, at Kandos and Canowindra—thanks in no small way to this government, and the one before, totally supporting privatisation, economic rationalism and government downsizing policies that bear no sympathies for the needs of rural communities like Kandos, where no banking service apart from a post office will remain.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Worth, Trish, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —My grievance relates to the ill service given to the people of South Australia, and in particular to my constituents in the federal seat of Adelaide, by a succession of Labor governments at both state and federal level. Since the late 1980s, South Australia, and in particular my inner city electorate of Adelaide, has been a microcosm of the economic and social costs associated with Labor's mismanagement. I would like to take this opportunity to alert the House to just some of these costs.

SPEECH.PARA: Youth unemployment in Adelaide city areas has remained at between 30 and 40 per cent since the early 1990s and, of course, the inner city central business district has witnessed many of the direct social consequences of prolonged youth unemployment. Increases in youth homelessness, crime, alcohol and drug abuse, and a general despondency among the younger people in Adelaide were all reported to my electorate office by a number of concerned voluntary and youth support groups working within the Adelaide area.

At the other end of the scale, the generally poor prospects of the labour market resulted in a drain of many of Adelaide's talented and experienced workers to the larger eastern states in a search for quality employment. The South Australian business sector has also experienced an exodus of managers and corporate personnel, many of whom had lived and worked in my electorate of Adelaide for many years. In 1980, there were 88 listed company headquarters in South Australia. By 1993, this figure had dropped to 39.

This departure of many good South Australians from the state during the worst years of state Labor undoubtedly contributed to South Australia having the worst population growth rate among the mainland states, with all the negative implications for the housing industry, consumer demand and small businesses. In the last year of the state Labor government in South Australia, the state had the lowest growth in investment of all Australian states while the number of available jobs declined by 11,000.

Many of South Australia's 62,000 small businesses are in my electorate, and the burden of Labor's mismanagement and apathy fell particularly heavily upon this sector. The then minister for small business—a South Australian—Senator Chris Schacht, epitomised the political cynicism and opportunism of federal Labor. Despite recommendations and the pleading of several small businesses and retail groups for the then Labor government to address the problem of unfair competition, red tape and an unfair tax burden, the then minister could only introduce the Trade Practices Amendment (Better Business Conduct) Bill into the parliament in the last fortnight of the parliamentary sitting prior to the calling of the 2 March election. This was after 18 months of lobbying by the small business sector.

Not surprisingly, significant portions of the small business community questioned the commitment of the Labor Party to small business. This last‐ditch attempt to show some concern for the small business sector addressed few of the issues raised by the small business groups which consulted with me during the campaign and the small business sector was even more disheartened by Labor's inability to promise anything but more of the same in the lead‐up to the election. In stark contrast, the new Howard government has moved to reduce the provisional tax uplift factor, is in the process of forming small business consultative groups, and has already cut the volume of red tape faced by small business in its dealings with the Taxation Office.

Another outstanding piece of political cynicism was the Labor government's—and, in particular, the then Minister for Transport's—belated announcement of the funding to clean up the Australian National Islington toxic dump site at Kilburn in my electorate just three days before the 2 March election was announced. This was after I had lobbied the then minister for two years for an urgent and responsible reaction by the Labor government. It will now fall upon the coalition government to finally respond to the legitimate concerns of my constituents by cleaning up this contaminated site.

But the political cynicism shown by Labor was not restricted just to their time in government. Their recent election campaign of fear and loathing introduced a whole new element of deceit.
