Let me remind the House that the members on the other side participated in deliberate misrepresentation of coalition policy, including the claim that a coalition government would introduce timed phone calls and destroy Medicare.

Another political stunt used by my Labor opponent in the campaign for Adelaide was the use of a letter supporting her, signed by Australia's Olympic soccer coach, Mr Eddie Thomson, in the guise of an ordinary neighbourhood letter. I am reliably informed that permission was never sought or given for the circulation of this letter. The fact that this piece of material was authorised by someone else gives further weight to this claim.

The Labor Party was cynical in government and desperate in the election campaign and remains unapologetic and arrogant about its economic and social performance whilst in government at both federal and state level. I am pleased to report to the House, however, that the job of undoing Labor's mess is well under way in South Australia.

By the end of the 1980s, state debt in South Australia amounted to $8,000 million, with the State Bank alone recording a $3,150 million loss. Simultaneously, 30,000 South Australians were out of work. Ties with the union movement had restricted the then Labor government's ability to implement the structural reform to the economy that commissioned reports—such as the one done by the Arthur D. Little Institute—had stated was overdue and critical if South Australia was to avoid becoming the economic and demographic backwater of Australia.

In 1993, the South Australian people comprehensively dismissed a Labor government short on ideas and performance, giving the state Liberal Party a 26‐seat majority in the lower house of the state parliament. After only a year, the Brown government had already begun to receive commendations from the national press for its debt reduction strategies, its investment and marketing initiatives and, perhaps most importantly of all, the putting into place of a clear vision of a new era of security and opportunity for South Australia.

The House will be pleased to know that business and investment are slowly returning to the state, led by such companies as Australis Cable TV, EDS, Motorola and MBF. By the middle of last year, indications from the South Australian Chamber of Commerce were that business confidence in the state was finally on an upward trend. In the December quarter of last year, South Australia recorded the highest quarterly and annual growth in gross state product of all states. The state debt is being cut faster than expected with projections of the state debt improving by $256 million since the last state budget.

The state government is also on target for a budget surplus by 1997‐98, despite inheriting a $350 million deficit from the state Labor government. Developments via the Brown government's IT2000 strategy in the technology and science sector now assist the return of $2.6 million in export earnings to the state from this sector. South Australia's internationally renowned wine industry, buoyant from new sources of investment and confidence in South Australia's fiscal environment, is on target to return $1 billion to the state in export earnings by the end of the century. Morgan and Banks Ltd, Australia's leading recruitment company, has also recently revealed that South Australian job seekers are among the most optimistic in the country.

Out of the 12 federal lower house seats in South Australia, 10 are held by the Liberal Party. The Labor Party of South Australia has much to answer for and has been sent a very clear message by the people of South Australia that propriety and responsibility in the financial management of the state and the country must always remain at the highest of levels.

The colony of South Australia was unique. Unlike other Australian settlements, South Australia was not settled by convicts. It was settled by innovators, pioneers and persons of conviction and innovation who were often escaping religious intolerance in their homelands and economic depression. Today, after many years of Labor, South Australia is again beginning to emerge as an important centre of innovation and opportunity.

Paul Keating asked the Australian people at the last election for another term to complete Labor's `Big Picture'. But, as reported in the Sydney Morning Herald last week, disillusioned workers believed that Mr Keating was `off fighting battles with little relevance to the battle of their daily lives'. Members on the opposite side of the chamber forgot individuals in seats like Adelaide who had been isolated by Labor in its pursuit of economic and social policies aimed more at filling the trophy cabinet than delivering real economic management and social justice.

Labor forgot the age pensioner, the jobless youth, the members of struggling small businesses and their families, and those who, despite hard work, could not get ahead but ultimately decided that enough was enough. The new coalition government at the federal level and the Liberal government in South Australia have begun the task of undoing Labor's economic mismanagement by reducing public sector debt, encouraging business and investment, and making the tough decisions needed to ensure that the lifestyle we enjoy in South Australia continues for us and for future South Australians.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crosio, Janice, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The Prime Minister (Mr Howard) earlier announced that he will be visiting Indonesia in August. I rise in all earnestness to speak in this grievance debate because some time in the next few weeks the Indonesian government will make a decision on how to meet that country's energy demands. It is a decision which will have great ramifications for all Indonesians and, depending on the outcome, it has the capacity to affect Australia and the entire South‐East Asia region. The question to be decided is whether Indonesia will go nuclear. Until there is an answer to that, the region must wait with bated breath.

SPEECH.PARA: It will not be an easy decision to make. Every advanced nation in the world has grappled with the question of how to supply the energy demands of its population. Since the development of nuclear power it is a question that has become more difficult to solve. Australia made that choice 30 years ago. We chose to say no to nuclear power, and I do not think we have had any cause to regret the fact since.

The Indonesians' decision is based on their estimated demand for energy come the year 2015. Government figures say that by that time the island of Java alone will require 32.6 gigawatts of electricity, of which only 25 gigawatts will be available from conventional energy sources such as hydroelectricity, geothermal electricity, gas, steam, natural gas, oil and coal. The government is considering whether to make up the energy shortfall by installing 12 nuclear power reactors on the islands of Java and Bali, the first to be built in the shadow of Mount Muria and scheduled to commence in 1998.

I do not think I am alone in this House in my concern over the Indonesians' decision. Safety is a real question. The dangers, the threats to the environment and to the people of the region, including Australians, are very genuine. It is a delicate situation but, after considering the facts surrounding the development of the proposed reactors, my view is that the Australian government should now use all of its influence and pursue this matter through all relevant channels to convince the Indonesians that nuclear energy is not necessarily the road best travelled.

The Indonesian government has pointed to nuclear power as a cheaper energy source than traditional forms of energy. That argument is open to debate. In 1993 the World Bank stated that the costs associated with nuclear power could be between 20 to 50 per cent higher than coal based energy. In fact, Mr Djali Ahimsa, the Director‐General of BATAN, Indonesia's national nuclear agency, has stated as much himself.

He has admitted that the price of nuclear energy for Indonesia will at the very best be equal to other energy sources but certainly not cheaper. In fact, the only reason the Indonesian government can point to nuclear energy as providing cheaper energy is that when doing its sums it has considered only the construction and production costs for the 12 reactors. It has not taken into account the costs related to environmental and health regulations, nor the prohibitive costs involved in disposing of nuclear waste. That leads me again to Mr Ahimsa, who stated:

In the United States . . . there are some nuclear power plants which are more expensive in terms of production costs because the United States government issues more regulations for power plants to comply with.
Is this supposed to allay our fears? I doubt it. Obviously, the Indonesian government does not intend its reactors to operate along the same stringent safety lines followed in the US.

There is further cause for concern. I do not know if the House is aware of this but the site of the first reactor, should it be built, is Mount Muria on the island of Java, which is actually a dormant volcano. In December 1989, the epicentre of an earthquake registering nine on the Richter scale—a very large tremor—was only about 50 kilometres from the proposed site.

Java is recognised as the second most active of nine international seismic zones. Six years ago there was an earthquake in Sumatra which rated seven on the Richter scale and killed 200 people. In December 1992 there was an earthquake at Flores Maumere which killed 1,500 people. In 1977, an earthquake just off Sumbawa island and its resulting tidal wave, or tsunami, killed 100 people. I can go back to 1883 and the devastation caused by the volcano Krakatoa, the eruption of which was heard as far away as Australia, and the resulting tidal wave which killed 30,000 Indonesians.

These natural tragedies cannot be ignored. Do we really want to see the Indonesians build 12 nuclear reactors, each with an energy capacity of 1,800 megawatts—greater than that of the ruined Chernobyl reactor—in such an environment? There are those who would argue that Japan has over 50 nuclear reactors, each built on an island which has had its share of seismic activity, all without any mishaps. I suggest that no building or reactor can be 100 per cent safe from an earthquake on a massive scale. There are others who would question the safety of any reactor positioned on a fault line in a country where political power often conflicts with technical expertise.

Australia has much to fear from this nuclear program should it progress. If any of the proposed reactors were to suffer an accident, and if such a breakdown were to occur between the months of October and April, it could spell disaster for us. During this period, the northern Australian wet, the prevailing winds could blow emissions from Java to the shores of the Northern Territory and Western Australia. You would have a situation where people as far away from Java as Broome, Townsville and Alice Springs could be the victims of radioactive fallout—a ghastly image that has recently been supported by studies conducted by Dr John Taylor of the Australian National University. If this sounds a little far fetched, remember the Chernobyl disaster and how its radioactive emissions spread thousands of kilometres across Europe, finally reaching the dairies and farms of Scotland and Wales.

And what of the nuclear waste produced by these reactors? Indonesia's unpredictable and violent natural environment poses great threats in this regard as well. Nuclear waste dump sites are potentially dangerous because of the possible penetration of radioactivity into the water.

How will the Indonesians protect their dump sites from the geologically unstable nature of their islands? How will they prevent the penetration of radionuclides into the sea? Where will Indonesia find the space to dump its waste considering its massive population and small land content? Will it look to Australia for assistance? All of these questions are not answered.

Just as in the past we have sent our hazardous waste to Indonesia for storage or recycling, will they now look to us to accept their radioactive waste? We are more geologically stable. We have large expanses of arid land suitable for such use. But should we consider now how we will respond to such a request before we even contemplate the construction of these reactors?
The World Bank has itself expressed reservation about the disposal of nuclear waste among the world's advanced nations. It reported:
The environmental problems associated with radioactive wastes have not been fully resolved in the OECD countries . . .

And we are not expected to question Indonesia's capacity, while still a developing nation, to deal with nuclear waste! How can we have faith in its ability while others, such as the United States and the UK, have failed to adequately deal with this problem in the past?

It is indeed a delicate question. When was the last time someone stood in a grievance debate in this House and argued against the Sellafield nuclear reactor site in the UK or the over 100 nuclear reactors in the United States? I am not questioning the right of the Indonesian government to consider nuclear power. I do not stand against the proposal out of some warped racist notion of `it's okay for them but not okay for you'.

There has always been an aura of danger surrounding nuclear power. In Indonesia's case, should they proceed with their program, it is my belief that the dangers facing their population and environment and Australia, which is what I really care for, through its sheer proximity are, however, much greater than normal. As such, I think we have an obligation not only to our own citizens and to their health but also, as a responsible member of the region and a close partner of the Indonesians, to do our best to persuade them from taking this path.

We should offer our technological expertise to the Indonesians. We should assist them in developing alternative energy programs. In doing so, I believe we can avert any future tragedy and protect the delicate environmental balance of our region.

As I stated at the beginning, I raise this matter in the grievance debate today following the announcement that the Prime Minister is going to visit Indonesia. On behalf of the people of Australia, I hope that this is one topic he will at least raise with the Indonesian ministers and the government. If he cannot do it himself, he should arrange to have bipartisan meetings not only expressing our concern but also, as I said earlier in my speech today, offering our expertise to assist them.

I still believe deep down that if they were to go ahead and build these reactors in those areas which have been recognised as experiencing regular fault activity it is our country in the future that will suffer. I do not believe we can be ostriches, put our heads in the sand and say, `It is too late. It has happened now. No‐one brought it to our attention.' That is why I have risen to speak in the grievance debate today. People are far more expert than me—I can do it only from what research is available from the library, from what I have been able to read and also from the concerns expressed by many people over these particular activities that are going to be designed to overcome the energy problems of our near neighbour.

I believe our population at the top end of Australia is closer to Indonesia and will suffer more effects if something were to happen than either Sydney or Melbourne or perhaps Western Australia. The very top end of our nation needs to be protected, as does all of Australia. I am particularly concerned with the basin that we represent. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dondas, Nick, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise in the grievance debate today probably having the most significant grievance of them all—the fact that the Northern Territory has waited some 85 years for the north‐south railway to be constructed. It has been 85 years since a promise was made by the then government that a rail link would be constructed. It is only now with the Howard coalition that the railway looks like being a possibility.

SPEECH.PARA: Many years ago Darwin was always considered to be the gateway from Europe into Australia. Today I believe that the Territory is Australia's gateway to Asia. The Northern Territory is spearheading Australia's link with new growth areas of Asia and it offers companies in the rest of Australia the opportunity to use Darwin as a point from which to foray into the Asia‐Pacific region.

As a product of both its history and location, the Territory is strongly focused on the region. The Territory has representative offices in Jakarta, Hong Kong, Singapore, Beijing and Shanghai to assist exporters and identify business opportunities. The Territory Minister for Asian Relations, Trade and Industry, Eric Poole, regularly leads delegations of Territory and interstate businesses to Asia where the government endorsement gives added credence to exporters and enables greater access to business and government leaders. The Territory also regularly participates in trade related expositions.

The major trade exposition the Territory supports is NT Expo, which will be held in Darwin next month from 25 to 30 June. NT Expo has grown to be one of the premier national and international trade initiatives of Australia. More than 700 international delegates from countries, including China, Hong Kong, Indonesia, Brunei, Malaysia, Vietnam, Philippines, Macau, Papua New Guinea, Singapore, Pakistan and New Zealand, are expected this year, as well as business people from throughout Australia.

Key drawcards include a series of conferences in mining, construction, agribusiness, tourism and transport links. There will also be business matching sessions and a range of seminars which will be held in conjunction with the Expo. The first meeting of Australia's trade ministers under the new coalition government will also be held in Darwin during NT Expo 1996.

NT Expo has grown to be one of the largest business gatherings in Australia and South‐East Asia out of which millions of dollars worth of business is written. It is also a vivid illustration of the successful blend of western and Asian business practices for which the Territory has become well known.

In the 1990s, the Territory has concentrated on forming strong alliances in business, trade, government, culture and sport with our northern neighbours. We have focused on the regions closest to us both in proximity and in its relatively youthful stage of development. The new growth areas in Asia are BIMP and EAGA. For those who do not know, BIMP and EAGA incorporate the country of Brunei, some of the eastern provinces of Indonesia, east Malaysia including Labuan, and the southern Philippines. EAGA stands for east ASEAN growth area.

As with the Territory, the region is one of enormous potential. It has a market base of some 40 million customers of growing prosperity, relatively cheap and abundant land covering almost 700,000 square kilometres, major mineral, petroleum and natural gas deposits, rich marine resources and enormous tourism potential.

The first formal mark of recognition of the Territory's efforts in this area came in 1992 when the Territory government signed a memorandum of understanding with Indonesia. It was the first and only time that a government of Indonesia had signed such a memorandum with a state or territory in preference to a national government.

I am very pleased to advise that I was at the signing of that MOU. The MOU calls for involvement between the Northern Territory and the 10 eastern provinces of Indonesia to develop manufacturing and processing industries, trade and infrastructure. It also calls for the joint development of a range of other areas including professional services, transport, technology transfer, tourism and primary industries. A joint policy committee with representatives from both countries was set up to cut red tape and to facilitate business ventures and cross‐investment.

While business and trade with the region have steadily grown, the Territory has continued to forge relationships with EAGA. In November 1994, while a Territory delegation attended the first Asian business convention in Mindanao, the Territory was invited to participate in BIMP and EAGA. There are now in place formal agreements with almost all members of EAGA, building on the 1991 MOU with Indonesia. Pacts have been signed with the governments of the Philippines and Brunei. Agreements relating to Sabah, Sarawak and Labuan are expected to be signed this year. The Territory's Minister for Asian Relations, the Hon. Eric Poole, will sign a memorandum of intent with Labuan tomorrow, Tuesday, 28 May.

These agreements have put a high degree of certainty into commerce between our countries and are being used for a variety of Territory and national companies. In the five-year period since the Territory began focusing its efforts into EAGA, the value of two-way trade, excluding mineral fuels, has increased from $30 million to more than $130 million. In fact, trade with the BIMP countries is already $122.8 million for the financial year to March, compared with the $120.5 million for the whole of the last financial year.

This spectacular growth seems set to continue. In fact, the Territory's exports to the BIMP countries are likely to top $170 million. Overall, this is a $50 million or 40 per cent increase in exports. Indonesia is at the top of the export list, now worth $65.2 million, followed by the Philippines at $42.5 million, Malaysia at $9.8 million and Brunei at $5.3 million.

The main export continues to be live cattle, with a value last year of $101.8 million compared to $113.5 million for the whole of 1994-95 and $69.3 million for 1993-94. The other significant export area is transport equipment, with $9.1 million exported principally to Indonesia in the year to March, compared to $2.7 million for all of 1994-95.

Imports from the BIMP region are also on the rise, which further emphasises the Territory's success in trading with the region. It reflects the growing commerce and the effective transport links between the BIMP countries and the Territory. I can give an illustration of the growth in transport and telecommunications access to South-East Asia that has occurred in recent years in order to meet the growing demands of business.

In 1990, the Territory had one shipping company operating an international shipping service to Singapore and some ports in Indonesia without any regular connections to the eastern seaboard of Australia. In November 1992, the government introduced a subsidy which saw Darwin based Perkins Shipping introduce a regular shipping service to Ujung Pandang, which proved to be a vital stimulant to the development of regular shipping links into the region. Today the subsidy has been dropped and services run on purely commercial lines.

In 1996, 12 regular shipping services operated throughout the Territory providing Australia's most comprehensive shipping services to Indonesia. They also provided regular connections between the Territory and Singapore and Christmas Island; Port Moresby and Lae in Papua New Guinea; Port Kelang, Kota Kinabalu and Sandakan in Malaysia; General Santos City and Cagayan De Oro in the Philippines; Yokahama and Kobe in Japan; Rotterdam, Hamburg and Hull in Europe; and a number of other ports on the eastern and western coasts of Australia, as well as on-inducement services throughout Asia.

An additional shipping service running between Brisbane, Cairns, Darwin, Bali, Jakarta and Singapore begins operating in August this year. This luxury cruise liner will have the capacity to carry up to 300 passengers as well as 220 containers, including 96 refrigerated containers.

BREAK.PARA: In response to booming demand, international air services have also been expanded. In 1994-95, Darwin airport recorded the highest growth in international and domestic passenger traffic of all FAC airports in Australia. During the same period, visitor numbers to the Territory topped one million for the first time, up almost 200,000 since 1990-91. Compared to 1990, when nine international outbound air services operated each week, in 1996 there are 20 outbound and 21 inbound flights each week. These directly connect the Territory with Brunei, Ambon, Denpasar, Singapore, Kuala Lumpur, Kupang and Japan. More direct air links are being introduced and Qantas has recently announced an additional service to Singapore from July this year. A direct air service between Darwin and Davao City, on the southern Philippine island of Mindanao in the EAGA, is also likely to be introduced in the next 12 months.

Supporting these far reaching transport services are advanced infrastructure and telecommunications facilities. Darwin's new international airport opened in December 1991. The airport has 24-hour operation with no restriction on aircraft movement. Darwin's new $75 million port will be operational in 1997. The port will be equipped with world-class technology and will be largely automated. It will be able to handle live cattle, bulk and general cargo and will complement the existing container centre at Stokes Hill. Ultimately, the new deep water port will be capable of other commercial uses such as oil rig tendering, ship repair and extended bulk loading. Not far from the port in the trade development zone, the Territory government has spent some $800,000—(Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mossfield, Frank, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I grieve for the future of one of a number of successful labour market programs that have operated in both the Blacktown local government area and the electorate of Greenway over the last three years. The particular program I refer to is the Blacktown regional economic and employment development task force, the BREED Task Force, funded under the Office of Labour Market Adjustment during the term of the previous Labor government. I believe the benefit of this task force to the local community has been the successful completion of a number of projects that will help to make the region of western Sydney a better place to invest and work.

SPEECH.PARA: In this brief address I would like to quickly report on a number of these projects that were mentioned in the 1995 annual report of BREED. The first project I would like to refer to is the adult literacy and numeracy coordinator. The need to introduce an adult literacy and numeracy program to improve the employment skills of workers at risk was identified in an earlier BREED project. This is an area in which Minister Kemp has attempted to portray the previous Labor government as having done nothing—a claim that is totally and absolutely false. I am sure many groups such as BREED would be greatly offended by the comments of Minister Kemp, which were not only false but gratuitous and unhelpful.

A coordinator was employed for a period of 12 months to, among other things, develop a range of strategies for raising awareness of literacy and numeracy such as developing networks of literacy and numeracy and employment skilled programs using established programs where possible and organising and coordinating consultative forums consisting of providers, employers and peak bodies in the field of literacy, numeracy and employment skills to provide an ongoing dissemination and sharing of information.

One of the outcomes of this project was the production of a monthly newsletter which covers all areas relating to literacy and numeracy. This newsletter and the coordinator have acted as a catalyst for the various groups delivering literacy and numeracy services in our area.

Another program I would like to refer to is the training needs analysis. The aim of this project was to identify the training needs of major industries within the region and to evaluate these needs and to assess the availability of training infrastructure. The report highlighted that a major impediment to economic growth in this region was the inability of the local work force to share in the benefits of development because of the skill gap that existed between the growing demands of industry and the skills of the local work force.

A number of critical trends were identified which would make it more difficult for less skilled workers and managers to get access to and maintain good jobs. These trends included the need for a higher level of education and training and to continually upgrade skills to adapt to new technology and product requirements, greater emphasis on team work and communication skills to enable individuals and teams to focus on improving enterprise productivity and meeting customer demands, and efforts by firms to support and reward their core work force by providing them with some career paths and financial incentives to stay with the firm to reduce turnover.

The final report, which contained 21 recommendations, was launched by the very respected and prominent businessman Mr Bill McNamara OAM, Chairman of the Greater Western Sydney Economic Development Board, at the University of Western Sydney, Nirimba campus. The launch consisted of a summary of the findings by the consultants and a detailed workshop consisting of representatives from 50 industries and training organisations. The final report refers to the critical training needs of local industry as being in the areas of quality related training, computer software, team work, safety, sales and marketing.

It also recommended that there is a need to more closely study the training needs of major firms in the region, to assess the skill base in the region and education and training infrastructure, and to identify ways to more closely link industries with local education and training institutions such as high schools, TAFE colleges and the University of Western Sydney.

Another project that I would like to refer to is the small business incubator. A feasibility study has been carried out to ascertain the commercial viability of a small business incubator to assist small business to become economically viable. It is apparent that there is a high demand for a small business incubator in our region.

BREAK.PARA: I am pleased to report that, at this period, negotiations are being carried out for the refurbishment of two buildings in the Nirimba College of TAFE for this purpose. I would encourage the current government to ensure that appropriate funds are available to enable the establishment of this small business incentive for Greenway.

Another project I will refer to is the economic development strategy. This project has produced an excellent document, particularly for new investors in the area, as it gives a detailed background of the population mix, skills of the work force, industries already established in the region, training and education facilities available and regional rail and road links. Details were also provided on major industry groupings in the Blacktown local government area.

This report also shows that Blacktown industrial estates are strategically located along major transport corridors, east-west and north‐south. It also shows that rail passes near to the Seven Hills, Kings Park and Riverstone industrial estates. Reference is also made in the report that Blacktown has a large diverse economic base across manufacturing industries, agriculture and tourism. Its industrial base contains some of the largest manufacturing and distribution corporations in Australia marketing their products nationally and internationally. These include Sharp, Sony, Pepsi, BHP, Transfield, Westbus, United Distillers, P&O Cold Storage, Atlas Copco, Lidco, Trane and Davis Holdings.

Another project that I will mention briefly was the West Jobs campaign. The BREED coordinator, Steve Frost, took part in the very successful West Jobs campaign. This campaign was run by the Outer Western Sydney and Central Western Area Consultative Committee. Its aim was to find 4,000 positions in a period of three months. It was overwhelmingly successful due to the support of small business and, in fact, 7,500 positions were created during that period.

It is always difficult to measure the success of labour market programs, but I believe the calibre of the people on the task force, the number of ongoing BREED projects, and the networking between task force members and other regional bodies, both state and federal, will contribute to increased employment opportunities.
The BREED Task Force has always been able to attract high quality people, and I seek leave to table a list of members who have served on the task force over the past three years.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would particularly like to refer to the support that the task force has received from small business and through the contributions of John Allen, the first Project Coordinator of BREED and also the current President of the Blacktown City Chamber of Commerce and Industry, and the Acting Chairperson of BREED, Miss Beverly Norton, who is the Executive Director of the Blacktown City Chamber of Commerce. The outstanding input that they have been able to make on behalf of small business has been vital in developing projects that will increase employment growth in small business.

BREAK.PARA: I should mention that all task force members gave their time freely and that no attendance fees or out‐of‐pocket expenses were paid to task force members. As a former chairman of BREED, I thank the task force members and their employers for their generous contribution to the work of the BREED task force. I urge the government not to add this type of important community based group to their forthcoming budgetary slash and burn proposals.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vaile, Mark, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —This evening in the grievance debate I bring to the attention of the House a couple of unrelated but very important issues affecting my electorate of Lyne. The first issue concerns the inadequate number of nursing home beds available in my electorate. Mr Deputy Speaker, you would no doubt agree that there is an inadequate number of nursing home beds in your electorate, just as there is right up and down the New South Wales coast. In the last two years a strange anomaly occurred in the distribution of the allocated nursing home beds in New South Wales. On 1 July 1994 the chairman of the board of directors of the Lower North Coast Area Health Service wrote to me on behalf of his organisation and the broader community generally. He stated:

SPEECH.PARA: Our Board of Directors are concerned with the shortfall of nursing home and hostel beds in our local District when compared to the Commonwealth Department of Health formula.

The attached table will show that at this stage we are 45 nursing beds short, according to the Commonwealth formula, and 164 hostel beds short. It should be noted that in relation to this last figure, account has not been taken of the proposed 60 bed hostel at Forster.

That 60‐bed hostel was subsequently built by Baptist Community Services. In July 1994, the Commonwealth Department of Human Services and Health advertised that recurrent funding was available for the provision of new and additional hostel, nursing home and community care services. Target areas published included a nursing home priority for the Great Lakes area. The advertisement indicated that there was a need for an allocation of 30 nursing home beds in the Great Lakes area.

Two organisations that had established infrastructure in the Great Lakes area in my electorate applied to provide the 30 nursing home beds. The first was the Great Lakes Aged and Invalid Care Association Ltd, a community based organisation. That organisation runs Glacier House, predominantly a hostel, which has been established for a number of years. I think it was first established in 1981. In 1983 it was granted 40 hostel beds and since then it has grown, with the addition of a 10‐bed dementia care wing. That organisation had secured land adjacent to its establishment for the accommodation of the additional nursing home beds if granted.

The other organisation in the Great Lakes area that had established infrastructure was the Baptist Community Services Organisation. It has a brand new hostel called Kularoo Gardens, which is bigger than Glaica, and which also had the facilities and infrastructure to accommodate the nursing home beds that the Commonwealth Department of Health advertised for. The closing date for applications came and went. I supported both applications because, if the department had been of a mind to allocate the nursing home beds to either of those organisations, it would have been a welcome addition to the services provided in the area.

To the surprise of the entire community, 20 beds only were allocated to a company based in Inverell which had no infrastructure in the Great Lakes area. That seemed extremely strange to us. We had great problems in trying to find out what decision making process took place. We subsequently found out that the Inverell company tried to relocate those nursing home beds to Coffs Harbour. I note that that is in your electorate, Mr Deputy Speaker. When approval for that reallocation was not forthcoming from the department, I understand that the 20 nursing home beds went back into the pool in the department. It has been almost two years since the advertisement for 30 nursing home beds in the Great Lakes area first appeared. Not one brick has been laid towards the implementation and establishment of the 30 nursing home beds in Forster.

I wrote to the former minister for health and received no response. I have now written to the current Minister for Health and Family Services (Dr Wooldridge) to try to ascertain what went on within the department, what possessed the department to allocate those beds to a company based in Inverell that had no infrastructure in the region in which those beds were to be allocated. The beds have gone back into the system and the people in the Great Lakes area, where we are desperately short of nursing home beds, have completely missed out. This is a matter of grave concern in an area where we have a high retired population and an increasing need for nursing home beds.

The other issue I wanted to raise in the grievance debate this evening is that of petrol prices. My electorate of Lyne on the mid‐ north coast of New South Wales is between 300 and 400 kilometres north of Sydney, which is the main distribution point for motor spirit. The majority of motor spirit is transported into the area by road freight, not by rail. Unfortunately, the minister responsible, the Minister for Science and Technology (Mr McGauran), who was in the chamber five or 10 minutes ago, is no longer here. I have raised the issue with him. I know that an ACCC inquiry is being undertaken at the moment. I want to highlight this evening some of the inequities that exist in the system.

Last week, I got from the Australian Competition and Consumer Commission, which I presume is the follow‐on from the Prices Surveillance Authority, an interesting paper on the intervention pricing system and how they establish that intervention price. I went through that paper and found that during the month of May, with some minor variations, the intervention price has been running at 66.62c per litre for motor spirit.

That is all well and good. Those intervention prices are across all the majors—Ampol, BP, Caltex, Mobil and Shell. Ampol and Shell were both supposedly running maximum wholesale prices of 66.62c per litre. I spoke to a couple of resellers in Port Macquarie, where we have seen the retail price of unleaded fuel running at about 80c a litre. I asked them what their wholesale price has been during the month of May. After you deduct the freight differential, which is established by the former Prices Surveillance Authority, we found that during the month of May the wholesale prices that they were paying for motor spirit into Port Macquarie ranged from between 71.77c per litre to 72.31c per litre. That is a fair bit higher than the established intervention price set by the Prices Surveillance Authority of 66.62c per litre. So there was a strange anomaly there during that period.

The Prices Surveillance Authority is supposed to be setting a maximum wholesale price, to which is added the freight differential, which we know is much greater in country areas than it is in the city. In the city it is zero. Into Port Macquarie it is 3.8c per litre. Anybody who runs a transport business that could get hold of that sort of freight component would be smiling with glee. If you work it out over a 40,000‐litre load of fuel, it takes a lot of money to drag a semitrailer load of fuel from Sydney to Port Macquarie. That is one of the areas which, hopefully, the government will address in trying to create a bit of transparency in the petroleum industry.

As I said earlier, the ACCC is running an inquiry into the disparity between country and city prices of fuel at the moment. I urge the minister responsible to suggest to the ACCC that it should also look at LPG prices. At the end of last week a constituent of mine contacted me regarding LPG prices across New South Wales. There is a larger disparity between city and country prices. Mr McGee rang me. He had just bought a new vehicle that will run on LPG. He indicated that across New South Wales last week the Sydney price for LPG was 23.9c per litre, the Taree price was 36.9c per litre, the Coopernook price was 36.9c per litre, while between Port Macquarie and Coffs Harbour it was 42.9c per litre.

I acknowledge that it is not the reseller who is creaming the system. When I went back to the motor spirit price and highlighted to the House the difference in wholesale price, the reseller was paying 72.31c per litre on 6 May while the intervention price set by the PSA was 66.62c per litre.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! As the time for the grievance debate has expired, the debate is interrupted and I put the question:

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 9 May, on motion by Mr Miles:
That the bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Latham, Mark, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That all words after "That" be omitted with a view to substituting the following words:
"whilst not declining to give the Bill a second reading, the House is of the opinion that the Government has:
(1) by adopting a permanent rate of 10% beyond 1996‐97, failed to fulfil its election promise to small businesses and self‐funded retirees to reduce the provisional tax uplift factor to 6%;
(2) failed to fulfil its long‐standing promise to set the provisional tax uplift factor at rates corresponding to forecasts for inflation, income growth and economic growth; and
(3) failed to deliver a sound policy framework for small business, with:

PARA.TAB: (a) the contractionary impact of withdrawing more than 2% GDP from the income/expenditure stream in the forthcoming budget;
(b) failure to consider an even lower uplift factor in light of the Government's downward revision of the growth forecasts for 1996‐97 (3.75% to 3.25%);
(c) cuts to small business support programs such as EMDG, AusIndustry, NIES and the Innovate Australia programs;
(d) higher underlying interest rates with the abolition of wages policy; and

(e) the Government's failure to support amendments to the Trade Practices Act to strengthen the provisions concerning harsh or oppressive conduct in circumstances where a small business is vulnerable and economically captive to another enterprise".

SPEECH.PARA: I point out to the House that this taxation legislation is red hot. It is a red hot breach of a coalition election commitment. It is a breach of faith to the 800,000 small businesses and investors in Australia paying provisional tax. What this government is trying to do with this legislation is to say to those 800,000 Australians that its election promise to reduce the uplift factor for provisional tax was for 1996-97 alone. They are trying to say through this legislation that it was a promise with a sunset. As the sun sets on 30 June 1997, all bets will be off.

What the government is proposing to do with this legislation is to introduce an uplift factor of six per cent for 1996-97 alone. When you look at the fine print of the legislation, the fine print that the Parliamentary Secretary (Cabinet) to the Prime Minister (Mr Miles) would not mention in his second reading speech, the rate goes back up to 10 per cent.

TALK.START.PARA: —He's diddled them.

—It is up to 10 per cent for 1997-98 and they are after a permanent rate of 10 per cent. When the sun sets on 30 June 1997, all bets are off. As the member for Corio has correctly pointed out, this is a tax fiddle, a tax diddle by the Howard government and a tax con by the Treasurer, Peter Costello. The legislation provides for a six per cent rate for 1996-97, but then the 10 per cent permanent rate comes into law for 1997-98, 1998-99 and on it goes.

SPEECH.PARA: This is from a government which day in and day out complains to this House and complains to the media and complains all over the nation that they do not have control of the Senate. This government which complains that they do not have control of the Senate had the opportunity with this legislation to keep their election promise chapter and verse. They promised the 800,000 small businesses and investors around the nation that the six per cent uplift factor meant six per cent for now and six per cent for the following financial year—a six per cent permanent rate. If they do not support the amendment that the Australian Labor Party moves in this House, without their control of the Senate, they are going to entrench in law on the statute books of this nation a 10 per cent permanent rate. That is in clear breach of their very clear election promise on 2 March.

This is a massive breach of faith. This is a massive con job on small businesses and self‐funded retirees throughout the nation. When John Howard put his hand on his chest and said that there would be a six per cent uplift factor, they all thought that that promise meant a six per cent permanent rate—not a promise with the sunset, not a promise that changes on 30 June 1997, not a promise that was for one year only, but a promise that was forever. When the Prime Minister put his hand on his chest and got near his heart after a while, they thought that he was talking about six per cent for now and six per cent forever.

This is another Costello con. This is another fistful of dollars, one of the specials of the member for Bennelong, the most experienced member in this House. This is the fistful of dollars offered for the 1996 election campaign to be snatched back on 30 June 1997. It is the fistful of dollars that was offered as a $180 million benefit to small businesses and self-funded retirees which is snatched back for the fiscal year 1997-98 and becomes a $360 million penalty on those people. It is a $180 million benefit up front—the bribe, the fistful of dollars—to be snatched back thereafter to become a $360 million penalty for 1997-98.

Indeed, even Richard Evans could do the mathematics on these things. You do not need to be all that clever. You do not even need to plagiarise anyone on these sorts of issues to work out the mathematics. The mathematics indicate that there would be a $180 million benefit in the first year of this parliamentary term; a $360 million penalty for the second fiscal year, and a $360 million penalty for small businesses and self‐funded retirees in the third year. This means a net pain for small businesses and self‐funded retirees over the three years of this parliamentary term of $540 million.

This is a half billion dollar tax fraud, a tax con and penalty for any of those 800,000 small businesses and self‐funded retirees who believe in the fistful of dollars, mark two. For all those people who thought that it was an uplift factor of six per cent for evermore, they now see it snatched back and a tax penalty of over half a billion dollars applying throughout the life of this parliament.

The truth is that this was a promise made only to be broken. This was a promise by the Prime Minister and the member for Higgins (Mr Costello), now the Treasurer, which was made only to be broken. It was a promise used for a very cynical, narrow, short‐term electoral reason: to get support through bribing 800,000 small businesses and self‐funded retirees, knowing the government would snatch it back thereafter and leave those businesses substantially out of pocket.

PARA.BREAK: In fact, when you do the calculation per electorate, small businesses and self‐funded retirees in the electorates of Werriwa, Corio, Tangney, Stirling and Isaacs are all going to be on average per electorate $3.7 million worse off over the term of the Howard government because they have not legislated on their election promise. They have legislated for a six per cent uplift factor for 1996‐97 alone. They know full well as they explain day in day out that they do not control the Senate that they are trying to leave the perma nent rate at 10 per cent. This permanent rate could well remain on the statute books of this parliament for the full three years of the parliamentary term.

SPEECH.PARA: So it is a tax bribe snatched back. It is a promise made only to be broken. It is a penalty of $3.7 million per electorate for small businesses and self‐funded retirees, the groups that they said they would support. What does that mean for small businesses? The shock and horror of finding a permanent rate of uplift factor on provisional tax of 10 per cent for the out years will damage their cash flow and their investment prospects. It will damage the jobs that the Prime Minister said he would create out of the small business sector. There will be no job creation. There will be no investment or reasonable cash flow for those small businesses in the out years of this first Howard‐Costello budget when they face an uplift factor on provisional tax of 10 per cent. That 10 per cent permanent rate is shameful.

I suggest to the Attorney‐General, the member for Tangney (Mr Williams), representing the government in the chamber now, that if they meant a six per cent permanent rate in the campaign, they should support the amendment that will be moved by the Labor Party in this chamber to say that the promise meant six per cent for now and forever.

We will be moving an amendment in this debate to entrench the promise of a six per cent permanent rate in order to keep these people honest. Only the Labor Party is trying to keep honest these people who brought you the charter of airport dishonesty, and who have broken election promises hand over fist. We will do that in this House of Representatives and, hopefully, with the support of the minor parties, we will keep them honest in the Senate, too. If they defeat that amendment, it means that they did not want a permanent rate of six per cent, that they really mean 10 per cent.

So when John Howard put his hand on his chest and tried to find his heart and swore on the Bible to all those small businesses and self‐funded retirees throughout the nation that he was going to bring the uplift factor to six per cent, they will know that he was not telling the truth. They will know that it is nothing more than a con; another fistful of dollars and a tax fraud on the people of Australia by this Howard‐Fischer government. It is nothing more than plain greed, an outright breach of faith, a tax lie from the last election campaign that we are nailing in this parliament tonight. We are nailing these people down to the true nature of their election commitment.

Let us have a look at the wording, chapter and verse, of that particular election commitment. When John Howard and Mr Costello and all those Liberal and National Party candidates throughout the country had their hands on their hearts, these are the things that were on the public and the parliamentary record prior to the last election. It started when the member for Pearce (Mrs Moylan), then the shadow minister for small business, was on the Meet the Press program on 24 September 1995. She said:
We will improve the provisional uplift factor. In fact, we put an amendment to the House just recently to reduce it to six per cent.

There was no sunset clause and no one‐year qualification. It was six per cent, full stop. There was no talk about the 10 per cent permanent rate for the out years when Mrs Moylan spoke to the Meet the Press program in September of last year. Then with the election campaign approaching, the Prime Minister, then—and still, of course—the member for Bennelong, appeared on the Sunday program on 28 January and he said to Laurie Oakes:
In addition I am going to reduce the provisional tax uplift factor which affects small business.
He said that the current rate was eight per cent. He continued:
We are going to reduce it to a more realistic figure. We have in mind a figure of about six per cent.

That was not six per cent for one year only with a sunset clause but six per cent, full stop. That was the member for Bennelong's solemn promise to the Australian people. That was his promise to the 800,000 small businesses and self‐funded retirees in this country who are paying provisional tax.

Then of course as we progressed further into the election campaign—indeed, the very next day—the shadow Treasurer, the member for Higgins, appeared on the AM program speaking to Fran Kelly. He pointed out that the uplift factor needed to be reduced. He said that he would set a proper rate, stating that it would be:
A proper rate at some kind of average that you would expect incomes to go up, bearing in mind economic growth and the CPI.
So his commitment was not to mention the six per cent but to say that they had a policy structure for guiding the uplift factor. It would be linked to the rate of inflation and the rate of growth.

Is the Treasurer now saying in this legislation that he is expecting a permanent rate of inflation in Australia of 10 per cent? That is the way he has set the uplift factor. On 2 March the policy structure and policy approach goes out the window; he sits down with the Treasury officials and tries to work out a way in which they can convert this promise into a tax bribe snatched back from the hands of small businesses and self‐funded retirees. They have been nailed down, not least of all in their own document A new deal for small business policy released on 18 February, on the day of the member for Bennelong's policy speech. What the coalition said very clearly in black and white in that small business policy circulated across the nation was, `Reduce the provisional uplift factor from eight per cent to six per cent.' Not six per cent for one year only, not six per cent as a one‐off, but six per cent—full stop. In the detail of their election policy they had this to say:

Under a Liberal‐National coalition government the provisional tax uplift factor will be reduced by 2 per cent to 6 per cent which is more in line with nominal growth in the economy. This measure will have a one‐off cost of $180 million.

Again, six per cent—full stop. Not six per cent with a qualification, not six per cent with a get‐out clause to say that it is for one year only and a permanent rate. You cannot find a 10 per cent figure in these documents.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a diddle.

—It is a diddle. It is a regular con job on the people of this country who pay provisional tax. People now know that it was nothing more than a bribe, nothing more than an enticement that the coalition would snatch back once the election had been cleared, and of course that is exactly what this government is trying to do in this piece of legislation. The truth is, quite shamefully, in the substance of the debate on these tax bills that the coalition does not want the Australian people to know about the permanent rate of 10 per cent. The government does not want small businesses and self-funded retirees throughout the country to know about its tax swindle.

SPEECH.PARA: You can judge that from the second reading speech of the Parliamentary Secretary (Cabinet) to the Prime Minister, the member for Braddon (Mr Miles). He gave a two‐minute speech. He had 30 minutes at his disposal and he did not mention the 10 per cent permanent rate which is in this legislation. Quite appropriately for the member for Braddon, he was praying no-one would notice. He might even have listed the item for the Lyons Forum, praying at breakfast that nobody would notice that the 10 per cent permanent rate is in the fine print of the legislation.

So in the second reading speech of the parliamentary secretary—a 30‐minute opportunity to explain to the people of Australia all the provisions of this legislation—he gives a two‐minute speech and does not mention the most important and lasting impact of this legislation: a 10 per cent permanent rate on uplift factor for the assessment of provisional tax.

It gets worse because the Assistant Treasurer, Senator Short, in another place, issued a press release on 8 May, and again he did not mention the 10 per cent permanent rate. It is not in the second reading speech in this place and it is not in the minister's press release. It reminds me of an episode of Fawlty Towers where they said, `Don't mention the war!' For the coalition it is, `Don't mention the permanent rate in your press release. Don't mention the permanent rate in debate in this place. Let's hope that nobody noticed.'

The good news for small business and for self‐funded retirees throughout the country is that the Labor Party has noticed and we are going to keep these people honest. We are going to keep them, chapter and verse, to their election promise, that is, six per cent rate—full stop. That will be the effect of our amendment at the consideration in detail stage.

In my second reading amendment I have made a few points about the impact of this government's policy for small business—not just the tax con, not just the broken promise and not just the tax fraud that is implicit in this legislation but across the board. Led by the member for Bennelong, this party said that it would do everything for small business. If you listened closely to John Howard's rhetoric throughout the campaign, by now, almost three months after the election, every small business in Australia should be a medium sized business, such was the extent to which the coalition built up expectations.

What has been the truth, the substance, of this government's record for small business? On the fiscal side, the demand side of the economy, it is withdrawing two per cent of GDP from the income expenditure stream. Their fiscal position is to say to every electorate in the country and to every small business that there will be two per cent GDP withdrawn from the income expenditure stream, which will contract the Australian economy. For all those businesses which rely on spending power in Main Street Australia, particularly businesses in the regions—Geelong, the north of Queensland, the west of Sydney—that rely on spending power, this government is winding it back. This government will make it much harder for small business to turn a dollar, reducing their cash flow by the permanent rate in this legislation—10 per cent on the uplift factor—and reducing spending power in Main Street Australia by two per cent GDP as a result of their ill‐timed and ill‐thought‐out budgetary policies.

Further, my second reading amendment makes the very valid point that since the election this government has wound back its growth forecast. Shortly after the election the Treasurer said that the 1996‐97 growth forecast was down from 3.75 per cent to 3.25 per cent. The government have revised their growth forecast downwards and believe the uplift factor should be related to the growth forecast. Shouldn't the number tonight be lower than six per cent for 1996‐97?

If they are saying that the economy is slowing faster than anticipated and if revenue flowing through small business is going to be smaller than anticipated at the time of the election campaign, they should be winding down the uplift factor by an equivalent amount. If the growth forecast is down half a per cent—we know how much weight they put on growth forecasts—then surely they should have been adjusting that election promise downwards as an act of good faith for the small businesses and self‐funded retirees around the country. The government are not doing that. They are showing bad faith and bad judgment according to the context of their election promises.

Further broken promises—winding back small business support programs such as the export market development grants scheme, the AusIndustry programs, NIES and Innovate Australia programs—are all hurting small businesses which rely on a critical mass of capital and on government business programs to give them access to information, export markets and new business opportunities. If government does not play that role, small business is strangled away in the economy by bigger business interests.

It is no surprise—in another act of bad faith and bad judgment—that this government, as we hear day in and day out from the Prime Minister at question time, is failing to support amendments to the Trade Practices Act which strengthen the provisions concerning harsh, repressive conduct in circumstances where a small business is vulnerable and economically captive to another enterprise. The former government had before the Senate, at the time of the parliament's dissolution, a very useful amendment to the Trade Practices Act to protect the interests of small business.
Mr Williams interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —The member for Tangney acknowledges that. If he thinks it is such a good amendment to the Trade Practices Act, why does he not, as Attorney-General, try to convince his Prime Minister that it needs to be resurrected in this parliament? It should be supported in the Senate. It should be a safety valve, a safety net, for small business to ward off the anti-competitive practices of much bigger business interests.

SPEECH.PARA: If this government were interested in good policy structure, in fair policy structure, for small business, it would amend the Trade Practices Act—as the member for Tangney has acknowledged. It would support the small business support programs that I have mentioned; it would lower its uplift factor, given that the economy on the forecast of the Treasurer has slowed; and it would not be creating the harm and damage caused by withdrawing two per cent GDP from the income expenditure stream in the forthcoming budget.

Not only has the government created pain and no gain for small business but also the government has made the fundamental mistake of abolishing wages policy. Without security on wage outcomes, the monetary authorities—the Reserve Bank of Australia—with their forward-looking monetary policy, need to take out insurance against what they do not know on wage movements. That insurance is earlier and higher interest rate movements.

If there had been a wages policy in place, Australia would by now have had an interest rate cut of at least half a per cent. That has been acknowledged by the commentators and the independent forecasters in the market. If the monetary authorities—the Reserve Bank of Australia—had security on their forward-looking monetary policy measured against wage outcomes, if they had an accord mechanism in place, they would have had the security to lower interest rates at the bottom end of the business cycle, to the lasting benefit of home buyers, small businesses and, indeed, all parts of the Australian economy.

This government has abolished wages policy. They have torn away the Reserve Bank's security blanket. They have torn away the prospect of forward-looking monetary policy being measured against security on wages policy. They have denied every single small business in this country an interest rate cut. That is what they have done by ripping up wages policy on 2 March. It is a shameful thing.

BREAK.PARA: I could not imagine a government that was serious about helping all those small enterprises throughout the nation doing things which are more contrary to the interests of those enterprises. On this legislation, wages policy, interest rates, amendments to the Trade Practices Act, the abolition of small business programs and the impact of its budget, this Howard-Fischer government has created the situation of all pain and no gain for small business. It is a terrible thing.

On the uplift factor provisions of the legislation, the member for Higgins tried very hard to put in place, when in opposition, a policy structure. Why is he not in the chamber tonight defending that policy structure, trying to help small business and trying to do the decent thing on this legislation? Let me quote from a speech he made in this place on 8 June 1995. He said:

The coalition believes that the uplift factor should be set at a realistic level which is more consistent with expected rates of income growth and inflation. Headline inflation for the year to March is 3.9 per cent. Why then assume that an average income for a provisional taxpayer will rise by eight per cent?
It is not a bad question. We are asking it tonight: if the inflation forecast for 1996-97 is around three per cent, then why is the uplift factor set at six per cent?

For the out years, on the permanent uplift factor rate, it gets much worse. Can we judge, from the comments of the member for Higgins, that he is expecting an inflation rate of 10 per cent two years from now and that that is how he has decided on the rate of the permanent uplift factor that stands in this legislation?

The Treasurer is not known for his deep contributions to the economic debate in Australia. I cannot think of a single issue relating to these considerations to which he has added value. My mother always told me that you can judge someone by their friends. I notice that his good friend Michael Kroger had to defend him in the Bulletin by saying that he would be good at Treasury because he won the tax prize at Monash University. If we put all our university prizes on the table, he would not get anywhere near the Treasurer's job in this country. I hazard a guess that it was a tax prize for tax fraud, a prize for tax con, that he won at Monash.

The evidence of his first piece of tax legislation before this parliament suggests that it is all a con. It is all fraud, a tax grab, a piece of fiscal greed, a genuine con job on all those small businesses and self-funded retirees around the nation. He had the policy structure in place. I do not know who writes the speeches of the member for Higgins, I do not know who puts the material before him, but he had the policy structure in place—you set the uplift factor according to the headline inflation forecast. I can call on no less of an authority than Access Economics in respect of this area. They are well known to the coalition. What did they say in their recent five-year business forecast?

They said that the projected increase in CPI for 1997-98 is 3.3 per cent. Why, then, have a permanent uplift factor of 10 per cent? For 1998-99, it said 4.6 per cent. Again, the permanent rate is at 10 per cent, more than twice the forecast of Access Economics. For 1999‐2000, it said 3.9 per cent. Again, the permanent rate that Peter Costello has put in this parliament is at 10 per cent—well over double the amount.

This is totally different from what the Treasurer told the people of Australia before 2 March. Take the Access Economics forecast for nominal GDP, which is perhaps a more accurate measure—I will wear that as an opposition policy structure at this time. You take the nominal GDP, which is the real GDP plus the inflation rate, and use that as your projected most suitable uplift factor rate in legislation such as this.

What does it say for 1997-98? It says 7.1 per cent; for the following year, 8.3 per cent; for the year after that, 6.8 per cent. It is not within cooee of the 10 per cent that sits in this legislation.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Ten Per Cent.

—As the member for Corio accurately points out, the Treasurer is Mr Ten Per Cent. All those small business and self-funded retirees listening to this debate and reading the Hansard subsequently should mark down the Commonwealth Treasurer, the member for Higgins, as Mr Ten Per Cent.

BREAK.PARA: He wants to hurt them later on. He wants to hurt them in the out years, to reduce their cash flow, to reduce their investment, to reduce their employment generation with this permanent rate of 10 per cent. It is wrong. It is plain wrong. It should not be happening.

I say again to the government: if you were serious in the election campaign about a six per cent rate full stop—that is, six per cent for now, six per cent forever—if that was your promise, if that is what you really meant, and it certainly sounded like you really meant it, we were all going to come here and legislate a six per cent permanent rate. If they are the things you really meant, if that is what you tried to declare to small businesses across Australia, you should be supporting the Labor Party's amendment this evening.

You should be supporting our amendment in the consideration in detail stage to legislate a six per cent permanent rate. There is nothing wrong with that because no less an authority than the member for Higgins said, `That's your policy structure. Try to work out your inflation rate, your growth forecasts and cobble together an uplift factor that meets those particular forecasts.'

I have some very interesting figures from Treasury that I will be citing to the House in the consideration in detail stage. I say to the member for Higgins, who is probably hiding away in his office right now listening to this debate and trying to work out how six per cent became 10 per cent, trying to work out how he can wiggle his way out of this tax fraud on the Australian people, `Come to the House and explain in the consideration in detail stage how six per cent became 10 per cent on the permanent rate.' He should come and explain how he has within his hands, right there in his briefing folder, Treasury forecasts that tell him without any doubt whatsoever that the uplift factor should be much closer to six per cent than to 10 per cent on the permanent rate.

He is probably looking up all those Monash University notes. He is probably trying to work out how he could possibly get out of this one. He has been nabbed. He has been caught red‐handed. If he did win that prize at Monash for good tax law, he would know better than anyone the extent of this fraud.

I particularly invite the member for Stirling (Mr Eoin Cameron) to join with the Labor Party in supporting the amendment. You must know this is wrong. You do know it is wrong. You know it is wrong. The Treasurer knows it is wrong. It is a deliberate broken promise. It is a fistful of dollars being used only to be snatched back after the election. Every member in this House should support the amendment that I have moved on the second reading debate, which is of greatest relevance and greatest importance to those 800,000 small businesses and self-funded retirees around Australia. If you are truly honest, if you truly care about small business, support our amendment.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the amendment seconded?
—It is with great pleasure that I second the amendment moved by the honourable member for Werriwa.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cameron, Eoin, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for Werriwa (Mr Latham) for his very gracious invitation, which I sadly have to decline. I will speak only very briefly on the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 1) 1996, so the member for Isaacs (Mr Wilton) might like to not leave the chamber. I will only be a couple of minutes.

SPEECH.PARA: It is wonderful to have campaigned advocating a set of policies and to now see them being implemented. One of the disappointing aspects of the 1993 election was to have advocated a policy package while the then government had no idea as to what they would have done if they won and then to see the then government win the election and run government on an ad hoc basis while we had a plan ready and waiting.

It is a refreshing change, therefore, to speak on a piece of legislation which is delivering on an election promise. In the three years I have been in this place it was common for the then government to put up legislation which completely repudiated what they had promised at the election previously. The coalition will not take the Australian people for granted as Labor did.

This legislation amends the Income Tax Assessment Act to reduce the provisional tax uplift factor from eight per cent to six per cent. This was a policy announced by the coalition during the last election, and this legislation enacts that commitment. It is also a policy that was lambasted by the Labor Party at the last election.

The coalition attempted during the last term of the parliament to reduce the uplift factor from eight per cent to six per cent only to have the Labor Party oppose it. The Labor Party were being greedy. There are around 800,000 small businesses and investors who will benefit from this legislation. The change shows the coalition's recognition that the uplift factor should be set at a realistic level which is more consistent with expected rates of income growth and inflation.

The provisional tax uplift factor is essentially a method of bringing forward anticipated tax receipts. It will not save businesses money but it will affect when tax will be paid. This legislation provides an $800 million cash flow advantage to small businesses and investors—that is, $180 million that can be spent on more jobs.

The Senate Economics References Committee tabled a report last year entitled A question of balance: the tax treatment of small business, which looked at, among other things, the provisional tax uplift factor. The report said:

Almost all submissions and evidence received from the private sector, as well as one of the three submissions received from the public sector, opposed the current level of the provisional tax uplift factor, the most frequently stated reason being that the provisional tax uplift factor was far in excess of inflation.
The coalition has listened to the concerns of the business community—the engine room of our economy—and reduced the uplift factor. This is delivering on another election promise.

I am nevertheless concerned that we do not have a mandate for this legislation. Just like the promise on the partial privatisation of Telstra, we promised to reduce the provisional tax uplift factor well before the last election. However, despite announcing it before the election, the Labor Party, Democrats and Greens allege we do not have a mandate to sell one-third of Telstra. Is this an argument they will use with every piece of legislation that comes before this House?

The Labor Party have opposed the reduction of the uplift factor before. Will they oppose it again or will they only be obstructionist, jealous bullies when it suits them, irrespective of the mandate the coalition has, the harm they are inflicting on Australia's environment and the disrespect they bring to our institution of democracy?

This bill also amends the gift provision of the income tax law to allow deductions for gifts of $2 or more to various funds. I would like to take the opportunity to make an appeal on behalf of an organisation called Kidsafe WA, the Child Accident Prevention Foundation of Australia, to have membership fees paid to it to be made tax deductible.

Section 78(9) of the Income Tax Assessment Act allows a deduction to non-corporate taxpayers for contributions of money or property, subject to certain conditions, paid or given to registered political parties. The Commissioner of Taxation in determination TD 92/114 confirmed that the word `contributions' includes membership subscriptions paid to registered political parties.

Section 78(4) of the Income Tax Assessment Act, which this bill amends to include certain funds, provides a deduction for gifts to certain health, education, research and similar organisations. The act, however, does not define the word `gift', although the dictionary would suggest that a gift would not include membership fees. Therefore, notwithstanding the budget constraints caused by Beazley's $8 billion black hole, I would appeal to the government to include membership fees to such organisations as Kidsafe to be made tax deductible.

Presently the act discriminates against charities by denying its members a tax deduction for membership fees, but it allows a tax deduction for members of registered political parties for the same payment. It could be suggested that we have a conflict of interest in allowing tax deductions for membership fees to political parties but not charities. I hope this anomaly can be rectified.

Allowing membership fees to these charities to be tax deductible will assist them in attracting new members and allow the organisation to make a greater contribution to society. While it can be argued that membership fees to political parties is a legitimate deduction, charities deserve equal treatment from the taxation system for the vital and often thankless tasks they perform for the good of the society in general.

Kidsafe is involved in child accident prevention. By giving them more recognition, more incentive to attract members, they will be able to do more work on preventing child tragedies and save the community in other associated costs. I conclude by reminding the House that 10 June is the beginning of Kidsafe Week, and it would be a perfect opportunity to announce that membership fees to it and similar charities would be made tax deductible.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Wilton, Greg, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak in favour of the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 1) 1996 and the amendment proposed by the honourable member for Werriwa (Mr Latham). I congratulate him on one of his many fine contributions to the House.

SPEECH.PARA: The bill consists of three parts. The first part deals with the provisional tax uplift factor, and I will speak on that in a little more detail shortly. The second part of the bill reintroduces a measure proposed by the previous Labor government to remove a loophole affecting the taxation of buyback share arrangements. The third part of the bill is another component of the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill of 1995, proposed by the Labor government last year, to extend the deductibility for taxation purposes of donations to certain worthy charities. I say at the outset that the opposition wholeheartedly supports each of the measures proposed in part 2 and part 3 of the bill, and I shall return to speak further on them in due course.

I will return to the first part of the bill, which deals with the change to the provisional tax uplift factor. I will refer to the coalition's policy statement released on 18 February of this year. Page 21 of that fairly dubious document sets out the coalition's policies and approach to small business. Dressed up in the rhetoric of restoring the small business sector were a number of proposals for changes to the tax system to ease the burden of capital gains tax and fringe benefits tax on small business. Also included was this promise:
