We will reduce the provisional tax uplift factor from 8 per cent to 6 per cent at a oneoff cost of $180 million.

The coalition made a great play of this promise to change the tax uplift factor from eight per cent to six per cent. They said what a boon this would be for provisional taxpayers such as independent retirees and, in particular, the small business sector. Both the Treasurer (Mr Costello) and the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) stated that it was essential and a core part of the coalition's package to revitalise small business.
Prior to the launch of that policy document, the Prime Minister, at a doorstop in Oakleigh in Victoria, spelt out clearly and explicitly the coalition's policy platform in this area. He said:

Today I want to confirm that we will be legislating to vary the provisional tax uplift factor to bring it more into line with reality somewhere in the order of 6 per cent as opposed to the present 8 per cent and that is at a revenue cost of $180 million.

What is clearly implicit in both the Prime Minister's words as well as the coalition's policy document, and supported by other public comment by coalition members in the lead‐up to the last federal election, is that the reduction in the provisional tax uplift factor from eight to six per cent was to be a permanent—and I stress the word `permanent'—measure. Nowhere was there any mention of this occurring only in the 1996-97 financial year.

The coalition's position, as far as the perception it keenly fostered for itself among small business goes, was clear and unequivocal. It would be changing the provisional tax uplift factor permanently. Now we have this bill which alters the uplift factor for the 1996-97 year but makes no mention of changes to the same uplift factor in future years. Nor does it reset the default rate at a lower figure than is presently the case.
The government's attempts to fudge its position and back away from its promise are obvious from the words of the member for Braddon (Mr Miles). In his second reading speech, he said:
The bill will give effect to the coalition's election commitment to reduce the provisional tax uplift factor for the 1996-97 income year to six per cent.

This change of position must come as a great shock and a great disappointment to many small business owners and self-funded retirees who were looking forward to the government keeping one of its much touted promises.

What we have now is an attempt by the government to have it both ways on this particular promise. On the one hand, it is claiming that it has honoured its promise to provisional taxpayers to reduce the uplift factor and, on the other hand, it has found a convenient way to weasel out of its commitment by legislating the change for one year only. It then has the temerity and the cheek and the audacity to claim that this was its policy all along.
It has come to the attention of the opposition, the media and the Australian public that the coalition government is having a great deal of trouble in keeping and delivering on its election promises.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Sitting suspended from 6.30 p.m. to 8.00 p.m.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before the suspension of the sitting for dinner I was submitting to the House that the coalition was having a problem delivering on its election promises, that these were promises that were made to be broken and that it had undertaken a massive breach of faith with the Australian people. Whether through its failure to honour its commitments to ensure that the number of university places would be maintained, its commitments to maintain the refugee program and assistance to refugees, or its commitments to expand the export market development program and grants, particularly to small business, this government has made a mockery of the Prime Minister's much repeated claims that none of its promises would be broken.

SPEECH.PARA: It is a mark of this government's priorities that it trumpets its Telstra dissolution bill and workplace relations bill as two examples of keeping its promises. Both of these policies are destructive and are far from being in Australia's best interests. Yet issues of fundamental importance such as maintaining the availability of quality education are the areas where the government seems to have no qualms at all about going back on its word.

The provisional tax uplift factor looks to be the latest in a litany, a long line, of promises that the government will fail to keep, so we in the opposition have taken it upon ourselves, in a spirit of conciliation, of good government and in the interests of Australia's small business community and self‐funded retirees, to make it easier to keep this promise by proposing an amendment to set the default uplift factor at six per cent in perpetuity.

The second part of the bill before the House this evening seeks to amend the Income Tax Assessment Act as foreshadowed in the 1995‐96 budget introduced by the then Labor government in respect of share buybacks. Share buybacks occur, for example, when companies seek to reduce the number of their shares on issue by buying them and perhaps cancelling them thereafter. This activity is permissible under the current arrangements and, if proceeded with, certain tax arrangements and circumstances follow.

The amendments contained in the bill ensure that the full purchase price of a share in an off‐market share buyback is treated as what is known as disposal consideration for capital gain income tax purposes. Clearly, it is the intent of the bill to prevent exploitation of some three loopholes in regard to share buyback arrangements.

In summary, the first of these loopholes occurs when shares are bought perhaps at less than market value—where, for example, company A purchases shares at $100 per share in company B and shortly thereafter company B buys shares back at $1 each. An allowable paper loss of $99 per share is incurred by company B. The amendment basically outlaws this practice. For capital gains tax purposes, company B is deemed under the proposed arrangements to pay $100 per share realising effectively no capital loss.

The second loophole occurs when, for example, shares are purchased at $1 a share, are bought back by the seller at $3 a share, yielding a net gain of $2 a share for the shareholder. The amendments to these buyback provisions ensure that the $2 is treated as a capital gain, and a further $2 is treated as dividend. The amount that is treated as capital gain is reduced by the amount treated as dividend, effectively preventing double taxation. The third loophole which would be closed by the proposed amendments was designed to prevent rebatable dividends arising from an off‐market share buyback creating or increasing tax losses.

The final component of this bill deals with amendments to the Income Tax Assessment Act to permit tax deductibility for income tax purposes of gifts of $2 or more to a range of charities. It also extends the period of tax deductibility for certain charitable organisations which are currently tax deductible and enjoy tax deductible status. These charities include the Polly Farmer Federation, a federation dear to the heart of my colleague the member for Corio, who is in the chamber.

TALK.START.PARA: —A great player.

—A great player, indeed. The extension also applies to the Australian Games Uniform Co. Ltd and the Cobram and District War Memorial Incorporated Fund, which are, no doubt, all excellent bodies deserving the recognition and support of both the House and the public at large. I am sure that we all wish them well in their endeavours.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to say a few words about the Shrine of Remembrance in Melbourne, particularly its restoration and development trust fund to which this bill grants an extension of time for the purposes of tax deductibility. The Shrine Trust was established in 1992 to raise funds for the restoration of Melbourne's beloved Shrine of Remembrance. It was realised some years back that the waterproofing membrane under the terraces beneath the shrine had eroded allowing water to seep into the undercroft area. The beams and supporting terraces had become damaged by water and were at risk of collapse if restoration was not undertaken immediately.

The trust fund was set up and has since received overwhelming support from the Victorian government and the people of Victoria. The plight of the shrine was brought to the attention of Victorians by the considerable media coverage that this rather serious problem had attracted.

The trust raised approximately $2.7 million, half of which came from public donations, the other half from matching funds contributed by the state government. Clearly, it was a matter that touched the hearts of many Victorians. The shrine, standing in Melbourne's magnificent botanical gardens and seen from Melbourne's premier boulevard, St Kilda Road, has been for many years not only one of Melbourne's most prominent landmarks but also a fitting tribute and proud memorial to all those who gave so much for our country in the many theatres of war in which Australia has been engaged.

The money raised by the trust has been used to finance the necessary restoration work, which involved installing waterproofing and drainage under the terraces, as well as treating the damaged beams in the undercroft. Toilets and a lift were installed to improve the quality of the amenities afforded the many visitors to the shrine.

But the work of the Shrine Trust is not yet done. Another $10 million needs to be raised to fund plans already on the drawing board to develop the cavernous undercroft area and turn it into a gallery of remembrance that will serve to educate our young people about the great sacrifices and hardships endured by our military forces over the last century. It would be a vivid reminder of the sheer horror of war and I am sure that the people of Victoria will again generously support this most worthy cause.

I congratulate all those associated with the shrine on their efforts to date with the restoration program and wish them well in their future endeavours. I commend the bill, with the suggested amendment, to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: O'Connor, Gavan, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support the Taxation Laws Amendment (No. 1) Bill and the amendments that are proposed by the honourable member for Werriwa (Mr Latham). I commend him on the excellent speech he gave to the parliament earlier this evening. While the bill before the House does specifically refer to matters such as provisional tax uplift factors for small business and the rules relating to share buybacks for companies, this legislation also extends tax deductibility to organisations nominated in the legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: I seek the indulgence of the House to make some comments on one of the organisations nominated for tax deductibility in this legislation; namely, the Polly Farmer Foundation. It is appropriate that I make these comments in view of the fact that Polly Farmer played for and coached that great Australian football team in my electorate, and I refer to Geelong.

As the convener of the parliamentary Aussie Rules group in the parliament, I am sure in making these comments I reflect the sentiments of those members of the group who have an intimate knowledge and love of the game and of Polly Farmer's contribution to it. These remarks are also timely because as I speak the ball has bounced at the Geelong‐Collingwood match at the MCG this evening. If you are not doing anything after the show, slip down to the theatrette because it is on the big screen.

For those members who do not know the history of Australian rules very well, Graham `Polly' Farmer rose from humble beginnings to become a legend in his own time. Indeed, the honourable member for Werriwa, after his contribution tonight, is fast assuming that sort of status here on the field of the House. Polly Farmer is one of the greats of the greatest football code of them all—Aussie Rules.

PARA.BREAK: Separated from his mother at nine and leaving school at 14 to become a motor mechanic, Graham Farmer began his senior playing career with the East Perth Royals. As a ruckman, Polly Farmer developed his own unique style of play. When he came to Geelong in 1962 he brought with him a reputation that saw over 10,000 people turn up to his first training run with the Cats. That informa tion was supplied by another Cats legend, Nipper Trezise. Farmer played over 101 games with Geelong with the club reaching the finals each year that he played. He spearheaded the club to its premiership win over Hawthorn in 1963.

SPEECH.PARA: Very few players in this code achieve legend status in their own day. Very few players, regardless of their skill, can lay claim to achieving a paradigm shift in thinking about the way the game is played. Polly Farmer did it in the 1960s with a unique style of ruck play and handball. Farmer was more than just a tap ruckman with above average around the ground skills. He crafted a style which involves the clever use of the body to catch the ball at boundary throw‐ins and centre bounces and to feed the ball off to skilful small running players with precision handball at short and long range.

Farmer virtually revolutionised ruck play and the game with the purity of his skill. The Farmer‐Goggin combination became one of the most feared ruck and rover combinations in the old VFL. He was a drawcard in his own right like Whitten, Baldock and Barassi. He was the architect of that free flowing running style of football for which Geelong has become famous over the past three decades.

Farmer returned to Western Australia in 1968 to coach East Perth, which won the premiership in the WAFL in 1969 and 1971. He finally hung up the boots, as we say in football parlance, at the tender age of 36.

In 1994, Farmer launched the Polly Farmer Foundation with the aim of assisting Aboriginal people in developing their skills in the field of sport and education. It is this foundation which has been mentioned in this legislation here tonight. The foundation intends to assist Aboriginals through scholarships to university and sporting institutes for talented Aboriginals and through advanced coaching for sportspersons with exceptional skills.

The simple guiding principle of the foundation is that which motivated Polly Farmer in his own illustrious football career—the pursuit of excellence. The foundation has the strong support of the AFL, the Western Australian Football Commission, the East and West Perth Football Clubs and the Geelong Football Club. Graham `Polly' Farmer was a great Aboriginal footballer. In football parlance he was an ornament to the game. The foundation that now carries his name is worthy of the support of the provisions of this act and any support provided by the parliament and the public of this country.

Much has been said about the other provisions of this legislation. I support the words of the honourable member for Werriwa in his most eloquent speech to the parliament earlier on this evening. He has drawn attention to the fact that this is a government hell-bent on saying one thing to small business and doing another. When you read the fine print in this legislation, you see that the reduction in the uplift factor applies for only one year. I am referring specifically to that provision of the legislation. What John Howard did not say—good old honest John—in the context of the election campaign was, `Once 1996-97 is through, we are going to ratchet up the uplift factor to around 10 per cent.'

That measure will affect small businesses in not only my electorate but also certainly the electorates of Werriwa and Batman and all the other electorates throughout the length and breadth of Victoria. Those small businesses have already been hit by the announcements that have been made by this particular government in winding back the industry assistance measures and in the contractions that they are proposing to fiscal policy in this country.

It does not seem to have dawned on the members opposite that when the government makes an expenditure decision, invariably that decision is carried out by the private sector. One example of that is the building better cities program, which was sponsored by the former Minister for Housing and Regional Development, Brian Howe, in the previous Labor government. That program sponsored some $10 million worth of expenditures on the Deakin wool stores project, which was opened recently in Geelong.

What people do not understand is that that particular expenditure has called forth production from around Geelong. The Deakin wool stores project was designed by Geelong architects, who received payment for that. The major contractor on that was a Geelong building firm, which employed through the agency of this program some 150 people on that project alone. Over the road at the Geelong transport interchange, there was some $2 million worth of expenditure and more labour employed—more Geelong small businesses receiving the benefits of those expenditures.

I make that point because when the Treasurer (Mr Costello) and the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) talk about fiscal responsibility in this country and about cutting back on government expenditures, they need to be aware that out in the regions the people who carry these expenditures through are invariably small and medium sized firms in the private sector. They are the ones that are going to be starved by the fiscal policies of this particular government.

I had dinner tonight with some business people from here in the ACT. Boy, are they disappointed with this government. These are people who do not run large businesses, but the cutbacks are really of great concern to them. They see falls in their business, contractions in their revenue, contractions in their turnover and inevitably, at the end of the day, a contraction in staffing levels.

If you combine what is happening in the private sector with what this government is proposing in the public sector, you have a double whammy—a double hit on small and medium businesses all around this country. This was alluded to by the honourable member for Werriwa in his speech. This piece of legislation is but one of a whole range of measures designed to smack small and medium businesses right in the neck. It can have only one inevitable consequence—reduced employment levels, reduced levels of economic activity, a contraction in the Australian economy and, of course, repercussions for small business.

We need no more from King Con the Treasurer; the man who says one thing one day and then implements another thing another day. I have a few choice words for the Prime Minister which I am sure you would rule out of order, Mr Deputy Speaker. The uplift factor measure that the Prime Minister is introducing in this legislation, ratcheting it back up to 10 per cent in the out years, will come back to haunt him. He will be known forever as Dishonest John, the Prime Minister who drove the boot into small business in this country.

I commend to other members in this House the amendment that has been proposed by the honourable member for Werriwa. He eloquently stated that the fiscal policies of this government will have a damaging effect on small business. He also referred to the trade practices legislation, which is going to affect small business, and to the way in which this legislation is going to penalise small business. He made a very eloquent appeal to this House, which I reinforce here tonight.

I am often intrigued by government ministers who waddle up to the dispatch box to support the Prime Minister's concept of the black hole in the budget. I have one simple question to put to those ministers: if they regard a $4 billion deficit in 1996 as an economic disaster and they lambast the former finance minister and now the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Beazley) for that, how do they view an $8 billion deficit caused by the then Treasurer, John Howard, in 1983? You can come to only one conclusion: that particular deficit was foisted on the Australian economy by an economic imbecile. It was accompanied by double digit inflation, double digit unemployment, an economy in reverse, job shedding, and industrial disputation at an all‐time high.

The Minister for Finance (Mr Fahey) waddles up to the dispatch box and has a crack at the Leader of the Opposition for a purported deficit, but what would he say about a deficit in current terms of $24 billion and the Treasurer who incurred it? I leave you with that particular question tonight. I support the amendment that has been proposed by the honourable member for Werriwa in this debate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rocher, Allan, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 1) 1996 is an important bill for the new government because it contains the change of rate to the provisional uplift factor, an important election promise to unincorporated small business and smaller investors, and gives some inkling as to the future development of coalition taxation policy. I, along with the rest of the community and this House, I am sure, will be observing these developments very closely.

SPEECH.PARA: Having been a critic—trenchant at times—of the previous government's abysmal record in the area of taxation, I will certainly be doing what I can to hold the new government to account by those very same standards. In fact, the coalition has got a lot more to live up to. The rhetoric of oppositions has always been tempered by the move to the treasury bench, but it is hardly an excuse for backtracking.

Yet on many grounds, the coalition has a great deal to heed in the areas of tax simplification, reducing the cost of compliance, restricting the revenue hungry spread of the fringe benefits tax, applying commonsense to the provisional tax uplift factor, providing capital gains tax rollover relief, and so the list goes on. The coalition has promised much. The coalition has raised the expectations of many businesses that it will pursue with some vigour the matters to which I have just referred.

The bill deals with three matters, namely: share buybacks, deductions for gifts, and the reduction of the provisional uplift factor. The share buybacks and gift measures were introduced into the parliament late last year in the previous government's Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 5) 1995. This bill will give effect to the 1995-96 budget announcement by the Labor government that the full buyback price of a share in an off‐market share buyback is treated as consideration for ordinary income and capital gain purposes.

Relief from double taxation is provided by reducing the amount of the ordinary income gain, or capital gain, by the amount of the dividend included in assessable income or paid out of profits. If the dividend is rebatable, it will not create or increase a capital loss or an allowable deduction. A market value rule is also to apply to off‐market share buybacks. Any excess over the market value of a share, that is, a dividend, will not be frankable under these provisions. The amendments will apply to share buybacks that take place after 7.30 p.m. AEST on 9 May, unless they occur under certain transitional arrangements.

The government claims the amendments have the potential to prevent a future loss to its revenue. However, the Treasurer (Mr Costello) should not lose sight of the fact that a harmonised tax policy should not necessarily equate to a protection of the government's revenue base. The Keating government, as you probably remember, Mr Deputy Speaker, became expert at milking the small business community for every cent it could. Let that be a lesson for the new coalition government.

Surely the very reason for the existing rate of the provisional tax uplift factor needs to be revisited. Interest rates and inflationary expectations have fallen considerably since the eight per cent figure was envisaged by Labor and applied in a completely indiscriminate way then. It assumes that a provisional taxpayer's income will increase by the percentage stipulated, when in fact that income could rise or fall by an amount well outside the range of six per cent.

The historical reason for having an uplift factor, which is for the purpose of assessing provisional tax obligations, has been overlooked or well and truly superseded in the rationales of successive governments. An uplift factor to provisional tax assessments once allowed the Taxation Office merely to keep pace with inflation. In the immediate past, this parliament legislated under Labor to give the government the discretion to increase the uplift factor to as much as 12 per cent. The coalition now proposes to give it the option of increasing it to up to 10 per cent. I argued against it when Labor introduced the measure, and I remain consistent in my opposition to the government having a discretionary tax at its disposal. I will get back to that later.

PARA.BREAK: Eight per cent, six per cent or any figure in excess of the forecast rate of inflation this year amounts to nothing more than an unreasonable tax grab. The history of and logic for an uplift factor has been totally ignored. It simply becomes another way of wringing a little more out of our taxpayers in the private business sector and, in particular, the propri etors of unincorporated small businesses and small investors, including self-funded retirees.

SPEECH.PARA: As we all know, small business is the sector of our community which probably plays the most important role in creating real wealth and employment in this country. It might be arguable, but it is certainly up there in the top four. By employing 47 per cent of Australia's total work force and creating 30 per cent of the nation's wealth, small business has already demonstrated that it is the engine room for jobs growth in this country. If every small business could afford to employ just one extra person, our pool of unemployed would disappear. How many times have we heard that during the election campaign?

In terms of mitigating the effect of the uplift factor, the only available means to the taxpayer is by applying for a provisional tax variation from the Australian Taxation Office. That fails to rectify the situation because it greatly increases the exposure of taxpayers to penalties and back taxes if they should misjudge their likely income for the financial year ahead. At 15 per cent—the variation now allowed since 1992 without penalties—it is more than a bit tight. Such penalties can easily wipe out the benefits of a possible provisional tax variation. So many people are trapped into paying provisional tax and will have to recoup any overpaid tax at the end of the financial year. The ATO gets it both ways.

Any provisional tax uplift factor will inevitably be an arbitrary imposition. The only way in which the arbitrariness can be reduced is if it is kept at the lowest possible rate and if taxpayers are given a fair margin of error in calculating a provisional tax variation. The uplift factor remains a hindrance that the business community could very well do without. Given that we have it, the uplift factor should be linked to the forecast rise in the consumer price index or gross domestic product, but not both. The only problem for the government is that this makes a mockery of its six per cent figure. Average earnings have sometimes been quoted as being relevant, but there is no logical basis for that in this context.

BREAK.PARA: The revised budget estimates released by the Treasurer on 17 April this year show estimated gross domestic product growth of 3.25 per cent in 1995-96 and 3.25 per cent again the following financial year, with the figure never rising above four per cent through to 1998-99. The consumer price index growth for 1995-96 has been forecast upward from four per cent to 4.75 per cent. However, for the next three financial years CPI growth is predicted not to rise above four per cent. Incidentally, increases in average earnings over the next three years will also be around the four per cent mark, according to official forecasts.

Clearly, an uplift factor of no more than four per cent is warranted by each of the possibly relevant economic measures. If linked to average business growth, or even the CPI, the uplift factor would not be so arbitrary and it might, on the face of it, display some semblance of fairness. Small business is also negatively affected by the uncertainty and complexity of the tax laws passed under previous Labor governments. It is shameful that the private sector, especially unincorporated small business, is now to be slugged with an uplift factor of up to eight per cent before this bill passes the parliament, which was above the then current rate of inflation and exceeded the projected rate of returns on most investments.

By maintaining such an unrealistic uplift factor, the Keating government caused unnecessary cash flow problems for unincorporated small businesses, and that was that sector's reward for the part it played in creating 30 per cent of the nation's real wealth. Small business, as has been said ad nauseam, is the key to recovery of the Australian economy. It has already proven its capacity to generate jobs growth by employing 40 per cent of the national work force. Small business needs to be encouraged to continue to create wealth and consequential employment by fair and consistent tax legislation.

In reducing the provisional uplift factor to six per cent for the 1996‐97 year of income, the Treasurer is hopefully sending a message to the business community, that message being that the Howard government is committed to a review of the complicated and costly tax laws which hinder business growth. The Treasurer has a lot of ground to cover to restore the faith of the business sector in government, and unfortunately the amendments we are addressing today do not go far enough in doing just that. As I stated in June 1995, I think the Treasurer is being unduly generous to the revenue by insisting that the uplift factor should be at six per cent when we have a headline inflation rate of only four per cent. How did the Treasurer calculate his sums to arrive at the figure of six per cent when real GDP is set to increase at a rate of only 3¾ per cent for this year and for the following financial year? What rationale did the Treasurer rely on to decide on an uplift factor of six per cent when average weekly earnings are set to increase by less than four per cent for the next two years? If it has to be anything, the uplift factor should be around four per cent.

The reality is that the proposed reduction of the uplift factor by two per cent is a token gesture to the unincorporated business community and to investors such as self‐funded retirees. I say that because the financial gain to business is nominal when one considers not only the scope of the decrease but also that those who stand to gain from it are more likely to be individuals and sole traders and not the total small business community. I would like to use a quote now:
The coalition believes that the uplift factor should be set at a realistic level which is more consistent with expected rates of income growth and inflation.

TALK.START.PARA: —Who said that?

—They are not my words but those of the then Deputy Leader of the Opposition, the now Treasurer. His view then was in keeping with views voiced by the Australian Society of Certified Practising Accountants and the Economic Review Committee.

BREAK.PARA: It is therefore disturbing and confidence sapping to see the stipulation in this bill that after the 1996‐97 year of income the uplift factor could, at the whim of the government, jump to as much as 10 per cent, unless the parliament provides otherwise in the meantime, and the parliament will only be able to provide otherwise in the meantime if the measure is brought forward by the government. While the Treasurer has made reference to the parliament's right to increase the uplift factor, we must uphold the principle of no taxation without representation, and that is what this provision breaches.

To my knowledge, the uplift factor as proposed is the only area of taxation which can be increased by the government without prior debate in the parliament about the actual extent of the increase. If the parliament sanctions the right of the executive government to increase any tax without the parliament first having the opportunity to debate it, we will be allowing just another nail in the coffin of our relevance as both individual representatives and as a parliament.

I have several other concerns which relate to the bill. If the Treasurer is as confident about his and his government's ability to manage inflation and inflation rates, as he would have us believe, why is there a provision for the uplift factor to increase to 10 per cent after 1997? Is this a warning that the government expects the CPI to escalate to within the vicinity of 10 per cent sometime over the nominal term of this government, or is it merely an ambit claim?

I would also ask whether the present government is truly committed to long-term growth in small businesses. If it is, why hasn't it proposed that the uplift factor be reduced immediately to a logically arguable four per cent? As has already been pointed out, an uplift of four per cent is, after all, more in line with current projected increases in either the consumer price index or GDP.

I heard the honourable member for Werriwa (Mr Latham), amongst other things, mount his argument for an amendment to maintain the uplift factor at six per cent. I support the amendment that they propose to move at the consideration in detail stage—but, I say unequivocally, not for the reasons advanced by the honourable member for Werriwa.

The argument from the honourable gentleman went along the lines that they promised six per cent so that is what it should be forever. That is an argument which simply cannot be sustained. There is no tax rate set in this place which cannot be changed subsequently given the conditions of the day. It would be tantamount to taking the top marginal PAYE rate of 49c and saying that we will set it at 49c for a couple of years but that we would like to have the right after that to increase it to 60c if we are so of a mind. That is taxation without representation. It leaves with the executive government the right to set tax rates without first referring them to this chamber and to the parliament as a whole. I know the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) has said six per cent represents a more realistic figure for the uplift factor.

TALK.START.PARA: —Six is better.
—Unfortunately, transcripts do not tell you where he put the emphasis. It is more realistic than eight per cent, but it is not realistic by any logical measure. It is not attached to any formula.

BREAK.PARA: The only tax I know of which increases automatically—apart from taxes which the revenue benefits from in terms of bracket creep—is the fuel excise tax, but that is enshrined in law and there is a formula for that to increase once a year in accordance with growth in the CPI. That would be perfectly acceptable if it were applied to this measure. As I have said, average weekly earnings have very little to do with this, but the measure should be either business growth or growth in the CPI.

I favour the latter, but I would settle for either. It does not matter as long as it is there and constant. If it is to be six per cent, and left at that, as the opposition proposes to move, that is entirely supportable, but not for the reasons advanced by my colleague the honourable member for Werriwa. If it is set at six per cent, it is then open to the government, as it does with all taxes and all tax rates, to come before this parliament and move to increase it. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —I call the honourable member for Braddon.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: LATHAM

TALK.START.PARA: —He only gave a two-minute second reading speech.

INTERJECT.PARA: Mr MILES (Braddon—Parliamentary Secretary (Cabinet) to the Prime Minister) (8.44 p.m.)—in reply—The member for Werriwa (Mr Latham) says that I only gave a two‐minute speech. Of course, the speech of the member for Werriwa really was a one‐minute speech repeated 30 times. That is about all it was.

TALK.START.PARA: —But did you get the point?

—There was no point to be got. The point that you were making was absolute nonsense. Talk about the hypocrisy of the opposition on this issue. Just to underscore that, the media release of 22 May put out by the honourable member, the shadow minister for competition policy and assistant to the shadow Treasurer, says:

BREAK.PARA: The Federal Government has broken its promise to small businesses and self-funded retirees to set the provisional tax uplift factor at a permanent rate of 6 per cent . . .

TALK.START.PARA: —The permanent rate is 10.

—Wrong. We never said anything about a permanent rate. You know that. Outrageous! In your speech to the House, not one of the quotes you gave—whether by Costello, Howard or anybody—mentioned the concept of permanent.
—Mr Deputy Speaker, on a point of order: I would ask that the member appropriately address the Prime Minister and the Treasurer rather than refer to their surnames.
—With pleasure.
—The parliamentary secretary might also address his comments through the chair.

—I will, Mr Deputy Speaker. The speech of the honourable member was total obfuscation. The member for Werriwa built up an argument that never existed. It was absolutely a straw argument. It was totally false from the very first sentence.

BREAK.PARA: Who actually brought in the default rate, which is at 10 per cent? You did not say anything about the default rate. The previous government brought in the 10 per cent default rate. Who opposed the opposition's amendment to bring eight per cent down to six per cent?

TALK.START.PARA: —It is not our promise. It is your promise. You are the government.

—The previous government opposed dropping eight per cent down to six per cent last year. The hypocrisy of the whole argument is that, when you go back to 1991 and 1992 and have a look at what the nominal rates were, you find that Labor set the provisional tax uplift factor at 10 per cent when the growth in income subject to provisional tax was negative in both years. It was minus 4.1 per cent in 1990-91 and minus three per cent in 1991-92. What did you do? You put up the figure to 10 per cent. What an outrageous argument you gave to this parliament here tonight!

BREAK.PARA: Not only that, but the member for Werriwa came in here and talked about broken promises. Let us go back to the 1993 election. Labor promised not to put up taxes. What did we find? The total cost of Labor's dishonesty to Australian families was $7.3 billion. They increased company tax. They went to the 1993 election with the company tax rate at 33 per cent; after they were elected it went up to 36 per cent.

Have a look at fringe benefits tax. I can remember the former Prime Minister bringing that in. He talked about $200 million or $300 million being raised. Now it is $3½ billion being raised by the fringe benefits tax. They are the sorts of taxes that the previous government brought in for the Australian people. (Quorum formed)

Before I was rudely interrupted, I was commenting on the extra taxation which the previous government brought in after the 1993 election. There is no doubt that the previous government went to the election in 1993 with a commitment not to put up taxation, yet that is exactly what they did after the election, for example, with sales tax.

I remember one particular illustration which has to do with cars. At that stage we were proposing to bring in a GST at 15 per cent. What did the government of the day then do? They said, `We'll bring back sales tax to 15 per cent on cars.' A few months after the election, what did the tax go to? First of all, it went up to 21 per cent in June, up six per cent, and then in July it went up another one per cent. So it went up to 22 per cent.

TALK.START.PARA: —They are the taxing party.

—That is right. The Labor Party is the taxing party. That is the taxing party over there. Here we have a government that promised before this election to actually reduce the provisional tax uplift factor from eight per cent to six per cent. That is exactly what we are doing. That is what we promised. That is what we are delivering, quite different from that which the previous government did between 1993 and 1996.

BREAK.PARA: The member for Werriwa's speech in here, which went on for 30 minutes, as I said at the beginning, was really a one-minute speech given 30 times over. There was hardly a mention of anything else. But he complained that we had broken a promise. Here we are in fewer than three months delivering on this promise in this legislation. That is not what you did. You put out a press release trying to confuse the community and obfuscate between the default rate and the provisional uplift factor.

The member for Curtin (Mr Rocher) is quite right: there needs to be some rationale to the uplift factor. You are saying, `All right, we're going to bring it down to six per cent. It doesn't really matter what the economic circumstances are, we are going to have it at six per cent.' That is what your amendment is really saying.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Treasury forecast six per cent.

—No, it will be six per cent for years into the future. That is not what we are on about. What we are on about is delivering on our promise. We promised the Australian people, and we made it very clear, that we were going to reduce the provisional tax uplift factor down to six per cent from eight per cent.

BREAK.PARA: The extent of the hypocrisy by the member for Werriwa is that he says, `Well, what is going to happen is that in 1997-98 they are going to actually snatch back $360 million as a penalty.' That is what he says. Then he even goes on to try to get this press release to get some attention out there. He does not leave it at $360 million. He says, `Oh, in the three-year cycle it is going to be $540 million. It is a $540 million con. It is a lie.' The member is trying to get attention in this press release by just upping the figures and making it look grand. In actual fact, it is not on. It is just not working.

The member is really concerned because he is part of a party which, after the 1993 election, put up taxes. He is just trying to load that off on to the new government by saying that they are going to do the same. Our promise was that we would cut the provisional tax uplift factor from eight per cent to six per cent, and we are delivering on that. We are going to have a look at the uplift factor in future years, depending on the circumstances. That will be adjusted as is appropriate.

I want to thank the members who have participated in this debate—the member for Werriwa, the member for Isaacs (Mr Wilton), the member for Corio (Mr O'Connor), the member for Stirling (Mr Eoin Cameron) and the member for Curtin. The member for Curtin has also foreshadowed an amendment, proposing to reduce the provisional tax uplift factor from eight per cent to four per cent. I just make the comment that we went to the election promising that we would reduce eight per cent down to six per cent, and we are standing by that promise.

PARA.TAB: That the words proposed to be omitted (Mr Latham's amendment) stand part of the question.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the affirmative.
Original question resolved in the affirmative.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Clauses 1 to 4—by leave—taken together, and agreed to.
Schedule 1.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rocher, Allan, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Schedule 1, item 1, page 3 (line 9), omit "6%, substitute "4%".

As I have already indicated in my speech on the second reading, I propose that a four per cent uplift factor be substituted for the government's proposed six per cent. I will not go over the whole diatribe again but merely summarise by saying there is no logical basis for the six per cent.

The figure is not, as some innocent bystander might suspect, the equivalent of the expected increase in the consumer price index in the coming year or the equivalent of the expected increase in the gross domestic product in the coming year. It is merely a figure plucked out of the air. There is no basis for it. There is no recognised measure which would sustain an amount of six per cent.

The honourable member for Braddon (Mr Miles), the Parliamentary Secretary (Cabinet) to the Prime Minister, did make an accurate point. He said, `That is what we promised to do during the election, so that is what we are going to do.' I want to make it clear that, in the interests of logic, the figure should be in the vicinity of four per cent. It works out anyway. If you add projected growth of CPI and GDP together over the coming year and divide it by two, the average is around four per cent. The growth of each on its own is four per cent or less.

The only logic—this is borne out by the remark of the parliamentary secretary in summing up the second reading debate—is that it is two per cent less than Labor's figure. That is all it has going for it. Businesses generally, small businesses in particular and unincorporated small businesses that are going to have to meet the impost could reasonably expect that their tax uplift factor for provisional tax purposes would not exceed normal growth. This is a perfectly rational approach and one the government does not seem willing to accept.

There is no logic for the six per cent figure proposed by the government, except that that is what it promised to do. Therefore, the only logic left is that the government's figure is less than Labor's figure and that it is the product of a revenue hungry government.

The amendment I propose does have a logical basis, as I have explained already. It is approximate but is at least above the estimated percentage of growth in either the consumer price index or gross domestic product over the coming year. It is consistent also with past practice. The fuel excise impost, which is adjusted once a year by a percentage equivalent to the growth in the CPI for that year, is a precedent. It is logical and it is acceptable.

It is acceptable because, even though it promotes an increase in tax which does not have to be referred back to this parliament, it is set at an agreed and legislated rate by this parliament, and it is there until it is changed.

Everything I propose is consistent and logical and would be acceptable, I am sure, to the unincorporated small business sector and to those investors such as self-funded retirees, who are going to have to meet the six per cent impost despite estimated growth in the CPI being in the vicinity of four per cent.
Amendment negatived.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Latham, Mark, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Schedule 1, page 3, item 1 (subsection 221YA(1) (definition of provisional tax uplift factor )):
Omit the definition, substitute:
" provisional tax uplift factor , in relation to the 1996‐97 year of income and in relation to a later year of income, until the Parliament otherwise provides—means 6%.".

This is an amendment to keep the government honest. This is an amendment to test how seriously they take their own election promises. Earlier on we heard the Parliamentary Secretary (Cabinet) to the Prime Minister, the honourable member for Braddon (Mr Miles), saying that the Australian people should have known that this promise for an uplift factor of six per cent was for one year only. He is expecting the Australian people to be mind‐readers. He is expecting the Australian people to have been flies on the wall when the coalition determined the true nature of their election promises.

We have heard today how the government was expecting the people of south-west Sydney to be mind‐readers, to have been flies on the wall when they worked out their airports policy for Sydney. They are now expecting small businesses and self-funded retirees throughout the country to be mind-readers. I have to point out something to the parliamentary secretary. I have highlighted—I have been doing so much highlighting today—a section of your own small business policy. It states:
The policy will reduce the provisional tax uplift factor from 8% to 6%.

There is no qualification. There is no footnote. There is nothing in brackets which says `for one year only'. It says six per cent—full stop. At the last election you sought a mandate for three years. You made promises that the Australian people reasonably could have expected to last for three years. The expectation of 800,000 small businesses and self‐funded retirees is that when you said six per cent it would last for three years. You did not say it with a sunset clause that ends on 30 June 1997; you said it would last for three years. That is in black and white before the parliament in your own policy document. Not only that, but the Treasurer (Mr Costello), then just the Deputy Leader of the Opposition, in the House in June last year said:

The coalition believes that the uplift factor should be set at a realistic level which is more consistent with expected rates of income growth and inflation. Headline inflation for the year to March is 3.9 per cent. Why then assume that an average income for a provisional taxpayer will rise by eight per cent?

Why then assume for the out years that provisional tax assessment rates will rise by 10 per cent? That is what the government is legislating on. I have figures here from Treasury—the same figures the Treasurer has in his briefing document; the same figures he has on his desk in parliament right now—which show that for the out years, for years beyond 1996-97, the Treasury forecast of the uplift factor is much closer to six per cent than 10 per cent.

The forecast is there for the out years and you have been advised by your Treasury—we know how much store the Treasurer places on those forecasts—to set a rate much closer to six per cent than 10 per cent. Why, then, have you defied that advice? You made an open‐ended policy, a three-year policy, of six per cent—full stop. You came into government and received the advice from Treasury which said, `You are talking about a permanent rate. You are introducing legislation into the parliament for a permanent rate on the uplift factor. Here is our best advice.'

This is the best advice. The best advice from the Treasury on income subject to provisional tax for 1997-98 was 7.1 per cent. That is not within cooee of 10 per cent; it is much closer to six per cent. For 1998‐99 the forecast rate is 6.5 per cent. That is not within cooee of 10 per cent; it is much closer to six per cent. For 1999-2000 the forecast is 6.5 per cent. That is not within cooee of 10 per cent; it is much closer to six per cent.

Every single small business and self-funded retiree paying their provisional tax, looking at the out years, looking at the permanent rate, would know that they are victims of a Costello con, that they are victims of another John Howard fistful of dollars, snatched back after the election for the sole purpose of deceiving the people of Australia.

On the subject of further Treasury forecasts, the figures that the Treasurer has in his briefing folder—if he was willing to debate the matter he would have them right there on the desk—the nominal GDP forecasts for the out years from Treasury in 1997‐98 are 6½ per cent; 1998‐99, 6½ per cent; and 1999‐2000, 6½ per cent. The parliamentary secretary has to ask himself—he will not need the member for Cowan (Mr Richard Evans) to help him with this—is 6½ per cent, on Treasury advice, closer to six or 10? You should be able to work out that it is closer to six.

On that basis, you should be supporting the ALP amendment. Not to do so is to leave the possibility hanging over this parliament, small businesses and self‐funded retirees of this nation that the rate will stay at 10. You, your leader and your ministerial colleagues wax long and lyrical about the fact that you do not control the Senate. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rocher, Allan, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I support the amendment moved by the honourable member for Werriwa (Mr Latham), as I indicated earlier, but not for some of the reasons he gave earlier. Perhaps I am in sympathy with the reasons he gave when moving the amendment here today. My reason for supporting the amendment goes along this line: I would not trust any government with the right to increase a rate of tax by four per cent at its discretion. I simply would not do it. I argued against it when the Labor Party legislated for the first time in that way and set the uplift factor at something like 12 per cent. I remain consistent in my views and opposition to that.

SPEECH.PARA: For the executive government, by executive fiat, to be able to increase the uplift factor and therefore the tax payable by unincorporated small businesses and certain investors in this country who rely on their investment income is totally unacceptable, and it should be unacceptable to any fair‐minded person in this House. No other tax on the books can be increased in this way at the sole discretion of the executive, and it would not be allowed. I gave an example earlier. Take the top marginal PAYE tax rate of around 49c. Would this parliament give the government of the day the right to increase that to 60c at its discretion some time in the future? I do not think even coalition backbenchers would accept that. It is wrong in principle. It is taxation without representation because we simply do not get the opportunity to debate it in this place.

BREAK.PARA: Leave it at six per cent as is proposed by this amendment if you must. If you have to change it because of circumstances, do so by legislation—by coming into this parliament, by paying homage to the parliament, as the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) indicated on so many occasions prior to the last election campaign. Honour the parliament and give it a chance to influence executive government, to put it on some sort of parity. God knows we are nowhere near it at the moment. It is for that basic line of reasoning that I will support this amendment. It has nothing to do with the fact that in the run‐up to the election the coalition said that they are going to reduce the uplift factor to six per cent and therefore it should remain at six per cent for the full term of this government. It does not work that way.

TALK.START.PARA: —But the promise wasn't qualified.

—It was not extant; it was not to be for the full term of the parliament either. We can argue about the semantics. I simply do not accept that part of your argument. For the reasons I have already given, I believe this is wrong. It is following a totally unacceptable precedent set by this government's Labor predecessors. I do not think it is anything to be proud of.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Latham, Mark, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —My amendment seeks to establish the following definition:

SPEECH.PARA: "provisional tax uplift factor , in relation to the 1996‐97 year of income and in relation to a later year of income, until the Parliament otherwise provides—means 6%.".

That is what the coalition promised. It was not a qualified promise. They sought a three‐year mandate—they made a three-year promise—and we are doing nothing more than trying to keep them to that promise, to keep these people honest.

The coalition tell us about their Senate problem. My colleague the member for Banks (Mr Melham) was generous enough to suggest that the Senate should be abolished, and he is happy to second the motion of the Prime Minister (Mr Howard). The amendment I am moving tonight is just as good, because it solves the government's Senate problem on the uplift factor for provisional tax for the next two years. This is a government that does not control the Senate. This is a government that cannot give a guarantee to small businesses and self‐funded retirees that the 10 per cent permanent rate will be reduced in the out years, for 1997-98 and 1998-99.

If the government cannot provide that guarantee to small business and self‐funded retirees, why not support the Labor Party amendment? Why not support the amendment that solves its Senate problem? It does not need to go to the extreme of abolishing the Senate. We are providing, through this amendment, the opportunity for the government to solve its Senate problem on the uplift factor for provisional tax. To do nothing leaves the rate for the out years at 10 per cent.

The member for Curtin (Mr Rocher) has made a series of very good points. I think he has alluded to the fact that what the coalition plans is a bit of a swindle in the out years. What they will say to small business and self‐funded retirees 12 months from now is, `We had the permanent rate at 10. We are going to bring it down to eight. Aren't you lucky?' I submit to the member for Curtin and to every other member in this House that that is contrary to the intent and the faith that they expressed in their election promise. Small business would be dudded by that act if, 12 months from now, they came in here and said, `We've had the permanent rate of 10; that's in the legislation. We're now suggesting eight because the Treasury has given us some different advice.'

What the opposition says to the government is: set it at six—six for now, six for next year and six for the year after. They are the medium term projections you have received from your own Treasury department. That is the best advice that is currently available to the Treasurer (Mr Costello). I am the first to concede that if the legitimate forecast for nominal GDP growth in the out years goes up, and it is around eight per cent, then we will support an eight per cent amendment.

TALK.START.PARA: —And pigs might fly, too!

—As the member for Curtin has pointed out, the prospect of increased growth under this government is as likely as pigs flying. He has pointed that out because they are adopting a contractionary high interest rate policy. It is very unlikely that growth will go up, that nominal GDP forecasts out of the Treasury will go up to eight per cent. But, if they do, there is no problem. I commit all my colleagues in the Labor Party to supporting an amendment 12 months from now to put it at eight per cent if this is the best advice on the forecast. But the fair and reasonable and decent thing to do—based on the advice that the Parliamentary Secretary (Cabinet) to the Prime Minister (Mr Miles) has and on the advice that the Treasurer (Mr Costello) has from his department—is to set it at six per cent. Set it at six per cent in accordance with your policy and then, if it needs to be varied later on, we will do so. Set it at six just in case you decide to do nothing—and that is always available to the government. If they decide to do nothing on this option, then it stays at 10. If your Senate problems continue and you cannot carry similar legislation through the Senate in 12 or 24 months from now, you have solved the problem. You have got it at six. That is an act of good faith and decency to the 800,000 provisional taxpayers in Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: Here is an opportunity for the government to show what it meant and what it intended when it made that promise to the people of Australia. They are on to the government, because tonight I have revealed the Treasury forecasts on this matter. The medium year out year forecasts are so much closer to six than 10. It is so much more reasonable to set the permanent rate at six. I repeat to the parliamentary secretary: if you decide to do nothing, 12 or 24 months from now, it stays at 10. That, you must confess, is a clear breach of faith and intent on your election promise. If you cannot pass the legislation through the Senate 12 or 24 months from now, it stays at 10. Again, that is an act of bad faith. Support this amendment. It is the decent thing to do.

Mr MILES (Braddon—Parliamentary Secretary (Cabinet) to the Prime Minister) (9.29 p.m.)—It is very interesting that the member for Werriwa (Mr Latham), in his opportunity to comment, did not make the point that the default rate has been 10 per cent since 1991, under Labor. He had three opportunities to do that. He did not make one comment that it has been 10 per cent since 1991, and in 1992, 1993, 1994 and 1995. Now he comes into the House and wants us to change it. It does stretch the imagination a little bit.

The member for Werriwa's argument is that the default rate was a permanent rate. He was really arguing from silence and extrapolating just to suit his own political ends. There is no other reason or basis for it. At least the contribution by the member for Curtin (Mr Rocher) has been consistent through the years on this matter. There is no consistency in the debate which has been put to us by the opposition today. There is no consistency at all in what they were doing in government. At least we said at the election that we would reduce the uplift factor from eight per cent to six per cent, and that is exactly what we are doing here tonight. Under Labor the uplift factor was set at unrealistically high levels. This was merely a grab for revenue, which put extra strain on the cash flow position of small businesses.

I wish to make the point again that under Labor the provisional tax uplift factor exceeded actual growth in income subject to provisional tax in each and every year between 1991 and 1994-95. The Labor government set the uplift factor at eight per cent for the last four years, including 1995-96. When the coalition moved an amendment to reduce the uplift factor to six per cent in 1995-96, what did the Labor Party do? It did not accept it. Instead it retained the eight per cent. You have come in here and changed your whole argument around, all in a matter of a few months. At that stage it penalised provisional taxpayers, small businesses and self-funded retirees. It was an absolute tax grab at that stage. We are not allowing that to happen. We are cutting it from eight per cent down to six per cent. The government will ensure that the provisional tax uplift factor in each area is set more in line with the nominal income growth to prevent the tax grab that was present under the Labor government.

BREAK.PARA: The government will be setting the provisional tax uplift factor for each year when the most accurate information is available. For 1997-98 and future income years that assessment will be made at a later date. There is a clear difference in this area. We went to the election and we made a promise that we would reduce it from eight per cent down to six per cent and we are delivering on that promise.

In the 1993 election the Labor Party went to the people and said they would not increase taxation. What did they do? They went and put up taxes. We promised that we would reduce it from eight per cent down to six per cent. That is what we promised and we are delivering to the small businesses and independent retirees in this country.

The total hypocrisy of the member for Werriwa and the opposition to come and argue here about a reduction from 10 per cent down to six per cent is just to confuse. We are delivering on the promise of what we went to the Australian people with. We are cutting the uplift factor from eight per cent to six per cent. That is more than you did in the five or six years in which this piece of legislation has been around. It was your party that was in power at that time. You have just done a total U-turn. We made a promise and we are delivering on that promise. Mr Deputy Speaker, I am opposed to what is being proposed by the opposition.

PARA.TAB: That the words proposed to be omitted (Mr Latham's amendment) stand part of the question.
