TALK.START.PARA: —Before the debate is resumed on this bill, I remind the House that it has been agreed that a general debate be allowed covering this bill and Supply Bill (No. 2) 1996‐97 and Supply (Parliamentary Departments) Bill 1996‐97.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reid, Bruce, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —Before I commence speaking on the Supply Bill, I would like to congratulate the new members on this side of the chamber and on the other side of the chamber on the fine contribution that they have made already to the Supply Bill. From the talent on this side of the House, there have been some remarkable speeches and some very fine new members. There is an array of talent. I am sure that talent will take us right into the next century.

SPEECH.PARA: Many of the new members here have made a magnificent contribution. I congratulate each one of them for their contribution to the House and wish them well in their future career. I wish the members on this side who have not yet taken the opportunity to make their first speech every success also. We have a great array of talent on this side of the chamber. I am sure that they will stand the coalition in very good stead in the future.

At this point in speaking on the Supply Bill, I want to address a number of matters in the environment portfolio. Recently, I had a visit from the North Central Catchment and Land Protection Board, which operates in part of my electorate. That part of the electorate takes in both the Loddon and Campaspe rivers and many other streams which flow in a northerly direction into the great River Murray and into the Murray‐Darling system. Ultimately, the water which emanates from the Great Dividing Range in central Victoria and flows northward through this north central region contributes to the quality of water which ultimately ends up in South Australia and provides drinking water and irrigation water to a huge area of South Australia as well.

The North Central Catchment and Land Protection Board has established both a vision and a mission to work towards. I met with the chairman of the board, Ted Gretgrix, who is from Bagshot just out of Bendigo, as well as a number of members of his board and also the executive officer, Shawn Butters. They informed me that the vision they have for the catchment and land protection board in the north central region is an informed and responsible community using integrated and sustainable natural resource management to enhance the economic and social development of the north central region while protecting and improving our environment. Their mission is to provide strategic leadership, advice and coordination to achieve integrated natural resource management in the north central region.

It is a very important area in many respects. I compliment the board for their fine work in this area because, as you know, Mr Deputy Speaker, care and protection of the environment and the quality of water supply in north central Victoria and in the Murray region is vitally important to the residents, industry and also primary industry in that area.

I have also received a document from the Loddon catchment water quality strategy under the national landcare program. This particular body is interested in water quality, another very important water issue. It takes in the care and protection of the Loddon River, which flows right through to the Murray. The important aspect of it is the way it ensures the water quality is improved, the land surrounding all of this catchment area is managed and the landcare groups and salinity management groups are linked.

Salinity is a very major issue for anyone farming in that north central region of Victoria. The salinity management groups work in extremely well with every level of government—that is, local government, state government and federal government. They are reliant upon those three levels of government for funding at various levels to assist them in the fine work they do undertake.

One of the things that caused great concern in that area over the last few years was the blue-green algae which was appearing in many of the streams. It has become a major problem. There have been spectacular explosions of algal blooms in some of those streams. Some of the blooms are potentially toxic species and, in many instances, affect the water quality to such an extent that even withdrawing the water from a stream and boiling it still does not remove the toxins.

This algae is of great concern to the small communities within the catchment area and within the usage area of that stream as they have to ensure the quality of water is not detrimental to the residents of that area. The Loddon catchment area strategy addresses that problem. It is endeavouring, with assistance from the three levels of government, to ensure that the water quality of that area is protected.

There is also another problem; that is, the levels of nutrients which are going into those streams as well. Many of those nutrient levels contain nitrogen and phosphorus. There is always a certain amount of this occurring naturally in the area, but the levels are becoming particularly high and are causing quite a bit of concern. Some of it comes from domestic waste water, urban stormwater areas and industrial waste water, and some of it comes from the intensive animal industries. So it is a problem which has brought a lot of attention to it because of the high toxic level of some of those algal blooms which are occurring.

A strong effort is being made by all of the authorities to try to reduce the discharge from waste water treatment plants into the waterways in an effort to try to improve the quality of the water. The tertiary effluent treatment of sewage has also been introduced, but there are still many small townships without any form of sewerage. In many instances, they are reliant upon septic tanks. They do at times spill and seep into some of the water streams, and that adds to some of the difficulties that do occur in the quality of the water.

That has been addressed under the federal government country towns water management improvement program, which has a rather cute acronym—COWMIP. It has been a project which has done some excellent work in many of the small country townships throughout Australia, producing small sewerage systems that are generally not able to be effected by the local community. But, with state government assistance, a bit of local government assistance and federal government contribution, a sewerage system can be introduced to replace what has been an old septic system. Of course, an effort has been made to improve the quality of the water. But none of these things can be done without the necessary dollars, and there are many of these environment programs that will need to be attended to.

It is necessary to improve the river flow management as there is a lot of watercourse bank erosion, which is often caused by excessive flows of water. The inroads it makes into the banks and the lack of attention it may receive can erode significant areas and change the whole course of a waterway. That erosion can take away valuable soil from the farming pursuits on either side of the watercourse.

It is also important, from an environmental point of view, to have adequate flows of water to the wetlands areas. Some of those wetlands areas are very important ecologically to sustain life. They are very important to the processes of the flows into the Murray River and they improve the ecology of that river as well.

BREAK.PARA: It also has a significant impact on fishing. Throughout those Victorian streams we have the major problem of the European carp infestation, which does untold damage to many of those streams because of its peculiar feeding habits. It feeds on the bottom of a river and continually churns up the base of the river. It eats all of the feed on the bottom of the river and then turns it into mud. It can pollute the water streams and, of course, cause extreme difficulties for all of the native fish.

It was with this in view that the Australian Recreational and Sport Fishing Confederation Inc. came to see me just a week ago. It is one thing that is very important to the recreational fishing people. I understand that there are over 4½ million recreational fishers in Australia, so it is one of the biggest sports and certainly one of the biggest recreations.

They would like to see a system of adequate funding for recreational fishing administration, representation and management, and for fish habitat, resource conservation and management; an immediate allocation of funding to implement the goals and principles of the national recreational fishing policy; a commitment to fund a survey of recreational and sport fishing in Australia every five years; a restriction of foreign longlining in Australia's exclusive economic zone; and no commercial taking of billfish in the Australian fishing zone. The Minister for Administrative Services, the member for Fadden (Mr Jull), who is at the table, probably understands more about the billfish than us southerners. Certainly, he would understand that very clearly and would believe that it should be declared a recreational species only. I want to commend this organisation to members of the House.

Recreational fishing is a big industry. As well as having a number of devotees, the sport is a big industry when you think of all the equipment that is involved—the fishing gear, the boats and the recreational items that are required when you go fishing. It is a sport for all of the family. I can only commend it to the members of the House.

I also want to talk about a particular stream in my electorate, the Bendigo Creek. There has been extensive publicity about this creek because of the question mark which hangs over it and its ability to dispose of chemical and toxic waste. The Bendigo Advertiser recently ran a very big feature on this and headed up some of the problems that were involved and the need for the Environment Protection Authority of the Victorian state government and the federal government to take an active interest in this, along with the landcare groups and all of the local government bodies that border that creek.

It is a stream that emanates from Bendigo in the catchment area and finds its way right through Kow Swamp to Kerang, ultimately finding its way into the Murray River. This is a real problem that needs attention. I am delighted that the Bendigo Advertiser sought to look at reasons why this creek was polluting so many areas, tried to look at the reasons behind it and tried to find a strategy in conjunction with all of the groups—including the Loddon catchment area body and also with state government and federal government—to address that question.

There is also the problem of liquid waste. Some of it can be discharged to that creek and can be handled okay, but a lot of it needs to be handled by private firms who would remove some of that waste water and treat those toxic chemicals in the manner in which they should be treated.

All of these issues concerning the environment are extremely important for all of north central Victoria because of the impact that they have on so many farms, the contribution to salinity, the impact that it has on the Murray‐Darling system and the salt load that goes in there. But there is another issue that I would briefly like to touch on, and it is what is known as the Northern Mallee pipeline project, which is to the north of my electorate. Some of the streams in my area, and some of the water that ultimately finds its way into the northern area of my electorate, are associated with this.

The Northern Mallee pipeline program project is an infrastructure project with diverse and enduring benefits which are very much broader than just water supply improvement. The dramatic water savings from both the total project and the individual stages directly translate to a number of major improvements in the area. They assist in the establishment of minor and major industrial and commercial developments. I might add that this scheme, when completed, will save 65,000 megalitres of water each year. That is probably enough water to keep the whole city of Bendigo and its 85,000 residents in water for a year. So you can see the incredible savings that could be achieved by piping what was once an open channel right through the Northern Mallee area. Because it was an open channel, and much of it still is, there has been a tremendous amount of wastage through evaporation, drainage and spoilage of the quality of the water.

With a saving of 65,000 megalitres of water per annum, it would be a major breakthrough if the final stages of this Northern Mallee pipeline project were to be completed. It would mitigate the economic loss to existing farm and industrial enterprises through better drought preparedness, which is a very important topic. In 1995 that region was subjected to the second worst drought in Australian history.

The project would improve on‐farm management practices and productivity. It would assist important new rural agricultural and value added enterprises. It would also provide major environmental benefits throughout the Wimmera and Mallee, extending to the Glenelg and Murray river basins, with the rehabilitation of significant lands presently lost to production because of salinity. One of the areas most seriously affected is the Kerang area. It is therefore very important that this project proceed so that land there is rehabilitated and put back into full‐scale production.

This project is well worthy of federal and state government support. Back in 1992 and 1993 the federal and state governments provided $4.2 million in funds for the construction of the first of eight stages of this project. Stage two was completed in December of 1995 following a further allocation in 1994‐95 from both federal and state governments totalling $5.1 million.

About 40 per cent of this project has been funded but there is still much to be done. These are the sorts of programs that need to be continued because they result in tremendous savings in water and have very strong environmental impacts that include protecting land from desalinisation and putting it back into full‐scale production. But, regrettably, many of these projects cannot be funded under our existing budget. That is why our environment package is so important.

The environment package needs to pass through the Senate to ensure that additional funds are available for projects relating to these rivers and streams. Many groups in my electorate are hoping to receive funds because of it. The North Central Catchment and Land Protection Board certainly is, and both the Northern Mallee pipeline project and Bendigo Creek could do with some more money. Without that package we will not have sufficient funds to implement a lot of these major projects in the electorate. I am sure every Australian would know of similar important projects. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ferguson, Martin, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I rise this evening to speak about the importance of continued funding for what I regard as the most innovative labour market program put together in the history of this country. I refer specifically to Working Nation, which was first announced in 1994. I also make note of the importance of that scheme to regional Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: On the employment front, I must say that I was surprised this evening that the member for Bendigo (Mr Reid) did not raise the matter of the closure of the Family Court in Bendigo and the potential loss of jobs. I mention it because one of the objectives of Working Nation was to assist those who were displaced, as a result of the restructuring of the Australian economy, to ensure that they were given meaningful employment and training opportunities.

With respect to the innovative nature of Working Nation, historically up until the late 1980s the approach to unemployment in Australia was to basically adopt the view that a person who was unemployed would be unemployed for a short duration and was therefore entitled to a system of relief. In the late 1980s, it became clear to the Australian government and, for that matter, to industry at large that there were particular groups in the Australian labour force that required specialist attention. That therefore resulted in the development of JET—jobs, education and training—which was, in many instances, for single parents who had been out of the work force for varying periods, often unfortunately lengthy in nature.

We also put together the first program aimed at trying to assist the long-term unemployed, namely, newstart. I am pleased to say that in 1994 the Australian community adopted the view that in relation to many of the long-term unemployed, in association with other groups of the Australian community who had lost jobs as a result of the restructuring of the economy with respect to the railway, the maritime industry, the manufacturing industry or whatever, there was an obligation on the government of the day to ensure that there was sufficient allocation of resources to create meaningful training opportunities as a stepping stone to gainful employment for those people. It also meant that we put in place a fairly important cornerstone. That went to a new principle—a reciprocal obligation on the basis of which every person was guaranteed a reasonable offer of employment and training.

The other side of the coin that related to the question of reciprocal obligation represented a package of some significance. The key elements of that package, as embodied in Working Nation, included the following issues: firstly, a commitment to enhanced skills development; secondly, greater labour market program opportunities; thirdly, early intervention assistance for at‐risk short‐term unemployed; fourthly, a youth training initiative to ensure that unemployed youth under 18 years of age do not become long-term unemployed; and, fifthly and finally, a guaranteed job or suitable employment offer for those in the job context.

I raised this issue this evening because I am exceptionally concerned about the potential loss of many of the initiatives that have had a major impact in assisting people not just in metropolitan Australia but also in regional Australia as a result of the Working Nation initiatives. I say in passing that in recent weeks I have had contact from a number of regional centres around Australia expressing concern about the attitude of the current government to the Working Nation programs and in doing so highlighting their successes and perhaps, more importantly, their worries about the future of those programs.

I said in my first speech to parliament that one of the major issues confronting the Australian community at the moment was a requirement by government, in association with the community at large, to try to put some security back into people's lives. I would argue that Working Nation was about trying to put some security back into people's lives. I say that because, for whatever reason, the Australian community decided that we had to restructure the Australian economy. That effectively meant that many people, be it in the textile, clothing and footwear industry, the railway industry or a variety of other industries, lost jobs that they would have expected to hold for the rest of their working lives.

On that basis, I refer to contact recently made to my office in Batman in the northern suburbs of Melbourne by people such as Jim, Vahida and Tracey. I have also received faxes and letters from Fiona, Julia, Tahtali, Theresa, Garry and Yeh. I will tell you why all of them are making contact. They are exceptionally worried about what will happen to their job opportunities if the current government, led by the Prime Minister (Mr Howard), shuts down the labour market programs that have had so much success in recent months. I have also received calls from Perth, from the Hunter region and from Cairns—from people hoping that I can help them get back into training, get into a labour market program, which will get them meaningful long-term job opportunities.

They want my help because they have been told by the local CES office, on the instruction of the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs (Senator Vanstone), that the labour market skills training tap is being slowly turned off. They are effectively being told that nothing more is available. They are being told that it is drying up so quickly, under instructions from Senator Vanstone and Dr Kemp, that after Friday—if nothing new is heard—Skillshare groups around Australia expect to start handing out redundancy and termination notices to their 10,000 employees on the advice of the National Skillshare Association.

It is these types of decisions that I believe had a serious impact on the recent elections in the state of New South Wales. I think of the poor performance by the National Party in the seat of Clarence and the seat of Orange. I know that because in the northern suburbs of Melbourne and Northcote, for example, in my electorate of Batman, employers who have employed young apprentices and trainees under federal government programs are upset. They are seriously upset and angry with the coalition government.

There are, for example, more than 70 businesses in my electorate who have done the decent thing and taken on young people using the national training wage allowance that this government is now refusing to pay them. This government ought to hang its head in shame, turning its back yet again on small businesses. The Northcote CES office is having to tell employers that, even though they have been good local corporate citizens and taken on young people as trainees and apprentices, the new government will not let them pay the promised subsidies which were supported by this parliament.

One small business employer in my electorate has rung my office and said that he cannot believe what has happened to him in recent days. He has—I think he is to be congratulated and supported—doubled his work force by taking on five young trainees under the national training wage allowance. But now the CES, under the instructions of Senator Vanstone, the minister responsible, will not even pay him for his decision to try to do something constructive with respect to the all‐ important issue, especially in the northern suburbs of Melbourne, of creating training and job opportunities for young unemployed people.

To his credit, this employer has been ringing the CES almost daily, asking when he would be paid. But they cannot give him an answer because they have been given instructions to say that the money has run out. He was told, `Wait a month.' Then maybe they can pay him. This has in turn affected his cash flow, which is always tight for small business. Unfortunately, he has had to lay off two trainees in their 20s and told a third trainee that he may soon have to tell him that there is no more work because of the decision of this government. Unfortunately, this situation is being replicated all over the country with thousands of small businesses.

I refer in passing to the fact that one of our successes under Working Nation was the creation of jobs in the small business sector of the Australian economy. In fact, over 70 per cent of jobs created under Working Nation were created in the small business sector of the Australian economy. In that context I refer to the fact that the previous government banked $140 million to ensure that there would be enough money to pay all employers and their employees if, as has happened, the demand for labour market programs outstripped the original budget for this program.

Instead of using this money, the Treasurer (Mr Costello) is now unfortunately playing cheap politics, telling people that there is no money available. I suggest that it is a con—the Costello con, a nasty game unfortunately hurting small businesses and their employees, some of the most disadvantaged people in the Australian economy.

Let us go to Bathurst in New South Wales. I refer to a program which has had a successful track record in training young unemployed for the retail industry, one of the growth areas of employment at this particular point in Australian history. The retail trainers were given less than 24 hours in Bathurst to tell its trainees that the next retail training program had been shut down by this government, even though that program had plenty of applicants lining up for the opportunity to get the skills to get a job and to gain long-term employment in the retail industry.

PARA.BREAK: I turn to the question of reconciliation. I note that this week is National Reconciliation Week. This is a fairly sensitive issue. I be lieve there is a commitment in the Australian economy at the moment, out in the Australian community, to do something practical to assist our indigenous people.

SPEECH.PARA: In a truly sensitive move last Friday, four days before the beginning of reconciliation week, the Njernda Aboriginal Cooperative near Echuca in north‐west Victoria was rung by the local CES representative and told that there was no money for the nine trainees employed by the local co‐op. The co‐op was then told that the money for the trainees, all in the special labour market programs, may never come through. That is the government's commitment not only to the labour market but also to the question of reconciliation and trying to do something practical about indigenous people who have the highest level of unemployment in Australia at this time.

That co‐op had taken on these trainees in good faith. One of the trainees had in fact moved from Cairns in Queensland to get training in Victoria so as to ensure that, as is the normal practice by Senator Vanstone at the moment, the finger could not be pointed at that trainee and the suggestion made that the trainee was a dole bludger. Now the CES will probably have to say, `Sorry, no money, no training, no work,' as a result of the decisions of this government.

I want to talk about Carole Artery, a pensioner. Carol is to be congratulated because she is a pensioner trying to support herself and her daughter. She tells me that at the age of 46 her only opportunity of getting the skills to get a job and get off the pension, which is her desire, has been the local Skillshare organisation. I know that many members of this House support the local Skillshare organisation and they are as worried as I am about the future of those Skillshare organisations because of the attitude of the current government. She said:

Skillshare has given me the support and confidence. I know of other people who have done this course and now have very good jobs. If Skillshare closes, I would have a long wait to get into another course at TAFE. At my age—46—I may not get in at all.

Georgina Galea is also trying to get off the pension and get a job. I know it hurts the government for me to raise these issues this evening, because I am talking about ordinary men and women out there who want to pursue practical training opportunities so as to ensure they get on the ladder to gain a proper job and avoid being called a dole bludger by Senator Vanstone and Dr Kemp. What did she have to say? She said:
It will be a shame if we have to close the centre because the government wants to save money by making us suffer.
Then there is the migrant woman trying to get a job and to take part in Australian society. She says if her Skillshare is closed down:
I think that there will not be any hope for me to work. I will try to diminish all my hopes and sit back and be content with the social security benefits.
That is what the coalition would have that migrant woman do. She then goes on to say:
I hope you will reconsider your decision and God helps you.

I only hope this evening that Senator Vanstone and Dr Kemp, the member for Goldstein, are listening. I also hope that the Treasurer, Mr Costello, is listening because I want to raise the circumstance of a 32‐year‐old chef from rural Queensland. His name is Martin. I am pleased to say he has worked for a period of 15 years as a chef but now, because of a rare disease, he cannot continue working in the kitchen and needs new skills and retraining. I thought Working Nation was about giving those people an opportunity to transfer from one industry to another if they found, because of their personal circumstances, that they were no longer able to continue in those gainful employment opportunities. Martin said to me that his only hope to get anywhere in life was to get new skills through a literacy group run by the local TAFE and paid for by CES. He went on to say:
It is 1996 and I cannot believe that anybody does not understand how hard it is to survive without the skills so many people take for granted.
He has also asked my office for assistance. With respect to his other workmates who want to pursue such literacy programs, he said:
Please help us in our plight as we only have six weeks before our classes are cancelled and we are forgotten about by the coalition government.

Finally, let me talk about Tracey. In her effort to get a job, she is doing a skillshare typing course in the day and, to her credit, a different TAFE course in the evening, to try to make sure that she is ready to pursue employment opportunities. This is what Tracey had to say to me:

It's a pain knowing what the government and a lot of other people are saying about us: `All those unemployed people just sit at home all day, and those who don't have the experience needed don't even get out and try to get the experience needed to get a particular job.'

Tracey asked me, `How can we get the experience needed if you all decide to stop the funding?' Tracey also said—and I hope Senator Vanstone, Dr Kemp and Mr Costello are listening—that she did not like to be called a dole bludger. I hope you are all listening, because these are the types of men and women all around Australia—urban and regional Australia—who want to pursue practical training opportunities under Working Nation.

During the short break before parliament resumed, I took the opportunity to meet with those people. I met, for example, with the people at 15 Skillshare centres in Sydney. They are all sitting and wondering at the moment whether there will be continued funding to ensure that those Skillshare centres continue to make a major contribution to training and gainful employment opportunities around Australia.

People hope to get jobs. They also know that the stepping stone to decent job opportunities is practical training programs, delivered as a result of Working Nation. Working Nation was a success because we took it out of Canberra and gave it to local groups to ensure that they involved the local communities and developed programs specific to the needs of industries in their local regions. I would only hope that the current government, in seeking to pull apart the Working Nation initiatives, does not walk away from those successes and the opportunities we gave to many different people around Australia to make a significant contribution to the development of programs that met the skill requirements of industry development in the local regions.

BREAK.PARA: I urge the Australian community to listen to the stories that I have relayed to the parliament this evening. I urge members on the other side of the House to talk to some of the graduates of these programs who are now off the dole, off the pension, and who are earning good money and have self-respect. Working Nation is a success for that very reason. We put self-respect back into the Australian community because we developed programs that suit the needs and circumstances of individual people, their families and industry at large. The government is to be condemned for its activities, its short-sighted approach, its attacks on Working Nation and its failure to commit adequate resources to the ongoing implementation of the targeted Working Nation initiatives.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLeay, Leo, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise tonight to raise the concern that my constituents have about the problems at Sydney airport and the hypocrisy of the government in what it ran to the last election on. We have seen a number of statements by government spokespersons, the Minister for Transport and Regional Development (Mr Sharp) and others, talking about how we are going to share the noise around Sydney. We have seen a number of outright mistruths said by the government on this.

SPEECH.PARA: A number of people from the electorate of Lowe complained to me over the weekend that the government broke its promise to them. We heard the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) say on a number of occasions during the election campaign that there would be no planes flying over the electorate of Lowe if the people of Lowe voted for the coalition. That promise has been absolutely broken.

There is no doubt that on the weekend a number of planes flew over Enfield, Strathfield and that bottom part of the Lowe electorate. That is an absolute contravention of what the government said would happen. There has also been a substantial number of flights all over the south‐western and inner part of Sydney. Parts of Sydney that were never subjected to aircraft noise before are now being subjected to aircraft noise. There are heavy jets taking off and peeling off the flight path long before they reach the Iron Cove Bridge, which was where the Minister for Transport said the government would have those planes going to before they turned east or west. Any of the maps that Airservices Australia can provide will show that we have these spaghetti trails all over the Sydney metropolitan area now, affected by the changes that the government has made.

The reality is that the government was driven by ideology and sheer electoral fraud in wanting to look after themselves and hurt other people by the promises that they made during the election campaign about Sydney airport. In their manic desire to implement those policies, they have brought a lot of noise and difficulty to hundreds of thousands of people who live in Sydney.

We have also seen the government in its meanderings propose an EIS on Holsworthy. The effect of that will be that the government will find itself trying to make a choice about Holsworthy or Badgerys Creek, putting off the decision to build a second airport for Sydney. The reality of that will be—as we have already seen in the newspapers in recent days with the tourism task force—demands to turn Sydney airport into a 24‐hour operation airport and demands that we do great damage to the most beautiful city in Australia.

If the government wants to do something sensible about Sydney airport, it ought to look at doing something to take aircraft traffic away from that airport and move it to another airport that can service Sydney. All this stupidity about whether we will have an EIS on Holsworthy or whether or not we will go ahead with Badgerys Creek just puts off the day. As we come to the Olympic Games in the year 2000, we will find that there has been no airport built and that there are demands to do away with the curfew. Once that curfew is lost, the people of Sydney will be damned to a 24-hour operation airport for the rest of their lives.

It will just become too simple for the government. I see the minister at the table, the Minister for Sport, Territories and Local Government (Mr Warwick Smith), nodding when I say that. He is in on the plot with these people. He knows precisely what they are up to. That will not wash. He comes from a city which has the greatest white elephant ever built by the Liberal Party in civil aviation years—the Launceston airport. They are trying to cause the same ridiculous situation to happen in Sydney, but in reverse. You have an airport that no-one goes to at Launceston and an airport that too many want to come to in Sydney. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hardgrave, Gary, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight I rise to speak about the Coopers Plains level crossing in my electorate. This is a very dangerous level crossing and an overpass should have been built there some 25 years ago. Lack of an overpass contributes to the problems which cause one of Brisbane's most congested intersections, the intersection of Boundary, Orange Grove and Beenleigh Roads at Coopers Plains. Lack of an overpass has caused small business to decline in the general Coopers Plains area and it has also, unfortunately, caused several fatalities, the most recent just a few weeks ago.

SPEECH.PARA: This level crossing crosses the Brisbane suburban line, which has now been extended to the Gold Coast, so it is the Brisbane‐Gold Coast railway line which is affected. Since the line has been open there have been several accidents that have caused some delays to the progress of the Gold Coast train, which, of course, goes to the heart of the viability of the entire service.

I campaigned on this issue in the Coopers Plains area at the recent federal election and large numbers of people in the area supported my stand, and I note that recently the Brisbane City Council have come up with a number of band‐aid solutions—traffic light coordination and line marking for pedestrians—to try and make it safer. I am especially glad, though, that my recent campaign efforts have woken up the local Labor councillors in the area. These particular people want to be seen as doing something, but what they have come up with is certainly not the answer. Those are not my words alone. The Coopers Plains Concerned Citizens Group, including the Reverend John Case, shares my view that the ideas put forward by the Brisbane City Council are simply band‐aid solutions to a major problem and that the real response that is needed, and wanted, by the citizens in the area is an overpass.

You would be disturbed to know, Mr Speaker, that a coronial inquiry a few years ago into a fatality at the level crossing recommended an overpass, but the then state Labor government simply ignored the coroner's recommendations. I have written to the new coalition government in Queensland and so far, unfortunately, have been ignored by them also. It seems to me and to many residents in and around Coopers Plains that this is simply because this area is a traditionally safe Labor area. Locals thought, back in 1989 when a state Labor government was elected, that the problem would be remedied; after all, then Premier Goss had also once been the local member. But no, Labor ignored their needs. They took their votes for granted.

Sadly, my side of politics seems to have also written off the area as one in which they cannot get a vote. The state coalition government will get plenty of votes in the Coopers Plains area if they break the never ending cycle of fobbing‐off and actually fix the problem. I am particularly astounded that 10 weeks have passed since I wrote to the state transport minister in Queensland about this issue. Since I first wrote, another fatality has occurred at the crossing. I wrote to the minister at that time seeking a meeting on the issue, and last week I wrote to him again warning him that I would, regrettably, have to criticise him publicly for his silence on this issue. The only comment that I can find which comes close to having actually come from his own mouth was a statement to one of the local papers in my area last week by a spokesman for the minister who said it would cost $20 million to build an overpass at Coopers Plains.

No‐one in my area needs any more excuses or delays. The crossing should have been built 25 years ago when a similar crossing was built on the interstate line up the road. It was not, and the failure of successive state governments to act on this issue since then must now come to an end.

I reject the approach of putting off this issue yet again. Today I have written to the Queensland Premier, Rob Borbidge, the leader of the Liberal Party in Queensland, Joan Sheldon, the Labor leader, Peter Beattie, the local Labor state member for Archerfield, Len Ardill, and the Labor councillor for the Acacia Ridge ward, Kevin Bianchi, and asked them to join with me to put partisan politics aside and to work together to get the sensible solution to this problem which is needed. I have asked both the Premier and the opposition leader to make the overpass for Coopers Plains party policy.

Both sides must commit to action. We cannot afford a continuation of the long wait for action and both sides of Queensland state politics have to put aside partisan point scoring and get on with the job. As the federal member for the area, I will work with all interested people to achieve the best for my constituents, putting people ahead of politics. In simple terms: I want an end to the impasse which for decades has prevented an overpass being built.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hollis, Colin, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —This evening I want to raise an issue that I raised earlier today: the deception of the proposed airport at Holsworthy. This afternoon, when I had a bit of time on my hands, I obtained the first preference voting in the Hughes by-election at the recent general election. I was particularly interested in the Wattle Grove area because that is where the Defence Housing Authority has put in a magnificent housing estate.

SPEECH.PARA: I was interested to read that the Liberal candidate, who is now a member of this House, the honourable member for Hughes (Mrs Vale), received 1,228 first preference votes and the runner-up, the ALP candidate Robert Tickner, received 1,063 votes. I suggest that, if that election was repeated this coming Saturday, the 1,228 votes would not go to the Liberal candidate because people do not like the prospect of jets coming or taking off a few hundred feet above their houses.

Mr Speaker, as you would know, it is important—in a former life you were a member of the Public Works Committee—that, of all the defence housing projects all around Australia, Wattle Grove is a showplace. There is absolutely no question about that. It is a magnificent estate and has been very successful. Many people have purchased houses in Wattle Grove, not just defence houses. The defence department takes only about 20 per cent of the housing. There is a mix of people. Up until last week most of those houses have been selling between $280,000 and $520,000—a considerable amount of money. Overnight, the prices of these houses have halved. People obviously do not want to live under the flight path, and Wattle Grove is right on the edge of the proposed airport.

We hear a lot in this place about honesty in politics, how we have all got to lift our game and how standards have to be lifted. If I were a voter in the federal electorate of Hughes, especially if I had just paid $520,000 for a house in the Wattle Grove estate, I would want to know why I was not informed prior to the election of the possibility of Holsworthy becoming an airport. We in the Public Works Committee did inspect and have a public hearing at Badgerys Creek. We also made certain recommendations concerning the infrastructure at Badgerys Creek.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about the EIS?

—You have had your chance. If you want to have a say, jump up when you get the call. I have always taken the view that it is pointless putting in an airport anywhere unless you have the proper infrastructure for it and that means a railroad and various other services. I was personally very concerned that that came about with Badgerys Creek.

SPEECH.PARA: We are now going into the business of deciding whether the airport is going to be at Holsworthy or Badgerys Creek. The Public Works Committee has not yet had a look at Holsworthy. I have had a look at the terrain and did my national service there—more years ago than I care to remember—and I know what it is like. Living just south of that area, I know what it is like. Also, having been somewhat involved over the last couple of years in various clean‐ups of unexploded ordnance, I know how expensive that will be.

Going ahead with an airport at Holsworthy would be a very expensive business but not nearly as expensive for the people who have been deceived. They bought their houses in good faith in places like Wattle Grove believing that they could raise their families there. Their homes, worth hundreds of thousands of dollars, have been devalued overnight.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gash, Joanna, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to address the issue of the Internet. In days gone by, parents would often worry that their children were playing on the roads. These days the information superhighway has become that road and parents should be just as worried. One of the responsibilities we have as parliamentarians is to design and introduce laws that protect the weak and the vulnerable. There is surely nothing more vulnerable in our society than our children.

SPEECH.PARA: I believe that one of the most radical changes in the past year relates to the Internet. Frankly, the law in regard to copyright and other issues has not kept up with the changing environment that the Internet provides us with. Access to its information, whilst exciting, has its ugly side. I am referring, of course, to child pornography on the Internet. Whilst this is disturbing enough, what really worries me is the fact that the Internet in a large proportion of Australian households is being used by children.

I recently read in a magazine about a child telling his father that mowing the lawn was hard but that programming the video recorder was easy. How true. I know from experience. For a long time I have felt that governments have a responsibility to establish guidelines to protect the most vulnerable in our society; that is, as I said, our children.

I understand that a chip called the V chip has been introduced in the United States. I believe that the United States Congress is looking at legislating that chip to be used in every television set. The chip allows responsible parents to program a code into the television, which means you can watch certain rated shows that have the code set by the parents. This allows parents to then monitor what programs the children are watching.

The V chip does require some technical advancements, such as digital television signals. However, the issue is that it can be done. Essentially, it is possible to have a similar chip for computers, but it is somewhat more difficult as it will require providers to indicate what sort of material they are providing via the signal.

Some providers are already doing this. America on Line is one that comes to mind, and other countries are considering it. One of the arguments that is presented against the V chip is that it will not be used. But we should surely give parents the choice rather than not have it available at all. Another argument is that it infringes on free speech. However, to cry `Fire!' in a crowded theatre is not freedom of speech; just as publishing child pornography on the Internet for other children to see is not freedom of speech.

This chip would only control the viewing of the most vulnerable in our society. Should the V chip be used in Australia, we must make sure that overseas countries are doing this by way of international treaties and common agreements. The chip costs under $2 and is relatively easy to install. The next time a constituent calls me with their concern and shows me the sort of graphic material that is available on their computer and how easy it is to log into these programs, I would find it irresponsible and difficult to say that we are not at least investigating the use of a chip that costs less than $2.

There is no place for pornography for children who look to us for leadership and example. I believe it is our duty to provide security and peace of mind for those parents who are unaware that this sort of material is available through the computer network. I stress that I find the Internet fascinating and understand that it will become part of our everyday lives. However, I do object to those with devious intents subjecting our children to this pornography. I will continue to lobby for censorship of the material on the information superhighway, as to me it is the equivalent to children playing on the road.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ellis, Annette, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —This evening I rise in the adjournment debate to talk about a local high school, the community of which I believe deserves commendation. Calwell High School in my electorate has decided this year, against enormous odds, to go ahead with its entry into this year's National Rock Eisteddfod Competition. This competition is an annual event in the ACT. High schools particularly and colleges participate in the competition in a very pro‐active and useful way, and students are encouraged to take part in something which is really very good for their expression. It is also good for anti-drug and anti-alcohol messages.

SPEECH.PARA: The problem with this year's Rock Eisteddfod, as is unfortunately the problem with many extracurricular activities this year throughout our schools in Canberra, has been caused by an industrial dispute between the local government and the ACT teachers. Unfortunately, and due to the ACT government's stubborn resistance to reaching some pay settlement in this very long and ongoing dispute, many extracurricular activities of our schools in the ACT are having to be curtailed.

However, the school community of Calwell High has got behind its student body and together they have managed to find the resources to go ahead and lodge their entry. The Rock Eisteddfod, which usually attracts entries from around 25 to 30 schools, this year will have entries of around 12. So Calwell High is not exactly on its own.

We are in tough times in Canberra. People are really withholding their spending. They are, unfortunately, a bit reticent about going too far forward at the moment because they do not quite know what is ahead of them in terms of financial support or in terms of work. At a time like this within any school community the parents in that community have the fortitude to get together, to get behind their kids and support an entry into something like the Rock Eisteddfod.

It is something we should commend. I would like to make particular note of the fact that Calwell High's entry this year is based on the theme `The Olympic dream: world peace through sport'. Most of the input into projects such as this comes from the kids themselves. It takes an awful lot of resources, particularly in terms of time for the parents, friends and kids themselves, to get the entry together and to get it to a level which the ACT is now used to seeing. Rock Eisteddfod competitions in the past have reached an incredibly high level. I am assured—and I feel very confident in saying this—that the Calwell High School entry will not disappoint us at all but will be of an incredibly high level and standard. As I said a moment ago, Calwell High is not on its own. There are around 10 or 11 other schools doing the same thing.

In my electorate in Tuggeranong there is very grave and severe concern about finance, employment and financial income for families, and it is our newer suburban area where a lot of young families exist and where a lot of double income families rely on every dollar they can get. Yet this school community has got itself together and is raising money outside its own normal efforts of raising money to exist as a school. It is doing everything it can to get this entry together.

I want to put on the record in this place my congratulations and my good wishes to everybody at Calwell High and to everybody in any other school community in the ACT who is doing likewise. At the same time, I implore the ACT government to get off their seats and do everything they can to help resolve what has been an ongoing dispute of far too long which deserves to be solved quickly.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans, Richard, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —Today in the House there was a lot of conjecture amongst those on the opposite side about a speech I presented last week in the debate on the supply bills. I am quite flattered by the fact that people actually scour the Hansard to read the things that I present in this House.

SPEECH.PARA: A number of people have wondered loudly and silently about who wrote this particular speech. I can say to the House, and I will advise those who are keen to know, that one Mr Peter Drucker wrote the speech. There are a lot of people who are asking whether that is good enough. There is another concern, another issue—that is, who presented it to me to present it in the House. I do not think that is important. It is important to recognise my own responsibility, and my own responsibility is to acknowledge that Peter Drucker wrote the speech.

I never sought any personal gain from that particular speech, and I acknowledge that. The ideas that Drucker has been speaking about for the last 40‐odd years are ideas that this side of politics is well aware of. It would be very keen if those on the other side, other than the member of Lalor (Mr Barry Jones), who is very widely read on the issue of Drucker, read it. I would like to thank the member for Werriwa (Mr Latham) for raising the issue today. I believe he spent time on the weekend faffing about with the articles of Drucker, and he might have learned something from doing that.

This day, I am writing to Mr Drucker in America advising him of the fact that I have raised his speech in this House. I look forward to his response to that. Once I have a response from Mr Drucker, I will gladly rise in this House to explain it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Latham, Mark, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —It is well and good for the member for Cowan (Mr Richard Evans) to try to explain this away, but the truth is that, if he were a university student plagiarising as extensively as he did in this House, he would be struck out of the university. If he were a medical researcher plagiarising someone else's materials, he would be struck off his practice. If he were a researcher in any academic field plagiarising this extensively, he would be thrown out of the university.

SPEECH.PARA: On 2 March, the people of Cowan did not elect Peter Drucker to the House of Representatives. Now they are being represented in this House not by the person whom they think they elected but by some American futurist who wrote an article in the Atlantic Monthly 18 months ago, only to be brazenly plagiarised by the member for Cowan.

The member had the hide to come into this place and say that somehow it is all right. At the end of his speech—once he finished reading out Peter Drucker's article to the House—he had the hide to say, `Oh, the Labor Party is not thinking about these things. Only the Liberal Party is dealing with these issues.' You must have established a new faction in the Liberal Party—the Peter Drucker faction—because you have no ideas. You have no original thoughts. You have stooped to the lowest of the low in parliamentary debate. You have been sent here by your electorate to represent their needs according to your own views and your own opinions, and all you can do is read out word for word, sentence for sentence and paragraph for paragraph someone else's ideas.

The member for Lindsay (Miss Jackie Kelly), who is sitting next to you, seems to think this is a joke. It is an appalling indictment of the parliamentary Liberal Party that you can do nothing better in the House of Representatives—the people's house, where you are supposed to represent the needs of your constituents—than read out word for word an article written by an American futurist some 18 months ago. It really is the lowest of the low.

BREAK.PARA: If you were a university student, you would resign. If you were a medical researcher, you would resign. If you were someone in public life who had any decency or any standards, you would resign. You are not representing the people of Cowan simply by plagiarising some American futurist with their particular words in this House. It is the lowest of the low. In 95 years this House of Representatives would never have heard of anything lower than a member plagiarising word for word, sentence for sentence and paragraph for paragraph some other person.

Whatever happened to representative politics? Whatever happened to representative democracy? Whatever happened to the decency of acknowledging that you are totally lifting someone else's views and trying to put them across in this House as your own? You were doing nothing more than trying to impress all these new backbenchers on the government side, trying to present yourself as a new‐age thinker, as a post‐industrial economist, trying to make a big man of yourself, a big thinker for the Liberal Party. You were doing nothing more than the lowest of the low, doing something that a first‐year university student would not do, doing something that a high school student would not do and doing something that is absolutely despicable by the standards of this House.

You are a disgrace to the House of Representatives. No member in 95 years has gone lower than this. You are an absolute disgrace. You should get out of here. If you want someone to represent the people of Cowan, the Labor Party is thinking of running Peter Drucker at the next election. We thought we might recruit him to our side of politics. We also have a slogan. He is going to run under the slogan `The real thing'. If the people of Cowan want Peter Drucker to represent their needs and put speeches forward in the House, why not? `Peter Drucker—the real thing. Vote 1 for the ALP in the seat of Cowan.'

That is how low you have gone. You are not someone who is a new‐age thinker, a post‐industrial economist, putting those views. You are nothing more than a cheat, a fraud and a plagiariser. You stand condemned.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The member for Werriwa will withdraw that word.
—What word, Mr Speaker?
—Cheat.
—If he is not cheating, what is he doing?
—I am asking you to withdraw.
—You are kidding. With respect to you, Mr Speaker, I withdraw.

BREAK.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.

PROCTEXT.PARA: The following notices were given:
Mr Filing to move—
That this House:

(1) notes growing community concern about the possible long term effects on children and some electronic equipment of exposure to electromagnetic radiation such as that emitted from mobile telephone towers; and;

(2) therefore calls on the Government to immediately legislate to alter the Telecommunications Code to ensure future mobile telephone towers are located at an assured safety distance from community facilities, including medical centres, shopping centres, homes and schools.
Mr Langmore to move—

That, in view of the (a) increase in unemployment resulting from downsizing in both business and the public sector, (b) damage to effective enterprise functioning from downsizing due to the decline of employee morale, greater insecurity and loss of initiative and dynamism and (c) the repudiation of downsizing by business opinion leaders in the USA, calls on both business and public sector organisations to reject the perverse and destructive strategy of downsizing and contribute instead to employment generating economic and social development.
Mr Richard Evans to move—
That this House:

(1) recognises that the construction of mobile phone towers should be under the guidelines of proper investigation into the health risks, environmental concerns and the well-being of the local community;
(2) suggests to the Minister for Communications and the Arts that no tower is constructed within 300‐500 metres of any school, day care centre, kindergarten or playground;

(3) recognises that the construction of mobile phone towers is increasing at a rapid rate and therefore recognises that precautionary policy initiatives should be taken in the decision making process of construction;
(4) calls for further research to be undertaken to study the health effects of electromagnetic radiation and microwave radiation emissions from mobile phone towers;

(5) calls for a set of proposals establishing clear consultation between local councils and ratepayers, to be established under the Telecommunications Act, whenever a mobile phone tower is proposed; and

(6) investigates the feasibility of a national buffer zone around any prospective tower that is to be built so that there at least 300‐500 metres from residential areas, schools, kindergartens, day care centres and playgrounds.
Mr Sinclair to move—
That this House:

(1) deplores the continuing neglect of basic human rights by the State Law and Order Restoration Council (SLORC) of Burma, including the use of forced labour, arbitrary arrest, the maltreatment of prisoners and the suppression of free speech and legitimate political activity;

(2) condemns the large scale, arbitrary arrests of members of the National League for Democracy (NLD) which have occurred in Burma over the last week and call for their immediate and unconditional release;
(3) rejects the explanation of the Government of Burma that the proposed meeting of the NLD to mark the anniversary of the 1990 election represented a threat to national stability or security;
(4) supports the moderate efforts of Daw Aung San Suu Kyi to negotiate democratic change in line with the expressed will of the Burmese people at the last free and fair elections in Burma in 1990;

(5) reminds the SLORC of the repeated international calls for dialogue between themselves and the NLD, the party which won a majority of the seats at the 1990 elections, as a prerequisite to full reinstatement of Burma within the international community; and

(6) urges regional governments, in particular the Governments of Thailand, Malaysia, Singapore and Indonesia to use their influence with the Government of Burma to effect the immediate release of those arrested, bring about dialogue between the SLORC and the NLD and encourage improvements in Burma's human rights record.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Regional Television Stations: Local News Services

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Andren, Peter, MP

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Communications and the Arts, upon notice, on 6 May 1996:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Will the Government's media inquiry investigate the requirement for local regional television stations to maintain an adequate and comprehensive local news service.
(2) Will the existing 75 per cent television network audience reach provision be retained.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Smith, Warwick, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Communications and the Arts has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

ANSWER.PARA: Consistent with the approach outlined by the Government in its pre‐election communications policy statement, the review of media ownership rules will consider what role media regulation can have in the future in achieving plurality, diversity and competition in the provision of media services in Australia. Detailed terms of reference are still under consideration.

(1) The Government is aware that there has been some concern in the past about the adequacy of local news services following the aggregation of television markets and the affiliation of regional television services with metropolitan networks. It is a condition of a commercial television broadcasting licence that the licensee provide a service that, when considered together with other broadcasting services available in the licence area of the licence, contributes to the provision of an adequate and comprehensive range of broadcasting services in that licence area.
‐ The Australian Broadcasting Authority is required to investigate complaints about a breach of conditions of a licence.

Accordingly, while it would not seem to be necessary to specifically direct that the review of the ownership and control rules examine this issue, the terms of reference for the review should be broad enough to allow it to be examined if those undertaking the review deem this to be appropriate. The review will be a public review and members of the public will be able to make submissions on all matters that they consider relevant to the ownership and control rules.
(2) The 75% audience reach limit is one of the key control rules in the Broadcasting Services Act 1992, and will thus be central to the review.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission: Commissioners

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Campbell, Graeme, MP

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs, upon notice, on 7 May 1996:

QUESTION.PARA: Is it a fact that under the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission Act 1989, the conditions of appointment applying to commissioners of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission (ATSIC) are less stringent than those applying to subordinate positions in ATSIC; if so why.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Wooldridge, Dr Michael, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

ANSWER.PARA: It is not a fact that under the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission Act 1989 (the Act), the conditions of appointment applying to ATSIC commissioners are less stringent than those applying to subordinate positions in ATSIC.
Section 31 of the Act specifies the qualifications for appointment as a Commissioner. The section provides that a person is not qualified to be appointed as a Commissioner:
unless the person is an Aboriginal person or a Torres Strait Islander; or
if the person has been convicted of an offence against a Commonwealth, State or Territory law and sentenced to imprisonment for one year or longer; or
if the person has been convicted of an offence against a Commonwealth, State or Territory law involving dishonesty and sentenced to imprisonment for 3 months or longer.
The section further provides that a person convicted of an offence is not disqualified from appointment as a Commissioner if:
where the person was never actually imprisoned for the offence, at least 2 years have elapsed since the person was convicted; or
where the person has served a term of imprisonment, at least 2 years have elapsed since the person was released from prison.

The 17 elected Commissioners (of the total of 19 Commissioners) must also first satisfy the qualifications for election as a member of a Regional Council. These qualifications are specified in section 102 of the Act and include that a person is not qualified for election as a member for a Regional Council ward if:
the person is not entitled to vote at the Regional Council ward election concerned;
the person does not live in the ward;
the person is a member of the staff of, or a consultant to, the Commission;
the person is bankrupt; or
there is in operation a composition, deed of arrangement or deed of assignment with the person's creditors under the law relating to bankruptcy.
Section 46 of the Act deals with the appointment of a Chief Executive Officer (CEO) of the Commission. The only expressed limitations on the appointment of a CEO are that:
the Minister shall not appoint a person as CEO unless the Commission agrees to the appointment (section 46); and
a person who is 65 years old or older may not hold office as CEO (section 47).

Staff of the administrative arm of ATSIC, under the CEO, are engaged under the provisions of the Public Service Act 1922 and are subject to the normal appointment provisions under that Act which apply to other members of the Australian Public Service. These are not considered to be more stringent than the appointment conditions which apply to ATSIC Commissioners.

The Act also includes provisions for the termination of the appointment of Commissioners (section 40) and the CEO (section 53). There are considerable similarities between the matters for which Commissioners or the CEO may have their appointments terminated. The few differences which do exist between the provisions reflect the different status and roles of Commissioners and the CEO. Of greatest significance is that 17 of the 19 Commissioners are democratically elected to represent the interests of their constituents, whereas the CEO is appointed to manage the day‐to‐day administration of the Commission, in accordance with any policies determined, and any directions given, by the Commission in writing.

When considering the provisions for termination of Commissioners, it is important to note that, under subsection 40(6) of the Act, if an elected Commissioner ceases to be a member of a Regional Council, otherwise than by resigning from the Regional Council, their appointment as a Commissioner may be terminated by the Minister. Sections 121, 122 and 122A of the Act include provisions by which people may cease to be members of Regional Councils by means other than resignation.
